attribute.name: Description
attribute.value:
Class: ratio of the number of documented public methods in the class +1 if the class itself is documented to the number of all public methods in the class + 1 (the class itself); however, the nested, anonymous, and local classes are not included.
Package: ratio of the number of documented public classes and methods in the package to the number of all of its public classes and methods; however, the classes and methods of its subpackages are not included.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: API Documentation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Class: ratio of the number of documented public methods in the class +1 if the class itself is documented to the number of all public methods in the class + 1 (the class itself); however, the nested, anonymous, and local classes are not included.

Package: ratio of the number of documented public classes and methods in the package to the number of all of its public classes and methods; however, the classes and methods of its subpackages are not included.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Super call should be the first method invocation in the method.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Call Super First

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Call Super First: Super call should be the first method invocation in the override ofthe following methods of the Activity, Application, Service and Fragmentclasses:

  • onCreate()
  • onConfigurationChanged()
  • onPostCreate()
  • onPostResume()
  • onRestart()
  • onRestorInstanceState()
  • onResume()
  • onStart()
Example(s):

public class MyActivity extends Activity{
  public void onCreate(Bundle bundle) {
    foo();
    ...
    super.onCreate(bundle);
    ...
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Super call should be the last method invocation in the method.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Call Super Last

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Call Super Last: Super call should be the last method invocation in the override ofthe following methods of the Activity, Application, Service and Fragment classes:

  • finish()
  • onDestroy()
  • onPause()
  • onSaveInstanceState()
  • onStop()
  • onTerminate()
Example(s):

public class MyActivity extends Activity{
  public void onStop() {
    ...
    super.onStop();
    ...
    foo();
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Hard-code external storage directory can easily lead to faults, as it can differ on different devices.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Do not hard code the SD card.

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Do Not Hard Code SD Card: Hard-coding external storage directory can easily lead to faults, asit can differ on different devices. Instead of “/sdcard” use thegetExternalStorageDirectory() method of the android.os.Environment class.

Example(s):

public class MyActivity extends Activity{
  public void foo() {
    String storage =“/sdcard/myfolder”;
    ...
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: If you use SQLiteOpenHelper, make sure to avoid calling getReadableDatabase() or getWritableDatabase() from ContentProvider.onCreate(), as database upgrade may take a long time.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Do Not Open Database In ContentProvider

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Do Not Open Database In ContentProvider: Database upgrade may take a long time, you should not call thegetWritableDatabase() and the getReadableDatabase() methods from the ContentProvider.onCreate().

Example(s):

public class MyContentProvider extends ContentProvider{
  public boolean onCreate() {
    DatabaseHelper foo = newDatabaseHelper(getContext());
    SQLiteDatabase db = foo.getReadableDatabase();
    ...
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The name of a database should be final, if it is possible.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Database Name Should Be Final

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Database Name Should Be Final: The name of a database should be final, if it is possible.

Example(s):

public class DatabaseHelper extends SQLiteOpenHelper{
  private String DATABASE_NAME =“mydatabase.db”
  ...
  // The content of DATABASE_NAME doesnot change
  ...
  DatabaseHelper(Context context) {
    super(context,DATABASE_NAME, DATABASE_VERSION);
    ...
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Derived classes must call through to the super class's implementation of this method. If they do not, an exception will be thrown.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Is Super Called

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Is Super Called: In the classes, which inherits from Activity, you must call throughto the super class's implementation, if you override the so-called lifecycle methods.Otherwise, an exception will be thrown.The Activity’s lifecycle methodsare the following:

  • onCreate()
  • onStart()
  • onPause()
  • onResume()
  • onDestroy()
  • onRestart()
  • onStop()
  • onSaveInstanceState()
Example(s):

public class MyActivity extends Activity{
  @Override
  public void onCreate(BundlesavedInstanceState) {
    ...
    //Missing super.onCreate()
    ...
  }
  ...
  @Override
  protected void onStop() {
    ...
    //Missing super.onStop()
    ...
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Derived classes must call through to the super class's implementation of this method. If they do not, an exception will be thrown.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Is Super Called Fragment

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Is Super Called Fragment: In the classes, which extends Fragment, you must call through tothe super class's implementation, if you override the following methods:

  • onInflate()
  • onAttach()
  • onCreate()
  • onActivityCreated()
  • onViewStateRestored()
  • onStart()
  • onResume()
  • onConfigurationChanged ()
  • onPause()
  • onStop()
  • onLowMemory()
  • onTrimMemory()
  • onDestroyView()
  • onDestroy()
  • onDetach()
Otherwise, an exception will be thrown.

Example(s):

public class MyFragment extends Fragment{
  @Override
  public void onAttach(Activity activity){
    ...
    //Missing super.onAttach(activity)
    ...
  }
  ...
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: If you attach a listener to a location resource then you should always detach it.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Missing Remove Updates

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Missing Remove Updates: If you attach a listener to a location resource then you shouldalways detach it.

Example(s):

public class MyActivity extends Activity implementsLocationListener {
  @Override
  public void onStart(BundlesavedInstanceState) {
    ...
    myLocationManager.requestLocationUpdates(
      LocationManager.GPS_PROVIDER,0, 0, this);
    ...
  }
  ...
  //Missing lm.removeUpdates(this);
  ...
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: If you register a receiver in your Activity.onResume() implementation, you should unregister it in Activity.onPause() (you won't receive intents when paused, and this will cut down on unnecessary system overhead).

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Missing Unregister Receiver In Activity

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Missing Unregister Receiver In Activity: If you register a receiver in your Activity.onResume()implementation, you should unregister it in Activity.onPause() You won'treceive intents when paused, and this will cut down on unnecessary systemoverhead.

Example(s):

public class MyActivity extends Activity {
  @Override
  public void onResume() {
    ...
    registerReceiver(myReceiver,new IntentFilter(
     WifiManager.SCAN_RESULTS_AVAILABLE_ACTION));
    ...
  }
  ...
  @Override
  public void onPause() {
    ...
    //Missing unregisterReceiver(myReceiver);
    ...
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Do not place any release of resources in Activity.onSaveInstanceState(), because this callback is not always called when an activity is being placed in the background or on its way to destruction.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Resource Release In The Wrong Place

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Resource Release In The Wrong Place: Do not place any release of resources inActivity.onSaveInstanceState(), because this callback is not always called whenan activity is being placed in the background or on its way to destruction. Anideal place to release resources is the Activity.onPause().

Example(s):

public class MyActivity extends Activity {
  @Override
  public void onSaveInstanceState(BundeloutState) {
    ...
   unregisterReceiver(myReceiver); //wrong place
    ...
  }
  ...
  public void onPause() {
    ...
    unregisterReceiver(myReceiver);//good place
    ...
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An AntiPattern is a literary form that describes a commonly occurring solution to a problem that generates decidedly negative consequences. The AntiPattern may be the result of a manager or developer not knowing any better, not having sufficient knowledge or experience in solving a particular type of problem, or having applied a perfectly good pattern in the wrong context.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Anti Pattern

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: An AntiPattern is a literary form that describes a commonly occurring solution to a problem that generates decidedly negative consequences. The AntiPattern may be the result of a manager or developer not knowing any better, not having sufficient knowledge or experience in solving a particular type of problem, or having applied a perfectly good pattern in the wrong context.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bad Practice Rules

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Violations of recommended and essential coding practice. Examples include hash code and equals problems, cloneable idiom, dropped exceptions, Serializable problems, and misuse of finalize. We strive to make this analysis accurate, although some groups may not care about some of the bad practices.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Rules which enforce generally accepted best practices.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Best Practice Rules

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Rules which enforce generally accepted best practices.

attribute.name: Description

Clone class: sum of CE of the clone instances of the clone class + 1.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Clone Embeddedness

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Clone instance: sum of incoming and outgoing references (function calls, variable references, type references; different references to the same entity are counted only once) in the code fragment corresponding to the clone instance, weighted with the number of directory changes between the referenced code fragments.
Clone class: sum of CE of the clone instances of the clone class + 1.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value:
Clone class: index of the effort required to eliminate the clone class. It is computed as the product of CI, CE, and NCR.
Component: index of the effort required to eliminate all clones from the component. It is computed as the sum of CEE of the clone classes in the component.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Clone Elimination Effort

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Clone class: index of the effort required to eliminate the clone class. It is computed as the product of CI, CE, and NCR.
Component: index of the effort required to eliminate all clones from the component. It is computed as the sum of CEE of the clone classes in the component.

attribute.name: HelpText

attribute.name: Description

Clone class: index of the gain resulting from eliminating the clone class. It is computed as the ratio of CR to CEE.
Component: index of the gain resulting from eliminating all clones from the component. It is computed as the logistic function of the ratio of CR to CEE.

Clone class: index of the gain resulting from eliminating the clone class. It is computed as the ratio of CR to CEE.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value:
Clone class: risk index of the existence of the clone class. It is computed as the product of CLLOC, CI, CCO, NCR, and CV.
Component: relative risk index of the existence of code duplications in the component. It is computed as the sum of CR of the clone classes in the component, divided by the total logical lines of code (non-empty, non-comment lines) of the component. It expresses the risk index projected to a non-empty, non-comment line of code in the component.

attribute.name: DisplayName

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Clone class: risk index of the existence of the clone class. It is computed as the product of CLLOC, CI, CCO, NCR, and CV.
Component: relative risk index of the existence of code duplications in the component. It is computed as the sum of CR of the clone classes in the component, divided by the total logical lines of code (non-empty, non-comment lines) of the component. It expresses the risk index projected to a non-empty, non-comment line of code in the component.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value:
Clone instance: instability of the clone instance since it appeared. It is computed as the ratio of the number of previously analyzed revisions when the instance had been changed to its age (CA).
Clone class: instability of the clone class since it appeared. It is computed as the ratio of the number of previously analyzed revisions when its contained instances were moved, deleted, or added, to its age (CA), plus the average CV of its clone instances.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Rules that help you discover design issues.

attribute.value: Rules that help you discover design issues.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: In software engineering, a design pattern is a general repeatable solution to a commonly occurring problem in software design. A design pattern isn't a finished design that can be transformed directly into code. It is a description or template for how to solve a problem that can be used in many different situations.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Design Pattern

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: In software engineering, a design pattern is a general repeatable solution to a commonly occurring problem in software design. A design pattern isn't a finished design that can be transformed directly into code. It is a description or template for how to solve a problem that can be used in many different situations.

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: code that is confusing, anomalous, or written in a way that leads itself to errors. Examples include dead local stores, switch fall through, unconfirmed casts, and redundant null check of value known to be null. More false positives accepted. In previous versions of SpotBugs, this category was known as Style.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Creates an empty jar file entry

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Creates Empty Jar File Entry

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The code calls putNextEntry(), immediately followed by a call to closeEntry(). This results in an empty JarFile entry. The contents of the entry should be written to the JarFile between the calls to putNextEntry() and closeEntry().

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Creates an empty zip file entry

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Creates Empty Zip File Entry

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The code calls putNextEntry(), immediately followed by a call to closeEntry(). This results in an empty ZipFile entry. The contents of the entry should be written to the ZipFile between the calls to putNextEntry() and closeEntry().

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Explicit invocation of finalizer

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Explicit Invocation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This method contains an explicit invocation of the finalize() method on an object.Â  Because finalizer methods are supposed to be executed once, and only by the VM, this is a bad idea.

If a connected set of objects beings finalizable, then the VM will invoke the finalize method on all the finalizable object, possibly at the same time in different threads. Thus, it is a particularly bad idea, in the finalize method for a class X, invoke finalize on objects referenced by X, because they may already be getting finalized in a separate thread.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: BigDecimal constructed from double that isn't represented precisely

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bigdecimal Constructed From Double

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code creates a BigDecimal from a double value that doesnât translate well to a decimal number. For example, one might assume that writing new BigDecimal(0.1) in Java creates a BigDecimal which is exactly equal to 0.1 (an unscaled value of 1, with a scale of 1), but it is actually equal to 0.1000000000000000055511151231257827021181583404541015625. You probably want to use the BigDecimal.valueOf(double d) method, which uses the String representation of the double to create the BigDecimal (e.g., BigDecimal.valueOf(0.1) gives 0.1).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Sequence of calls to concurrent abstraction may not be atomic

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Operation Sequence On Concurrent Abstraction

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code contains a sequence of calls to a concurrent abstraction (such as a concurrent hash map). These calls will not be executed atomically.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class is final but declares protected field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Confused Inheritance

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class is declared to be final, but declares fields to be protected. Since the class is final, it can not be derived from, and the use of protected is confusing. The access modifier for the field should be changed to private or public to represent the true use for the field.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Incompatible bit masks

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method compares an expression of the form (e & C) to D, which will always compare unequal due to the specific values of constants C and D. This may indicate a logic error or typo.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Bitwise add of signed byte value

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Add Of Signed Byte

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Adds a byte value and a value which is known to have the 8 lower bits clear. Values loaded from a byte array are sign extended to 32 bits before any bitwise operations are performed on the value. Thus, if b[0] contains the value 0xff, and x is initially 0, then the code ((x << 8) + b[0]) will sign extend 0xff to get 0xffffffff, and thus give the value 0xffffffff as the result.

In particular, the following code for packing a byte array into an int is badly wrong:

int result = 0;
for(int i = 0; i < 4; i++)
    result = ((result << 8) + b[i]);

The following idiom will work instead:

int result = 0;
for(int i = 0; i < 4; i++)
    result = ((result << 8) + (b[i] & 0xff));

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Check to see if ((...) & 0) == 0

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: And Zz

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method compares an expression of the form (e & 0) to 0, which will always compare equal. This may indicate a logic error or typo.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Bad Applet Constructor relies on uninitialized AppletStub

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bad Applet Constructor

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This constructor calls methods in the parent Applet that rely on the AppletStub. Since the AppletStub isn't initialized until the init() method of this applet is called, these methods will not perform correctly.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Questionable cast to abstract collection

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bad Cast To Abstract Collection

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code casts a Collection to an abstract collection (such as List, Set, or Map). Ensure that you are guaranteed that the object is of the type you are casting to. If all you need is to be able to iterate through a collection, you donât need to cast it to a Set or List.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Questionable cast to concrete collection

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bad Cast To Concrete Collection

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code casts an abstract collection (such as a Collection, List, or Set) to a specific concrete implementation (such as an ArrayList or HashSet). This might not be correct, and it may make your code fragile, since it makes it harder to switch to other concrete implementations at a future point. Unless you have a particular reason to do so, just use the abstract collection class.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Primitive value is boxed and then immediately unboxed

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Boxing Immediately Unboxed

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A primitive is boxed, and then immediately unboxed. This probably is due to a manual boxing in a place where an unboxed value is required, thus forcing the compiler to immediately undo the work of the boxing.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Primitive value is boxed then unboxed to perform primitive coercion

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Boxing Immediately Unboxed To Perform Coercion

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A primitive boxed value constructed and then immediately converted into a different primitive type (e.g., new Double(d).intValue()). Just perform direct primitive coercion (e.g., (int) d).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class overrides a method implemented in super class Adapter wrongly

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Badly Overridden Adapter

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method overrides a method found in a parent class, where that class is an Adapter that implements a listener defined in the java.awt.event or javax.swing.event package. As a result, this method will not get called when the event occurs.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Doomed test for equality to NaN

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Test If Equal To Not A Number

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code checks to see if a floating point value is equal to the special Not A Number value (e.g., if (x == Double.NaN)). However, because of the special semantics of NaN, no value is equal to Nan, including NaN. Thus, x == Double.NaN always evaluates to false. To check to see if a value contained in x is the special Not A Number value, use Double.isNaN(x) (or Float.isNaN(x) if x is floating point precision).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Equals method should not assume anything about the type of its argument

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Equals Method Should Work For All Objects

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The equals(Object o) method shouldnât make any assumptions about the type of o. It should simply return false if o is not the same type as this.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Impossible cast

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Impossible Cast

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This cast will always throw a ClassCastException. SpotBugs tracks type information from instanceof checks, and also uses more precise information about the types of values returned from methods and loaded from fields. Thus, it may have more precise information that just the declared type of a variable, and can use this to determine that a cast will always throw an exception at runtime.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Impossible downcast

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Impossible Downcast

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This cast will always throw a ClassCastException. The analysis believes it knows the precise type of the value being cast, and the attempt to downcast it to a subtype will always fail by throwing a ClassCastException.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Bitwise OR of signed byte value

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Ior Of Signed Byte

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Loads a byte value (e.g., a value loaded from a byte array or returned by a method with return type byte) and performs a bitwise OR with that value. Byte values are sign extended to 32 bits before any bitwise operations are performed on the value. Thus, if b[0] contains the value 0xff, and x is initially 0, then the code ((x << 8) | b[0]) will sign extend 0xff to get 0xffffffff, and thus give the value 0xffffffff as the result.

In particular, the following code for packing a byte array into an int is badly wrong:

int result = 0;
for(int i = 0; i < 4; i++) {
    result = ((result << 8) | b[i]);
}

The following idiom will work instead:

int result = 0;
for(int i = 0; i < 4; i++) {
    result = ((result << 8) | (b[i] & 0xff));
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Check for sign of bitwise operation

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Signed Check

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method compares an expression such as ((event.detail & SWT.SELECTED) > 0). Using bit arithmetic and then comparing with the greater than operator can lead to unexpected results (of course depending on the value of SWT.SELECTED). If SWT.SELECTED is a negative number, this is a candidate for a bug. Even when SWT.SELECTED is not negative, it seems good practice to use â!= 0â instead of â> 0â.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Check for sign of bitwise operation involving negative number

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Signed Check High Bit

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method compares a bitwise expression such as ((val & CONSTANT) > 0) where CONSTANT is the negative number. Using bit arithmetic and then comparing with the greater than operator can lead to unexpected results. This comparison is unlikely to work as expected. The good practice is to use â!= 0â instead of â> 0â.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Primitive value is unboxed and coerced for ternary operator

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unboxed And Coerced For Ternary Operator

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A wrapped primitive value is unboxed and converted to another primitive type as part of the evaluation of a conditional ternary operator (the b ? e1 : e2 operator). The semantics of Java mandate that if e1 and e2 are wrapped numeric values, the values are unboxed and converted/coerced to their common type (e.g, if e1 is of type Integer and e2 is of type Float, then e1 is unboxed, converted to a floating point value, and boxed. See JLS Section 15.25.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Unchecked/unconfirmed cast

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unconfirmed Cast

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This cast is unchecked, and not all instances of the type casted from can be cast to the type it is being cast to. Check that your program logic ensures that this cast will not fail.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Unchecked/unconfirmed cast of return value from method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unconfirmed Cast Of Return Value

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code performs an unchecked cast of the return value of a method. The code might be calling the method in such a way that the cast is guaranteed to be safe, but SpotBugs is unable to verify that the cast is safe. Check that your program logic ensures that this cast will not fail.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Boxed value is unboxed and then immediately reboxed

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unboxing Immediately Reboxed

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A boxed value is unboxed and then immediately reboxed.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: instanceof will always return true

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Vacuous Instanceof

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This instanceof test will always return true (unless the value being tested is null). Although this is safe, make sure it isnât an indication of some misunderstanding or some other logic error. If you really want to test the value for being null, perhaps it would be clearer to do better to do a null test rather than an instanceof test.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Possible bad parsing of shift operation

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Wrong Add Priority

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The code performs an operation like (x << 8 + y). Although this might be correct, probably it was meant to perform (x << 8) + y, but shift operation has a lower precedence, so itâs actually parsed as x << (8 + y).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: instanceof will always return false

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Impossible Instanceof

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This instanceof test will always return false. Although this is safe, make sure it isnât an indication of some misunderstanding or some other logic error.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Incompatible bit masks

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This method compares an expression of the form (e | C) to D. which will always compare unequal due to the specific values of constants C and D. This may indicate a logic error or typo.

Typically, this bug occurs because the code wants to perform a membership test in a bit set, but uses the bitwise OR operator (â|â) instead of bitwise AND (â&â).

Also such bug may appear in expressions like (e & A | B) == C which is parsed like ((e & A) | B) == C while (e & (A | B)) == C was intended.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Abstract class defines covariant compareTo() method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Abstract Self

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class defines a covariant version of `compareTo()`.Â To correctly override the `compareTo()` method in the `Comparable` interface, the parameter of `compareTo()` must have type `java.lang.Object`.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Possibly incompatible element is stored in covariant array

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Covariant Array Element Store

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Value is stored into the array and the value type doesn't match the array type. It's known from the analysis that actual array type is narrower than the declared type of its variable or field and this assignment doesn't satisfy the original array type. This assignment may cause ArrayStoreException at runtime.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Covariant array assignment to a field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Covariant Array Field

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Covariant array assignment to a local variable

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Covariant Array Local

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Covariant array is returned from the method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Covariant Array Return

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Array of covariant type is returned from the method. This is confusing and may lead to ArrayStoreException at runtime if the calling code will try to store the reference of some other type in the returned array.
Consider changing the type of created array or the method return type.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Test for circular dependencies among classes

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Circular Dependency

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class has a circular dependency with other classes. This makes building these classes difficult, as each is dependent on the other to build correctly. Consider using interfaces to break the hard dependency.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Impossible downcast of toArray() result

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Impossible Downcast Of Toarray

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This code is casting the result of calling toArray() on a collection to a type more specific than Object[], as in:

String[] getAsArray(Collection<String> c) {
    return (String[]) c.toArray();
}

This will usually fail by throwing a ClassCastException. The toArray() of almost all collections return an Object[]. They canât really do anything else, since the Collection object has no reference to the declared generic type of the collection.

The correct way to do get an array of a specific type from a collection is to use c.toArray(new String[]); or c.toArray(new String[c.size()]); (the latter is slightly more efficient).

There is one common/known exception to this. The toArray() method of lists returned by Arrays.asList(...) will return a covariantly typed array. For example, Arrays.asArray(new String[] { "a" }).toArray() will return a String []. SpotBugs attempts to detect and suppress such cases, but may miss some.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: compareTo()/compare() incorrectly handles float or double value

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Compareto Incorrect Floating

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method compares double or float values using pattern like this: val1 > val2 ? 1 : val1 < val2 ? -1 : 0. This pattern works incorrectly for -0.0 and NaN values which may result in incorrect sorting result or broken collection (if compared values are used as keys). Consider using Double.compare or Float.compare static methods which handle all the special cases correctly.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: compareTo()/compare() returns Integer.MIN_VALUE

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Compareto Results Min Value

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: In some situation, this compareTo or compare method returns the constant Integer.MIN_VALUE, which is an exceptionally bad practice. The only thing that matters about the return value of compareTo is the sign of the result. But people will sometimes negate the return value of compareTo, expecting that this will negate the sign of the result. And it will, except in the case where the value returned is Integer.MIN_VALUE. So just return -1 rather than Integer.MIN_VALUE.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class defines clone() but doesn't implement Cloneable

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Implements Clone But Not Cloneable

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class defines a clone() method but the class doesnât implement Cloneable. There are some situations in which this is OK (e.g., you want to control how subclasses can clone themselves), but just make sure that this is what you intended.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class names should start with an upper case letter

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Class Naming Convention

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Class names should be nouns, in mixed case with the first letter of each internal word capitalized. Try to keep your class names simple and descriptive. Use whole words-avoid acronyms and abbreviations (unless the abbreviation is much more widely used than the long form, such as URL or HTML).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Rough value of known constant found

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Rough Constant Value

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Itâs recommended to use the predefined library constant for code clarity and better precision.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Covariant compareTo() method defined

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Self No Object

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class defines a covariant version of `compareTo()`.Â To correctly override the `compareTo()` method in the `Comparable` interface, the parameter of `compareTo()` must have type `java.lang.Object`.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class implements Cloneable but does not define or use clone method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Class implements Cloneable but does not define or use the clone method.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Can't use reflection to check for presence of annotation without runtime retention

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Annotation Is Not Visible To Reflection

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Unless an annotation has itself been annotated with @Retention(RetentionPolicy.RUNTIME), the annotation canât be observed using reflection (e.g., by using the isAnnotationPresent method). .

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Reversed method arguments

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Arguments Wrong Order

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The arguments to this method call seem to be in the wrong order. For example, a call Preconditions.checkNotNull("message", message) has reserved arguments: the value to be checked is the first argument.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method invokes inefficient Boolean constructor; use Boolean.valueOf(...) instead

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Boolean Ctor

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Creating new instances of java.lang.Boolean wastes memory, since Boolean objects are immutable and there are only two useful values of this type.Â  Use the Boolean.valueOf() method (or Java 1.5 autoboxing) to create Boolean objects instead.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Bad constant value for month

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bad Month

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code passes a constant month value outside the expected range of 0..11 to a method.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The equals and hashCode methods of URL are blocking

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Blocking Methods On Url

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The equals and hashCode method of URL perform domain name resolution, this can result in a big performance hit. See http://michaelscharf.blogspot.com/2006/11/javaneturlequals-and-hashcode-make.html for more information. Consider using java.net.URI instead.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Boxing a primitive to compare

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Boxed Primitive For Compare

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A boxed primitive is created just to call compareTo method. Itâs more efficient to use static compare method (for double and float since Java 1.4, for other primitive types since Java 1.7) which works on primitives directly.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Boxing/unboxing to parse a primitive

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Boxed Primitive For Parsing

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A boxed primitive is created from a String, just to extract the unboxed primitive value. It is more efficient to just call the static parseXXX method.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method allocates a boxed primitive just to call toString

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Boxed Primitive Tostring

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A boxed primitive is allocated just to call toString(). It is more effective to just use the static form of toString which takes the primitive value. So,

Replaceâ¦ With thisâ¦
new Integer(1).toString() Integer.toString(1)
new Long(1).toString() Long.toString(1)
new Float(1.0).toString() Float.toString(1.0)
new Double(1.0).toString() Double.toString(1.0)
new Byte(1).toString() Byte.toString(1)
new Short(1).toString() Short.toString(1)
new Boolean(true).toString() Boolean.toString(true)

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Classloaders should only be created inside doPrivileged block

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Create Classloader Inside Do Privileged

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code creates a classloader, which needs permission if a security manage is installed. If this code might be invoked by code that does not have security permissions, then the classloader creation needs to occur inside a doPrivileged block.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Hardcoded constant database password

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Constant Db Password

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code creates a database connect using a hardcoded, constant password. Anyone with access to either the source code or the compiled code can easily learn the password.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Possible double check of field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method may contain an instance of double-checked locking.Â  This idiom is not correct according to the semantics of the Java memory model.Â  For more information, see the web page http://www.cs.umd.edu/~pugh/java/memoryModel/DoubleCheckedLocking.html.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: hasNext method invokes next

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Calling Next From Hasnext

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The hasNext() method invokes the next() method. This is almost certainly wrong, since the hasNext() method is not supposed to change the state of the iterator, and the next method is supposed to change the state of the iterator.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Maps and sets of URLs can be performance hogs

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Collection Of Urls

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method or field is or uses a Map or Set of URLs. Since both the equals and hashCode method of URL perform domain name resolution, this can result in a big performance hit. See http://michaelscharf.blogspot.com/2006/11/javaneturlequals-and-hashcode-make.html for more information. Consider using java.net.URI instead.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Collections should not contain themselves

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Collections Should Not Contain Themselves

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This call to a generic collectionâs method would only make sense if a collection contained itself (e.g., if s.contains(s) were true). This is unlikely to be true and would cause problems if it were true (such as the computation of the hash code resulting in infinite recursion). It is likely that the wrong value is being passed as a parameter.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Invokes run on a thread (did you mean to start it instead?)

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Invoke Run

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method explicitly invokes run() on an object.Â  In general, classes implement the Runnable interface because they are going to have their run() method invoked in a new thread, in which case Thread.start() is the right method to call.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method uses the same code for two branches

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Duplicate Branches

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method uses the same code to implement two branches of a conditional branch. Check to ensure that this isnât a coding mistake.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Reliance on default encoding

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Default Encoding

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Found a call to a method which will perform a byte to String (or String to byte) conversion, and will assume that the default platform encoding is suitable. This will cause the application behaviour to vary between platforms. Use an alternative API and specify a charset name or Charset object explicitly.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method invoked that should be only be invoked inside a doPrivileged block

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Do Inside Do Privileged

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code invokes a method that requires a security permission check. If this code will be granted security permissions, but might be invoked by code that does not have security permissions, then the invocation needs to occur inside a doPrivileged block.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Dead store to local variable

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dead Local Store

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This instruction assigns a value to a local variable, but the value is not read or used in any subsequent instruction. Often, this indicates an error, because the value computed is never used.

Note that Sunâs javac compiler often generates dead stores for final local variables. Because SpotBugs is a bytecode-based tool, there is no easy way to eliminate these false positives.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Useless assignment in return statement

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dead Local Store In Return

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This statement assigns to a local variable in a return statement. This assignment has effect. Please verify that this statement does the right thing.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Dead store of null to local variable

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dead Local Store Of Null

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The code stores null into a local variable, and the stored value is not read. This store may have been introduced to assist the garbage collector, but as of Java SE 6.0, this is no longer needed or useful.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Dead store to local variable that shadows field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dead Local Store Shadows Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This instruction assigns a value to a local variable, but the value is not read or used in any subsequent instruction. Often, this indicates an error, because the value computed is never used. There is a field with the same name as the local variable. Did you mean to assign to that variable instead?

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method uses the same code for two switch clauses

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Duplicate Switch Clauses

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method uses the same code to implement two clauses of a switch statement. This could be a case of duplicate code, but it might also indicate a coding mistake.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Dead store of class literal

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dead Store Of Class Literal

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This instruction assigns a class literal to a variable and then never uses it. The behavior of this differs in Java 1.4 and in Java 5. In Java 1.4 and earlier, a reference to Foo.class would force the static initializer for Foo to be executed, if it has not been executed already. In Java 5 and later, it does not.

See Sunâs article on Java SE compatibility for more details and examples, and suggestions on how to force class initialization in Java 5.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Empty database password

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Db Password

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code creates a database connect using a blank or empty password. This indicates that the database is not protected by a password.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Adding elements of an entry set may fail due to reuse of Entry objects

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Entry Sets May Reuse Entry Objects

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The entrySet() method is allowed to return a view of the underlying Map in which a single Entry object is reused and returned during the iteration. As of Java 1.6, both IdentityHashMap and EnumMap did so. When iterating through such a Map, the Entry value is only valid until you advance to the next iteration. If, for example, you try to pass such an entrySet to an addAll method, things will go badly wrong.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Futile attempt to change max pool size of ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Futile Attempt To Change Maxpool Size Of Scheduled Thread Pool Executor

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: (Javadoc) While ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor inherits from ThreadPoolExecutor, a few of the inherited tuning methods are not useful for it. In particular, because it acts as a fixed-sized pool using corePoolSize threads and an unbounded queue, adjustments to maximumPoolSize have no useful effect.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method invokes inefficient floating-point Number constructor; use static valueOf instead

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Fp Number Ctor

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Using new Double(double) is guaranteed to always result in a new object whereas Double.valueOf(double) allows caching of values to be done by the compiler, class library, or JVM. Using of cached values avoids object allocation and the code will be faster.

Unless the class must be compatible with JVMs predating Java 1.5, use either autoboxing or the valueOf() method when creating instances of Double and Float.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Code contains a hard coded reference to an absolute pathname

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Hardcoded Absolute Filename

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code constructs a File object using a hard coded to an absolute pathname (e.g., new File("/home/dannyc/workspace/j2ee/src/share/com/sun/enterprise/deployment");

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Invocation of hashCode on an array

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Invoking Hashcode On Array

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The code invokes hashCode on an array. Calling hashCode on an array returns the same value as System.identityHashCode, and ignores the contents and length of the array. If you need a hashCode that depends on the contents of an array a, use java.util.Arrays.hashCode(a).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Incorrect combination of Math.max and Math.min

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Invalid Min Max

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code tries to limit the value bounds using the construct like Math.min(0, Math.max(100, value)). However the order of the constants is incorrect: it should be Math.min(100, Math.max(0, value)). As the result this code always produces the same result (or NaN if the value is NaN).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Invocation of toString on an array

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Invoking Tostring On Array

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The code invokes toString on an array, which will generate a fairly useless result such as [C@16f0472. Consider using Arrays.toString to convert the array into a readable String that gives the contents of the array. See Programming Puzzlers, chapter 3, puzzle 12.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Invocation of toString on an unnamed array

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Invoking Tostring On Anonymous Array

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The code invokes toString on an (anonymous) array. Calling toString on an array generates a fairly useless result such as [C@16f0472. Consider using Arrays.toString to convert the array into a readable String that gives the contents of the array. See Programming Puzzlers, chapter 3, puzzle 12.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Double.longBitsToDouble invoked on an int

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Long Bits To Double Invoked On Int

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The Double.longBitsToDouble method is invoked, but a 32 bit int value is passed as an argument. This almost certainly is not intended and is unlikely to give the intended result.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Switch statement found where default case is missing

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Switch No Default

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This method contains a switch statement where default case is missing. Usually you need to provide a default case.

Because the analysis only looks at the generated bytecode, this warning can be incorrect triggered if the default case is at the end of the switch statement and the switch statement doesnât contain break statements for other cases.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method might drop exception

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Might Drop

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method might drop an exception.Â  In general, exceptions should be handled or reported in some way, or they should be thrown out of the method.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method might ignore exception

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Might Ignore

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method might ignore an exception.Â  In general, exceptions should be handled or reported in some way, or they should be thrown out of the method.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Monitor wait() called on Condition

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Monitor Wait On Condition

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method calls wait() on a java.util.concurrent.locks.Condition object.Â  Waiting for a Condition should be done using one of the await() methods defined by the Condition interface.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Explicit garbage collection; extremely dubious except in benchmarking code

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Code explicitly invokes garbage collection. Except for specific use in benchmarking, this is very dubious.

In the past, situations where people have explicitly invoked the garbage collector in routines such as close or finalize methods has led to huge performance black holes. Garbage collection can be expensive. Any situation that forces hundreds or thousands of garbage collections will bring the machine to a crawl.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method invokes System.exit(...)

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Invoking System.exit shuts down the entire Java virtual machine. This should only been done when it is appropriate. Such calls make it hard or impossible for your code to be invoked by other code. Consider throwing a RuntimeException instead.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Non serializable object written to ObjectOutput

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Nonserializable Object Written

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code seems to be passing a non-serializable object to the ObjectOutput.writeObject method. If the object is, indeed, non-serializable, an error will result.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Thread passed where Runnable expected

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Thread Passed Where Runnable Expected

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A Thread object is passed as a parameter to a method where a Runnable is expected. This is rather unusual, and may indicate a logic error or cause unexpected behavior.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Use the nextInt method of Random rather than nextDouble to generate a random integer

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Nextint Via Nextdouble

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
If r is a java.util.Random, you can generate a random number from 0 to n-1 using r.nextInt(n), rather than using (int)(r.nextDouble() * n).

The argument to nextInt must be positive. If, for example, you want to generate a random value from -99 to 0, use -r.nextInt(100).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Overwritten increment

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Overwritten Increment

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The code performs an increment operation (e.g., i++) and then immediately overwrites it. For example, i = i++ immediately overwrites the incremented value with the original value.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Possible exposure of partially initialized object

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Partially Constructed

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Looks like this method uses lazy field initialization with double-checked locking. While the field is correctly declared as volatile, itâs possible that the internal structure of the object is changed after the field assignment, thus another thread may see the partially initialized object.

To fix this problem consider storing the object into the local variable first and save it to the volatile field only after itâs fully constructed.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method invokes dangerous method runFinalizersOnExit

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Run Finalizers On Exit

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Never call System.runFinalizersOnExit or Runtime.runFinalizersOnExit for any reason: they are among the most dangerous methods in the Java libraries. â Joshua Bloch

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Random object created and used only once

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Random Used Only Once

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This code creates a java.util.Random object, uses it to generate one random number, and then discards the Random object. This produces mediocre quality random numbers and is inefficient. If possible, rewrite the code so that the Random object is created once and saved, and each time a new random number is required invoke a method on the existing Random object to obtain it.

If it is important that the generated Random numbers not be guessable, you must not create a new Random for each random number; the values are too easily guessable. You should strongly consider using a java.security.SecureRandom instead (and avoid allocating a new SecureRandom for each random number needed).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method invokes inefficient new String(String) constructor

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: String Ctor

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Using the java.lang.String(String) constructor wastes memory because the object so constructed will be functionally indistinguishable from the String passed as a parameter.Â  Just use the argument String directly.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Synchronization on Boolean

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Synchronization On Boolean

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The code synchronizes on a boxed primitive constant, such as a Boolean.

private static Boolean inited = Boolean.FALSE;
...
synchronized(inited) {
    if (!inited) {
        init();
        inited = Boolean.TRUE;
    }
}
...

Since there normally exist only two Boolean objects, this code could be synchronizing on the same object as other, unrelated code, leading to unresponsiveness and possible deadlock.

See CERT CON08-J. Do not synchronize on objects that may be reused for more information.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Synchronization on boxed primitive

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Synchronization On Boxed Primitive

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The code synchronizes on a boxed primitive constant, such as an Integer.

private static Integer count = 0;
...
synchronized(count) {
    count++;
}
...

Since Integer objects can be cached and shared, this code could be synchronizing on the same object as other, unrelated code, leading to unresponsiveness and possible deadlock.

See CERT CON08-J. Do not synchronize on objects that may be reused for more information.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Synchronization on interned String

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Synchronization On Shared Constant

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The code synchronizes on interned String.

private static String LOCK = "LOCK";
...
synchronized(LOCK) {
    ...
}
...

Constant Strings are interned and shared across all other classes loaded by the JVM. Thus, this code is locking on something that other code might also be locking. This could result in very strange and hard to diagnose blocking and deadlock behavior. See http://www.javalobby.org/java/forums/t96352.html and http://jira.codehaus.org/browse/JETTY-352.

See CERT CON08-J. Do not synchronize on objects that may be reused for more information.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Synchronization on boxed primitive values

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Synchronization On Unshared Boxed Primitive

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The code synchronizes on an apparently unshared boxed primitive, such as an Integer.

private static final Integer fileLock = new Integer(1);
...
synchronized(fileLock) {
    .. do something ..
}
...

It would be much better, in this code, to redeclare fileLock as

private static final Object fileLock = new Object();

The existing code might be OK, but it is confusing and a future refactoring, such as the âRemove Boxingâ refactoring in IntelliJ, might replace this with the use of an interned Integer object shared throughout the JVM, leading to very confusing behavior and potential deadlock.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Creation of ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor with zero core threads

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Scheduled Thread Pool Executor With Zero Core Threads

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: (Javadoc) A ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor with zero core threads will never execute anything; changes to the max pool size are ignored.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method invokes inefficient new String() constructor

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: String Void Ctor

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Creating a new java.lang.String object using the no-argument constructor wastes memory because the object so created will be functionally indistinguishable from the empty string constant "".Â  Java guarantees that identical string constants will be represented by the same String object.Â  Therefore, you should just use the empty string constant directly.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Call to unsupported method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unsupported Method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: All targets of this method invocation throw an UnsupportedOperationException.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Don't use removeAll to clear a collection

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Using Removeall To Clear Collection

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: If you want to remove all elements from a collection c, use c.clear, not c.removeAll(c). Calling c.removeAll(c) to clear a collection is less clear, susceptible to errors from typos, less efficient and for some collections, might throw a ConcurrentModificationException.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Invocation of substring(0), which returns the original value

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Useless Substring

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code invokes substring(0) on a String, which returns the original value.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A thread was created using the default empty run method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Useless Thread

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method creates a thread without specifying a run method either by deriving from the Thread class, or by passing a Runnable object. This thread, then, does nothing but waste time.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Useless/vacuous call to EasyMock method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Vacuous Call To Easymock Method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This call doesnât pass any objects to the EasyMock method, so the call doesnât do anything.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Vacuous call to collections

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Vacuous Self Collection Call

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This call doesnât make sense. For any collection c, calling c.containsAll(c) should always be true, and c.retainAll(c) should have no effect.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: D'oh! A nonsensical method invocation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This partical method invocation doesnât make sense, for reasons that should be apparent from inspection.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: equals() used to compare array and nonarray

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Array And Nonarray

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method invokes the .equals(Object o) to compare an array and a reference that doesnât seem to be an array. If things being compared are of different types, they are guaranteed to be unequal and the comparison is almost certainly an error. Even if they are both arrays, the equals method on arrays only determines of the two arrays are the same object. To compare the contents of the arrays, use java.util.Arrays.equals(Object[], Object[]).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: equals method always returns false

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Always False

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This class defines an equals method that always returns false. This means that an object is not equal to itself, and it is impossible to create useful Maps or Sets of this class. More fundamentally, it means that equals is not reflexive, one of the requirements of the equals method.

The likely intended semantics are object identity: that an object is equal to itself. This is the behavior inherited from class Object. If you need to override an equals inherited from a different superclass, you can use:

public boolean equals(Object o) {
    return this == o;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Abstract class defines covariant equals() method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Abstract Self

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class defines a covariant version of equals().Â  To correctly override the equals() method in java.lang.Object, the parameter of equals() must have type java.lang.Object.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: equals method always returns true

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Always True

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class defines an equals method that always returns true. This is imaginative, but not very smart. Plus, it means that the equals method is not symmetric.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Invocation of equals() on an array, which is equivalent to ==

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bad Array Compare

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method invokes the .equals(Object o) method on an array. Since arrays do not override the equals method of Object, calling equals on an array is the same as comparing their addresses. To compare the contents of the arrays, use java.util.Arrays.equals(Object[], Object[]). To compare the addresses of the arrays, it would be less confusing to explicitly check pointer equality using ==.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: equals method compares class names rather than class objects

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Comparing Class Names

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method checks to see if two objects are the same class by checking to see if the names of their classes are equal. You can have different classes with the same name if they are loaded by different class loaders. Just check to see if the class objects are the same.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Equals checks for incompatible operand

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Check For Operand Not Compatible With This

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This equals method is checking to see if the argument is some incompatible type (i.e., a class that is neither a supertype nor subtype of the class that defines the equals method). For example, the Foo class might have an equals method that looks like:

public boolean equals(Object o) {
    if (o instanceof Foo)
        return name.equals(((Foo)o).name);
    else if (o instanceof String)
        return name.equals(o);
    else return false;
}

This is considered bad practice, as it makes it very hard to implement an equals method that is symmetric and transitive. Without those properties, very unexpected behaviors are possible.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Comparison of String parameter using == or !=

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Comparing Parameter String With Eq

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code compares a java.lang.String parameter for reference equality using the == or != operators. Requiring callers to pass only String constants or interned strings to a method is unnecessarily fragile, and rarely leads to measurable performance gains. Consider using the equals(Object) method instead.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Comparison of String objects using == or !=

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Comparing Strings With Eq

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code compares java.lang.String objects for reference equality using the == or != operators. Unless both strings are either constants in a source file, or have been interned using the String.intern() method, the same string value may be represented by two different String objects. Consider using the equals(Object) method instead.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class defines compareTo(...) and uses Object.equals()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Compareto Use Object Equals

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This class defines a compareTo(...) method but inherits its equals() method from java.lang.Object. Generally, the value of compareTo should return zero if and only if equals returns true. If this is violated, weird and unpredictable failures will occur in classes such as PriorityQueue. In Java 5 the PriorityQueue.remove method uses the compareTo method, while in Java 6 it uses the equals method.

From the JavaDoc for the compareTo method in the Comparable interface:

It is strongly recommended, but not strictly required that (x.compareTo(y)==0) == (x.equals(y)). Generally speaking, any class that implements the Comparable interface and violates this condition should clearly indicate this fact. The recommended language is âNote: this class has a natural ordering that is inconsistent with equals.â

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Covariant equals() method defined for enum

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dont Define Equals For Enum

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class defines an enumeration, and equality on enumerations are defined using object identity. Defining a covariant equals method for an enumeration value is exceptionally bad practice, since it would likely result in having two different enumeration values that compare as equals using the covariant enum method, and as not equal when compared normally. Donât do it.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class doesn't override equals in superclass

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Doesnt Override Equals

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class extends a class that defines an equals method and adds fields, but doesnât define an equals method itself. Thus, equality on instances of this class will ignore the identity of the subclass and the added fields. Be sure this is what is intended, and that you donât need to override the equals method. Even if you donât need to override the equals method, consider overriding it anyway to document the fact that the equals method for the subclass just return the result of invoking super.equals(o).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: May expose internal representation by returning reference to mutable object

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Expose Rep

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Returning a reference to a mutable object value stored in one of the object's fields exposes the internal representation of the object.Â If instances are accessed by untrusted code, and unchecked changes to the mutable object would compromise security or other important properties, you will need to do something different. Returning a new copy of the object is better approach in many situations.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: May expose internal static state by storing a mutable object into a static field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Expose Static Rep2

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code stores a reference to an externally mutable object into a static field. If unchecked changes to the mutable object would compromise security or other important properties, you will need to do something different. Storing a copy of the object is better approach in many situations.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Empty finalizer should be deleted

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Empty finalize() methods are useless, so they should be deleted.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: equals method fails for subtypes

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Getclass And Class Constant

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class has an equals method that will be broken if it is inherited by subclasses. It compares a class literal with the class of the argument (e.g., in class Foo it might check if Foo.class == o.getClass()). It is better to check if this.getClass() == o.getClass().

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: equals(...) used to compare incompatible arrays

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Incompatible Array Compare

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method invokes the .equals(Object o) to compare two arrays, but the arrays of of incompatible types (e.g., String[] and StringBuffer[], or String[] and int[]). They will never be equal. In addition, when equals(â¦) is used to compare arrays it only checks to see if they are the same array, and ignores the contents of the arrays.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Call to equals(null)

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Null Arg

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method calls equals(Object), passing a null value as the argument. According to the contract of the equals() method, this call should always return false.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: equals method overrides equals in superclass and may not be symmetric

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Overriding Equals Not Symmetric

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class defines an equals method that overrides an equals method in a superclass. Both equals methods use instanceof in the determination of whether two objects are equal. This is fraught with peril, since it is important that the equals method is symmetrical (in other words, a.equals(b) == b.equals(a)). If B is a subtype of A, and Aâs equals method checks that the argument is an instanceof A, and Bâs equals method checks that the argument is an instanceof B, it is quite likely that the equivalence relation defined by these methods is not symmetric.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: equals() method defined that doesn't override equals(Object)

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Other No Object

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class defines an equals() method, that doesnât override the normal equals(Object) method defined in the base java.lang.Object class.Â  Instead, it inherits an equals(Object) method from a superclass. The class should probably define a boolean equals(Object) method.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: equals() method defined that doesn't override Object.equals(Object)

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Other Use Object

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class defines an equals() method, that doesnât override the normal equals(Object) method defined in the base java.lang.Object class.Â  The class should probably define a boolean equals(Object) method.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Empty synchronized block

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Sync

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The code contains an empty synchronized block:

synchronized() {
}

Empty synchronized blocks are far more subtle and hard to use correctly than most people recognize, and empty synchronized blocks are almost never a better solution than less contrived solutions.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Covariant equals() method defined

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Self No Object

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class defines a covariant version of equals().Â  To correctly override the equals() method in java.lang.Object, the parameter of equals() must have type java.lang.Object.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Covariant equals() method defined, Object.equals(Object) inherited

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Self Use Object

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class defines a covariant version of the equals() method, but inherits the normal equals(Object) method defined in the base java.lang.Object class.Â  The class should probably define a boolean equals(Object) method.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Unusual equals method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class doesnât do any of the patterns we recognize for checking that the type of the argument is compatible with the type of the this object. There might not be anything wrong with this code, but it is worth reviewing.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Call to equals() comparing unrelated class and interface

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unrelated Class And Interface

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method calls equals(Object) on two references, one of which is a class and the other an interface, where neither the class nor any of its non-abstract subclasses implement the interface. Therefore, the objects being compared are unlikely to be members of the same class at runtime (unless some application classes were not analyzed, or dynamic class loading can occur at runtime). According to the contract of equals(), objects of different classes should always compare as unequal; therefore, according to the contract defined by java.lang.Object.equals(Object), the result of this comparison will always be false at runtime.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Call to equals() comparing different interface types

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unrelated Interfaces

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method calls equals(Object) on two references of unrelated interface types, where neither is a subtype of the other, and there are no known non-abstract classes which implement both interfaces.
