Therefore, the objects being compared are unlikely to be members of the same class at runtime (unless some application classes were not analyzed, or dynamic class loading can occur at runtime). According to the contract of equals(), objects of different classes should always compare as unequal; therefore, according to the contract defined by java.lang.Object.equals(Object), the result of this comparison will always be false at runtime.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Call to equals() comparing different types

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unrelated Types

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method calls equals(Object) on two references of different class types and analysis suggests they will be to objects of different classes at runtime. Further, examination of the equals methods that would be invoked suggest that either this call will always return false, or else the equals method is not be symmetric (which is a property required by the contract for equals in class Object).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Using pointer equality to compare different types

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unrelated Types Using Pointer Equality

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method uses pointer equality to compare two references that seem to be of different types. The result of this comparison will always be false at runtime.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: May expose internal representation by incorporating reference to mutable object

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Expose Rep2

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code stores a reference to an externally mutable object into the internal representation of the object.Â  If instances are accessed by untrusted code, and unchecked changes to the mutable object would compromise security or other important properties, you will need to do something different. Storing a copy of the object is better approach in many situations.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Finalizer does not call superclass finalizer

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Missing Super Call

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This finalize() method does not make a call to its superclassâs finalize() method.Â  So, any finalizer actions defined for the superclass will not be performed.Â  Add a call to super.finalize().

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Finalizer nulls fields

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Finalizer Nulls Fields

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This finalizer nulls out fields. This is usually an error, as it does not aid garbage collection, and the object is going to be garbage collected anyway.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Finalizer only nulls fields

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Finalizer Only Nulls Fields

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This finalizer does nothing except null out fields. This is completely pointless, and requires that the object be garbage collected, finalized, and then garbage collected again. You should just remove the finalize method.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Test for floating point equality

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Floating Point Equality

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This operation compares two floating point values for equality. Because floating point calculations may involve rounding, calculated float and double values may not be accurate. For values that must be precise, such as monetary values, consider using a fixed-precision type such as BigDecimal. For values that need not be precise, consider comparing for equality within some range, for example: if ( Math.abs(x - y) < .0000001 ). See the Java Language Specification, section 4.2.4.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Missing expected or desired warning from SpotBugs

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Missing Expected Warning

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: SpotBugs didnât generate generated a warning that, according to a @ExpectedWarning annotated, is expected or desired.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method performs math using floating point precision

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Math Using Float Precision

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The method performs math operations using floating point precision. Floating point precision is very imprecise. For example, 16777216.0f + 1.0f = 16777216.0f. Consider using double math instead.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Finalizer nullifies superclass finalizer

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Nullify Super

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This empty finalize() method explicitly negates the effect of any finalizer defined by its superclass.Â  Any finalizer actions defined for the superclass will not be performed.Â  Unless this is intended, delete this method.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Finalizer should be protected, not public

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Public Should Be Protected

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A classâs finalize() method should have protected access, not public.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Finalizer does nothing but call superclass finalizer

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The only thing this finalize() method does is call the superclassâs finalize() method, making it redundant.Â  Delete it.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Unexpected/undesired warning from SpotBugs

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unexpected Warning

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: SpotBugs generated a warning that, according to a @NoWarning annotated, is unexpected or undesired.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: No relationship between generic parameter and method argument

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unrelated Types

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This call to a generic collection method contains an argument with an incompatible class from that of the collectionâs parameter (i.e., the type of the argument is neither a supertype nor a subtype of the corresponding generic type argument). Therefore, it is unlikely that the collection contains any objects that are equal to the method argument used here. Most likely, the wrong value is being passed to the method.

In general, instances of two unrelated classes are not equal. For example, if the Foo and Bar classes are not related by subtyping, then an instance of Foo should not be equal to an instance of Bar. Among other issues, doing so will likely result in an equals method that is not symmetrical. For example, if you define the Foo class so that a Foo can be equal to a String, your equals method isnât symmetrical since a String can only be equal to a String.

In rare cases, people do define nonsymmetrical equals methods and still manage to make their code work. Although none of the APIs document or guarantee it, it is typically the case that if you check if a Collection<String> contains a Foo, the equals method of argument (e.g., the equals method of the Foo class) used to perform the equality checks.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Unchecked type in generic call

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unchecked Type In Generic Call

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This call to a generic collection method passes an argument while compile type Object where a specific type from the generic type parameters is expected. Thus, neither the standard Java type system nor static analysis can provide useful information on whether the object being passed as a parameter is of an appropriate type.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class defines equals() but not hashCode()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Equals No Hashcode

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class overrides equals(Object), but does not override hashCode().Â  Therefore, the class may violate the invariant that equal objects must have equal hashcodes.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class defines equals() and uses Object.hashCode()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Equals Use Hashcode

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This class overrides equals(Object), but does not override hashCode(), and inherits the implementation of hashCode() from java.lang.Object (which returns the identity hash code, an arbitrary value assigned to the object by the VM).Â  Therefore, the class is very likely to violate the invariant that equal objects must have equal hashcodes.

If you donât think instances of this class will ever be inserted into a HashMap/HashTable, the recommended hashCode implementation to use is:

public int hashCode() {
    assert false : "hashCode not designed";
    return 42; // any arbitrary constant will do
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class defines hashCode() but not equals()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Hashcode No Equals

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class defines a hashCode() method but not an equals() method.Â  Therefore, the class may violate the invariant that equal objects must have equal hashcodes.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Huge string constants is duplicated across multiple class files

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Huge Shared String Constant

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A large String constant is duplicated across multiple class files. This is likely because a final field is initialized to a String constant, and the Java language mandates that all references to a final field from other classes be inlined into that classfile. See JDK bug 6447475 for a description of an occurrence of this bug in the JDK and how resolving it reduced the size of the JDK by 1 megabyte.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class defines hashCode() and uses Object.equals()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Hashcode Use Object Equals

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This class defines a hashCode() method but inherits its equals() method from java.lang.Object (which defines equality by comparing object references).Â  Although this will probably satisfy the contract that equal objects must have equal hashcodes, it is probably not what was intended by overriding the hashCode() method.Â  (Overriding hashCode() implies that the objectâs identity is based on criteria more complicated than simple reference equality.)

If you donât think instances of this class will ever be inserted into a HashMap/HashTable, the recommended hashCode implementation to use is:

public int hashCode() {
    assert false : "hashCode not designed";
    return 42; // any arbitrary constant will do
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class inherits equals() and uses Object.hashCode()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Inherits Equals Use Hashcode

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This class inherits equals(Object) from an abstract superclass, and hashCode() from java.lang.Object (which returns the identity hash code, an arbitrary value assigned to the object by the VM).Â  Therefore, the class is very likely to violate the invariant that equal objects must have equal hashcodes.

If you donât want to define a hashCode method, and/or donât believe the object will ever be put into a HashMap/Hashtable, define the hashCode() method to throw UnsupportedOperationException.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: HTTP cookie formed from untrusted input

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Request Parameter To Cookie

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This code constructs an HTTP Cookie using an untrusted HTTP parameter. If this cookie is added to an HTTP response, it will allow a HTTP response splitting vulnerability. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_response_splitting for more information.

SpotBugs looks only for the most blatant, obvious cases of HTTP response splitting. If SpotBugs found any, you almost certainly have more vulnerabilities that SpotBugs doesnât report. If you are concerned about HTTP response splitting, you should seriously consider using a commercial static analysis or pen-testing tool.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: HTTP Response splitting vulnerability

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Request Parameter To Http Header

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This code directly writes an HTTP parameter to an HTTP header, which allows for a HTTP response splitting vulnerability. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HTTP_response_splitting for more information.

SpotBugs looks only for the most blatant, obvious cases of HTTP response splitting. If SpotBugs found any, you almost certainly have more vulnerabilities that SpotBugs doesnât report. If you are concerned about HTTP response splitting, you should seriously consider using a commercial static analysis or pen-testing tool.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Signature declares use of unhashable class in hashed construct

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Signature Declares Hashing Of Unhashable Class

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A method, field or class declares a generic signature where a non-hashable class is used in context where a hashable class is required. A class that declares an equals method but inherits a hashCode() method from Object is unhashable, since it doesnât fulfill the requirement that equal objects have equal hashCodes.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Use of class without a hashCode() method in a hashed data structure

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Of Unhashable Class

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A class defines an equals(Object) method but not a hashCode() method, and thus doesnât fulfill the requirement that equal objects have equal hashCodes. An instance of this class is used in a hash data structure, making the need to fix this problem of highest importance.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Computation of average could overflow

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Average Computation Could Overflow

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The code computes the average of two integers using either division or signed right shift, and then uses the result as the index of an array. If the values being averaged are very large, this can overflow (resulting in the computation of a negative average). Assuming that the result is intended to be nonnegative, you can use an unsigned right shift instead. In other words, rather that using (low+high)/2, use (low+high) >>> 1

This bug exists in many earlier implementations of binary search and merge sort. Martin Buchholz found and fixed it in the JDK libraries, and Joshua Bloch widely publicized the bug pattern.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Potentially ambiguous invocation of either an inherited or outer method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Ambiguous Invocation Of Inherited Or Outer Method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
An inner class is invoking a method that could be resolved to either a inherited method or a method defined in an outer class. For example, you invoke foo(17), which is defined in both a superclass and in an outer method. By the Java semantics, it will be resolved to invoke the inherited method, but this may not be what you intend.

If you really intend to invoke the inherited method, invoke it by invoking the method on super (e.g., invoke super.foo(17)), and thus it will be clear to other readers of your code and to SpotBugs that you want to invoke the inherited method, not the method in the outer class.

If you call this.foo(17), then the inherited method will be invoked. However, since SpotBugs only looks at classfiles, it canât tell the difference between an invocation of this.foo(17) and foo(17), it will still complain about a potential ambiguous invocation.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: JUnit assertion in run method will not be noticed by JUnit

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Assert Method Invoked From Run Method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A JUnit assertion is performed in a run method. Failed JUnit assertions just result in exceptions being thrown. Thus, if this exception occurs in a thread other than the thread that invokes the test method, the exception will terminate the thread but not result in the test failing.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Doomed attempt to append to an object output stream

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Appending To Object Output Stream

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This code opens a file in append mode and then wraps the result in an object output stream. This wonât allow you to append to an existing object output stream stored in a file. If you want to be able to append to an object output stream, you need to keep the object output stream open.

The only situation in which opening a file in append mode and the writing an object output stream could work is if on reading the file you plan to open it in random access mode and seek to the byte offset where the append started.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Check for oddness that won't work for negative numbers

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bad Check For Odd

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The code uses x % 2 == 1 to check to see if a value is odd, but this wonât work for negative numbers (e.g., (-5) % 2 == -1). If this code is intending to check for oddness, consider using x & 1 == 1, or x % 2 != 0.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Bad comparison of int value with long constant

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bad Comparison With Int Value

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code compares an int value with a long constant that is outside the range of values that can be represented as an int value. This comparison is vacuous and possibly incorrect.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Bad comparison of nonnegative value with negative constant or zero

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bad Comparison With Nonnegative Value

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code compares a value that is guaranteed to be non-negative with a negative constant or zero.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Bad comparison of signed byte

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bad Comparison With Signed Byte

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Signed bytes can only have a value in the range -128 to 127. Comparing a signed byte with a value outside that range is vacuous and likely to be incorrect. To convert a signed byte b to an unsigned value in the range 0..255, use 0xff & b.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Integer remainder modulo 1

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bad Rem By 1

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Any expression (exp % 1) is guaranteed to always return zero. Did you mean (exp & 1) or (exp % 2) instead?

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: 32 bit int shifted by an amount not in the range -31..31

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bad Shift Amount

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The code performs shift of a 32 bit int by a constant amount outside the range -31..31. The effect of this is to use the lower 5 bits of the integer value to decide how much to shift by (e.g., shifting by 40 bits is the same as shifting by 8 bits, and shifting by 32 bits is the same as shifting by zero bits). This probably isnât what was expected, and it is at least confusing.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: TestCase declares a bad suite method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bad Suite Method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Class is a JUnit TestCase and defines a suite() method. However, the suite method needs to be declared as either

public static junit.framework.Test suite()

or

public static junit.framework.TestSuite suite()

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A collection is added to itself

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Container Added To Itself

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A collection is added to itself. As a result, computing the hashCode of this set will throw a StackOverflowException.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Dubious catching of IllegalMonitorStateException

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dont Catch Imse

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: IllegalMonitorStateException is generally only thrown in case of a design flaw in your code (calling wait or notify on an object you do not hold a lock on).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: NodeList.getLength() called in a loop

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Elements Get Length In Loop

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The method calls NodeList.getLength() inside the loop and NodeList was produced by getElementsByTagName call. This NodeList doesn't store its length, but computes it every time in not very optimal way. Consider storing the length to the variable before the loop.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Field not guarded against concurrent access

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Field Not Guarded

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This field is annotated with net.jcip.annotations.GuardedBy or javax.annotation.concurrent.GuardedBy, but can be accessed in a way that seems to violate those annotations.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: int value converted to long and used as absolute time

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Int 2 Long As Instant

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This code converts a 32-bit int value to a 64-bit long value, and then passes that value for a method parameter that requires an absolute time value. An absolute time value is the number of milliseconds since the standard base time known as âthe epochâ, namely January 1, 1970, 00:00:00 GMT. For example, the following method, intended to convert seconds since the epoch into a Date, is badly broken:

Date getDate(int seconds) { return new Date(seconds * 1000); }

The multiplication is done using 32-bit arithmetic, and then converted to a 64-bit value. When a 32-bit value is converted to 64-bits and used to express an absolute time value, only dates in December 1969 and January 1970 can be represented.

Correct implementations for the above method are:

// Fails for dates after 2037
Date getDate(int seconds) { return new Date(seconds * 1000L); }

// better, works for all dates
Date getDate(long seconds) { return new Date(seconds * 1000); }

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Initialization circularity

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Init Circularity

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A circularity was detected in the static initializers of the two classes referenced by the bug instance.Â  Many kinds of unexpected behavior may arise from such circularity.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Integral division result cast to double or float

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Idiv Cast To Double

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This code casts the result of an integral division (e.g., int or long division) operation to double or float. Doing division on integers truncates the result to the integer value closest to zero. The fact that the result was cast to double suggests that this precision should have been retained. What was probably meant was to cast one or both of the operands to double before performing the division. Here is an example:

int x = 2;
int y = 5;
// Wrong: yields result 0.0
double value1 = x / y;

// Right: yields result 0.4
double value2 = x / (double) y;

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Integral value cast to double and then passed to Math.ceil

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Int Cast To Double Passed To Ceil

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code converts an integral value (e.g., int or long) to a double precision floating point number and then passing the result to the Math.ceil() function, which rounds a double to the next higher integer value. This operation should always be a no-op, since the converting an integer to a double should give a number with no fractional part. It is likely that the operation that generated the value to be passed to Math.ceil was intended to be performed using double precision floating point arithmetic.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: int value cast to float and then passed to Math.round

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Int Cast To Float Passed To Round

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code converts an int value to a float precision floating point number and then passing the result to the Math.round() function, which returns the int/long closest to the argument. This operation should always be a no-op, since the converting an integer to a float should give a number with no fractional part. It is likely that the operation that generated the value to be passed to Math.round was intended to be performed using floating point arithmetic.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Inefficient use of String.indexOf(String)

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Inefficient Index Of

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code passes a constant string of length 1 to String.indexOf(). It is more efficient to use the integer implementations of String.indexOf(). f. e. call `myString.indexOf('.')` instead of `myString.indexOf(".")`

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An apparent infinite loop

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Infinite Loop

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This loop doesnât seem to have a way to terminate (other than by perhaps throwing an exception).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Inefficient use of String.lastIndexOf(String)

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Inefficient Last Index Of

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code passes a constant string of length 1 to String.lastIndexOf(). It is more efficient to use the integer implementations of String.lastIndexOf(). f. e. call `myString.lastIndexOf('.')` instead of `myString.lastIndexOf(".")`

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method accesses a private member variable of owning class

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Inefficient Member Access

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method of an inner class reads from or writes to a private member variable of the owning class, or calls a private method of the owning class. The compiler must generate a special method to access this private member, causing this to be less efficient. Relaxing the protection of the member variable or method will allow the compiler to treat this as a normal access.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Result of integer multiplication cast to long

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Integer Multiply Cast To Long

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This code performs integer multiply and then converts the result to a long, as in:

long convertDaysToMilliseconds(int days) { return 1000*3600*24*days; }

If the multiplication is done using long arithmetic, you can avoid the possibility that the result will overflow. For example, you could fix the above code to:

long convertDaysToMilliseconds(int days) { return 1000L*3600*24*days; }

or

static final long MILLISECONDS_PER_DAY = 24L*3600*1000;
long convertDaysToMilliseconds(int days) { return days * MILLISECONDS_PER_DAY; }

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An apparent infinite recursive loop

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Infinite Recursive Loop

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method unconditionally invokes itself. This would seem to indicate an infinite recursive loop that will result in a stack overflow.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Inconsistent synchronization

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Inconsistent Sync

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The fields of this class appear to be accessed inconsistently with respect to synchronization.Â  This bug report indicates that the bug pattern detector judged that

  • The class contains a mix of locked and unlocked accesses,
  • The class is not annotated as javax.annotation.concurrent.NotThreadSafe,
  • At least one locked access was performed by one of the classâs own methods, and
  • The number of unsynchronized field accesses (reads and writes) was no more than one third of all accesses, with writes being weighed twice as high as reads

A typical bug matching this bug pattern is forgetting to synchronize one of the methods in a class that is intended to be thread-safe.

You can select the nodes labeled âUnsynchronized accessâ to show the code locations where the detector believed that a field was accessed without synchronization.

Note that there are various sources of inaccuracy in this detector; for example, the detector cannot statically detect all situations in which a lock is held.Â  Also, even when the detector is accurate in distinguishing locked vs.Â unlocked accesses, the code in question may still be correct.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Needless instantiation of class that only supplies static methods

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Instantiate Static Class

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class allocates an object that is based on a class that only supplies static methods. This object does not need to be created, just access the static methods directly using the class name as a qualifier.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Integer multiply of result of integer remainder

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Multiplying Result Of Irem

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The code multiplies the result of an integer remaining by an integer constant. Be sure you donât have your operator precedence confused. For example i % 60 * 1000 is (i % 60) * 1000, not i % (60 * 1000).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Iterator next() method can't throw NoSuchElementException

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: No Such Element

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class implements the java.util.Iterator interface.Â  However, its next() method is not capable of throwing java.util.NoSuchElementException.Â  The next() method should be changed so it throws NoSuchElementException if is called when there are no more elements to return.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: TestCase has no tests

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: No Tests

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Class is a JUnit TestCase but has not implemented any test methods.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method calls Pattern.compile in a loop

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Pattern Compile In Loop

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The method calls Pattern.compile inside the loop passing the constant arguments. If the Pattern should be used several times there's no reason to compile it for each loop iteration. Move this call outside of the loop or even into static final field.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method compiles the regular expression in a loop

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Pattern Compile In Loop Indirect

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The method creates the same regular expression inside the loop, so it will be compiled every iteration. It would be more optimal to precompile this regular expression using Pattern.compile outside of the loop.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A parameter is dead upon entry to a method but overwritten

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Parameter Is Dead But Overwritten

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The initial value of this parameter is ignored, and the parameter is overwritten here. This often indicates a mistaken belief that the write to the parameter will be conveyed back to the caller.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method calls prepareStatement in a loop

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Prepare Statement In Loop

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The method calls Connection.prepareStatement inside the loop passing the constant arguments. If the PreparedStatement should be executed several times there's no reason to recreate it for each loop iteration. Move this call outside of the loop.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Unsigned right shift cast to short/byte

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Questionable Unsigned Right Shift

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The code performs an unsigned right shift, whose result is then cast to a short or byte, which discards the upper bits of the result. Since the upper bits are discarded, there may be no difference between a signed and unsigned right shift (depending upon the size of the shift).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: TestCase defines setUp that doesn't call super.setUp()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Setup No Super

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Class is a JUnit TestCase and implements the setUp method. The setUp method should call super.setUp(), but doesnât.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Superclass uses subclass during initialization

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Superclass Uses Subclass During Initialization

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
During the initialization of a class, the class makes an active use of a subclass. That subclass will not yet be initialized at the time of this use. For example, in the following code, foo will be null.

public class CircularClassInitialization {
    static class InnerClassSingleton extends CircularClassInitialization {
        static InnerClassSingleton singleton = new InnerClassSingleton();
    }

    static CircularClassInitialization foo = InnerClassSingleton.singleton;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method allocates an object, only to get the class object

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: New For Getclass

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method allocates an object just to call getClass() on it, in order to retrieve the Class object for it. It is simpler to just access the .class property of the class.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: TestCase defines tearDown that doesn't call super.tearDown()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Teardown No Super

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Class is a JUnit TestCase and implements the tearDown method. The tearDown method should call super.tearDown(), but doesnât.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Vacuous bit mask operation on integer value

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Vacuous Bit Operation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This is an integer bit operation (and, or, or exclusive or) that doesnât do any useful work (e.g., v & 0xffffffff).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Vacuous comparison of integer value

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Vacuous Comparison

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: There is an integer comparison that always returns the same value (e.g., x <= Integer.MAX_VALUE).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Asserting value of instanceof in tests is not recommended.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dont Assert Instanceof In Tests

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Asserting type checks in tests is not recommended as a class cast exception message could better indicate the cause of an instance of the wrong class being used than an instanceof assertion.
When debugging tests that fail due to bad casts, it may be more useful to observe the output of the resulting ClassCastException which could provide information about the actual encountered type. Asserting the type before casting would instead result in a less informative `"false is not true"` message.
If JUnit is used with hamcrest, the [`IsInstanceOf`](https://junit.org/junit4/javadoc/latest/index.html?org/hamcrest/core/IsInstanceOf.html) class from hamcrest could be used instead.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Fields of immutable classes should be final

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Field Isnt Final In Immutable Class

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The class is annotated with net.jcip.annotations.Immutable or javax.annotation.concurrent.Immutable, and the rules for those annotations require that all fields are final. .

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Using monitor style wait methods on util.concurrent abstraction

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Jsr166 Calling Wait Rather Than Await

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method calls wait(), notify() or notifyAll()() on an object that also provides an await(), signal(), signalAll() method (such as util.concurrent Condition objects). This probably isnât what you want, and even if you do want it, you should consider changing your design, as other developers will find it exceptionally confusing.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Synchronization performed on Lock

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Jsr166 Lock Monitorenter

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method performs synchronization on an object that implements java.util.concurrent.locks.Lock. Such an object is locked/unlocked using acquire()/release() rather than using the synchronized (...) construct.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Synchronization performed on util.concurrent instance

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Jsr166 Utilconcurrent Monitorenter

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This method performs synchronization on an object that is an instance of a class from the java.util.concurrent package (or its subclasses). Instances of these classes have their own concurrency control mechanisms that are orthogonal to the synchronization provided by the Java keyword synchronized. For example, synchronizing on an AtomicBoolean will not prevent other threads from modifying the AtomicBoolean.

Such code may be correct, but should be carefully reviewed and documented, and may confuse people who have to maintain the code at a later date.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Store of non serializable object into HttpSession

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Store Of Non Serializable Object Into Session

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code seems to be storing a non-serializable object into an HttpSession. If this session is passivated or migrated, an error will result.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: TestCase implements a non-static suite method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Suite Not Static

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Class is a JUnit TestCase and implements the suite() method. The suite method should be declared as being static, but isnât.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Incorrect lazy initialization of static field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Lazy Init Static

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method contains an unsynchronized lazy initialization of a non-volatile static field. Because the compiler or processor may reorder instructions, threads are not guaranteed to see a completely initialized object, if the method can be called by multiple threads. You can make the field volatile to correct the problem. For more information, see the Java Memory Model web site.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Incorrect lazy initialization and update of static field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Lazy Init Update Static

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This method contains an unsynchronized lazy initialization of a static field. After the field is set, the object stored into that location is further updated or accessed. The setting of the field is visible to other threads as soon as it is set. If the further accesses in the method that set the field serve to initialize the object, then you have a very serious multithreading bug, unless something else prevents any other thread from accessing the stored object until it is fully initialized.

Even if you feel confident that the method is never called by multiple threads, it might be better to not set the static field until the value you are setting it to is fully populated/initialized.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Potential lost logger changes due to weak reference in OpenJDK

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Lost Logger Due To Weak Reference

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
OpenJDK introduces a potential incompatibility. In particular, the java.util.logging.Logger behavior has changed. Instead of using strong references, it now uses weak references internally. That's a reasonable change, but unfortunately some code relies on the old behavior - when changing logger configuration, it simply drops the logger reference. That means that the garbage collector is free to reclaim that memory, which means that the logger configuration is lost. For example, consider:
``` {.java} public static void initLogging() throws Exception { Logger logger = Logger.getLogger("edu.umd.cs"); logger.addHandler(new FileHandler()); // call to change logger configuration logger.setUseParentHandlers(false); // another call to change logger configuration } ```
The logger reference is lost at the end of the method (it doesn't escape the method), so if you have a garbage collection cycle just after the call to initLogging, the logger configuration is lost (because Logger only keeps weak references).
``` {.java} public static void main(String[] args) throws Exception { initLogging(); // adds a file handler to the logger System.gc(); // logger configuration lost Logger.getLogger("edu.umd.cs").info("Some message"); // this isn't logged to the file as expected } ```
*Ulf Ochsenfahrt and Eric Fellheimer*

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Switch statement found where one case falls through to the next case

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Switch Fallthrough

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method contains a switch statement where one case branch will fall through to the next case. Usually you need to end this case with a break or return.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Field isn't final and can't be protected from malicious code

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Cannot Be Final

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A mutable static field could be changed by malicious code or by accident from another package. Unfortunately, the way the field is used doesnât allow any easy fix to this problem.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class defines field that masks a superclass field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Class Masks Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class defines a field with the same name as a visible instance field in a superclass. This is confusing, and may indicate an error if methods update or access one of the fields when they wanted the other.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Public enum method unconditionally sets its field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Enum Field Setter

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This public method declared in public enum unconditionally sets enum field, thus this field can be changed by malicious code or by accident from another package. Though mutable enum fields may be used for lazy initialization, itâs a bad practice to expose them to the outer world. Consider removing this method or declaring it package-private.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Field should be both final and package protected

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Final Pkgprotect

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A mutable static field could be changed by malicious code or by accident from another package. The field could be made package protected and/or made final to avoid this vulnerability.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Field is a mutable array

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Mutable Array

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A final static field references an array and can be accessed by malicious code or by accident from another package. This code can freely modify the contents of the array.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Field is a mutable collection

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Mutable Collection

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A mutable collection instance is assigned to a final static field, thus can be changed by malicious code or by accident from another package. Consider wrapping this field into Collections.unmodifiableSet/List/Map/etc. to avoid this vulnerability.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Field is a mutable collection which should be package protected

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Mutable Collection Pkgprotect

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A mutable collection instance is assigned to a final static field, thus can be changed by malicious code or by accident from another package. The field could be made package protected to avoid this vulnerability. Alternatively you may wrap this field into Collections.unmodifiableSet/List/Map/etc. to avoid this vulnerability.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Enum field is public and mutable

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Mutable Enum Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A mutable public field is defined inside a public enum, thus can be changed by malicious code or by accident from another package. Though mutable enum fields may be used for lazy initialization, itâs a bad practice to expose them to the outer world. Consider declaring this field final and/or package-private.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Field is a mutable Hashtable

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Mutable Hashtable

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A final static field references a Hashtable and can be accessed by malicious code or by accident from another package. This code can freely modify the contents of the Hashtable.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method defines a variable that obscures a field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Method Masks Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method defines a local variable with the same name as a field in this class or a superclass. This may cause the method to read an uninitialized value from the field, leave the field uninitialized, or both.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Mismatched notify()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Mismatched Notify

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method calls Object.notify() or Object.notifyAll() without obviously holding a lock on the object.Â  Calling notify() or notifyAll() without a lock held will result in an IllegalMonitorStateException being thrown.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Mutable servlet field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Mutable Servlet Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A web server generally only creates one instance of servlet or JSP class (i.e., treats the class as a Singleton), and will have multiple threads invoke methods on that instance to service multiple simultaneous requests. Thus, having a mutable instance field generally creates race conditions.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Mismatched wait()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Mismatched Wait

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method calls Object.wait() without obviously holding a lock on the object.Â  Calling wait() without a lock held will result in an IllegalMonitorStateException being thrown.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Field should be moved out of an interface and made package protected

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Ooi Pkgprotect

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A final static field that is defined in an interface references a mutable object such as an array or hashtable. This mutable object could be changed by malicious code or by accident from another package. To solve this, the field needs to be moved to a class and made package protected to avoid this vulnerability.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Field should be package protected

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A mutable static field could be changed by malicious code or by accident. The field could be made package protected to avoid this vulnerability.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Public static method may expose internal representation by returning array

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Expose Rep

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A public static method returns a reference to an array that is part of the static state of the class. Any code that calls this method can freely modify the underlying array. One fix is to return a copy of the array.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Field isn't final but should be

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Should Be Final

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This static field public but not final, and could be changed by malicious code or by accident from another package. The field could be made final to avoid this vulnerability.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Field isn't final but should be refactored to be so

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Should Be Refactored To Be Final

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This static field public but not final, and could be changed by malicious code or by accident from another package. The field could be made final to avoid this vulnerability. However, the static initializer contains more than one write to the field, so doing so will require some refactoring.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Synchronization on field in futile attempt to guard that field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Sync On Field To Guard Changing That Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This method synchronizes on a field in what appears to be an attempt to guard against simultaneous updates to that field. But guarding a field gets a lock on the referenced object, not on the field. This may not provide the mutual exclusion you need, and other threads might be obtaining locks on the referenced objects (for other purposes). An example of this pattern would be:

private Long myNtfSeqNbrCounter = new Long(0);
private Long getNotificationSequenceNumber() {
     Long result = null;
     synchronized(myNtfSeqNbrCounter) {
         result = new Long(myNtfSeqNbrCounter.longValue() + 1);
         myNtfSeqNbrCounter = new Long(result.longValue());
     }
     return result;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method synchronizes on an updated field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Sync On Updated Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method synchronizes on an object referenced from a mutable field. This is unlikely to have useful semantics, since different threads may be synchronizing on different objects.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class extends Servlet class and uses instance variables

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Suspect Servlet Instance Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class extends from a Servlet class, and uses an instance member variable. Since only one instance of a Servlet class is created by the J2EE framework, and used in a multithreaded way, this paradigm is highly discouraged and most likely problematic. Consider only using method local variables.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class is Serializable, but doesn't define serialVersionUID

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: No Serialversionid

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class implements the Serializable interface, but does not define a serialVersionUID field.Â  A change as simple as adding a reference to a .class object will add synthetic fields to the class, which will unfortunately change the implicit serialVersionUID (e.g., adding a reference to String.class will generate a static field class$java$lang$String). Also, different source code to bytecode compilers may use different naming conventions for synthetic variables generated for references to class objects or inner classes. To ensure interoperability of Serializable across versions, consider adding an explicit serialVersionUID.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Apparent method/constructor confusion

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Method Constructor Confusion

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This regular method has the same name as the class it is defined in. It is likely that this was intended to be a constructor. If it was intended to be a constructor, remove the declaration of a void return value. If you had accidentally defined this method, realized the mistake, defined a proper constructor but canât get rid of this method due to backwards compatibility, deprecate the method.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method names should start with a lower case letter

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Method Naming Convention

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Methods should be verbs, in mixed case with the first letter lowercase, with the first letter of each internal word capitalized.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class extends Struts Action class and uses instance variables

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Suspect Struts Instance Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class extends from a Struts Action class, and uses an instance member variable. Since only one instance of a struts Action class is created by the Struts framework, and used in a multithreaded way, this paradigm is highly discouraged and most likely problematic. Consider only using method local variables. Only instance fields that are written outside of a monitor are reported.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method does not check for null argument

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Argument Might Be Null

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A parameter to this method has been identified as a value that should always be checked to see whether or not it is null, but it is being dereferenced without a preceding null check.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Null pointer dereference

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Always Null

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A null pointer is dereferenced here.Â  This will lead to a NullPointerException when the code is executed.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Null pointer dereference in method on exception path

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Always Null Exception

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A pointer which is null on an exception path is dereferenced here.Â  This will lead to a NullPointerException when the code is executed.Â  Note that because SpotBugs currently does not prune infeasible exception paths, this may be a false warning.

Also note that SpotBugs considers the default case of a switch statement to be an exception path, since the default case is often infeasible.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class defines equal(Object); should it be equals(Object)?

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bad Equal

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class defines a method equal(Object).Â  This method does not override the equals(Object) method in java.lang.Object, which is probably what was intended.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method with Boolean return type returns explicit null

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Boolean Return Null

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A method that returns either Boolean.TRUE, Boolean.FALSE or null is an accident waiting to happen. This method can be invoked as though it returned a value of type boolean, and the compiler will insert automatic unboxing of the Boolean value. If a null value is returned, this will result in a NullPointerException.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Confusing method names

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The referenced methods have names that differ only by capitalization.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: close() invoked on a value that is always null

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Closing Null

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: close() is being invoked on a value that is always null. If this statement is executed, a null pointer exception will occur. But the big risk here you never close something that should be closed.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class is not derived from an Exception, even though it is named as such

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Class Not Exception

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class is not derived from another exception, but ends with âExceptionâ. This will be confusing to users of this class.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Potentially dangerous use of non-short-circuit logic

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dangerous Non Short Circuit

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This code seems to be using non-short-circuit logic (e.g., & or |) rather than short-circuit logic (&& or ||). In addition, it seem possible that, depending on the value of the left hand side, you might not want to evaluate the right hand side (because it would have side effects, could cause an exception or could be expensive.

Non-short-circuit logic causes both sides of the expression to be evaluated even when the result can be inferred from knowing the left-hand side. This can be less efficient and can result in errors if the left-hand side guards cases when evaluating the right-hand side can generate an error.

See the Java Language Specification for details.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Dereference of the result of readLine() without nullcheck

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dereference Of Readline Value

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The result of invoking readLine() is dereferenced without checking to see if the result is null. If there are no more lines of text to read, readLine() will return null and dereferencing that will generate a null pointer exception.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Use of identifier that is a keyword in later versions of Java

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Future Keyword Used As Identifier

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The identifier is a word that is reserved as a keyword in later versions of Java, and your code will need to be changed in order to compile it in later versions of Java.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Use of identifier that is a keyword in later versions of Java

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Future Keyword Used As Member Identifier

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This identifier is used as a keyword in later versions of Java. This code, and any code that references this API, will need to be changed in order to compile it in later versions of Java.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Field names should start with a lower case letter

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Field Naming Convention

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Names of fields that are not final should be in mixed case with a lowercase first letter and the first letters of subsequent words capitalized.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Null value is guaranteed to be dereferenced

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Guaranteed Deref

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
There is a statement or branch that if executed guarantees that a value is null at this point, and that value that is guaranteed to be dereferenced (except on forward paths involving runtime exceptions).

Note that a check such as if (x == null) throw new NullPointerException(); is treated as a dereference of x.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Value is null and guaranteed to be dereferenced on exception path

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Guaranteed Deref On Exception Path

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: There is a statement or branch on an exception path that if executed guarantees that a value is null at this point, and that value that is guaranteed to be dereferenced (except on forward paths involving runtime exceptions).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Immediate dereference of the result of readLine()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Immediate Dereference Of Readline

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The result of invoking readLine() is immediately dereferenced. If there are no more lines of text to read, readLine() will return null and dereferencing that will generate a null pointer exception.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Load of known null value

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Load Of Known Null Value

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The variable referenced at this point is known to be null due to an earlier check against null. Although this is valid, it might be a mistake (perhaps you intended to refer to a different variable, or perhaps the earlier check to see if the variable is null should have been a check to see if it was non-null).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class defines tostring(); should it be toString()?

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Lcase Tostring

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class defines a method called tostring().Â  This method does not override the toString() method in java.lang.Object, which is probably what was intended.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method tightens nullness annotation on parameter

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Method Parameter Tightens Annotation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A method should always implement the contract of a method it overrides. Thus, if a method takes a parameter that is marked as @Nullable, you shouldnât override that method in a subclass with a method where that parameter is @Nonnull. Doing so violates the contract that the method should handle a null parameter.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method relaxes nullness annotation on return value

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Method Return Relaxing Annotation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A method should always implement the contract of a method it overrides. Thus, if a method takes is annotated as returning a @Nonnull value, you shouldnât override that method in a subclass with a method annotated as returning a @Nullable or @CheckForNull value. Doing so violates the contract that the method shouldnât return null.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Non-null field is not initialized

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Nonnull Field Not Initialized In Constructor

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The field is marked as non-null, but isnât written to by the constructor. The field might be initialized elsewhere during constructor, or might always be initialized before use.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A known null value is checked to see if it is an instance of a type

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Null Instanceof

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This instanceof test will always return false, since the value being checked is guaranteed to be null. Although this is safe, make sure it isnât an indication of some misunderstanding or some other logic error.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Naked notify

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Naked Notify

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A call to notify() or notifyAll() was made without any (apparent) accompanying modification to mutable object state.Â  In general, calling a notify method on a monitor is done because some condition another thread is waiting for has become true.Â  However, for the condition to be meaningful, it must involve a heap object that is visible to both threads.

This bug does not necessarily indicate an error, since the change to mutable object state may have taken place in a method which then called the method containing the notification.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Using notify() rather than notifyAll()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Notify Not Notifyall

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method calls notify() rather than notifyAll().Â  Java monitors are often used for multiple conditions.Â  Calling notify() only wakes up one thread, meaning that the thread woken up might not be the one waiting for the condition that the caller just satisfied.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Possible null pointer dereference

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Null On Some Path

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: There is a branch of statement that, if executed, guarantees that a null value will be dereferenced, which would generate a NullPointerException when the code is executed. Of course, the problem might be that the branch or statement is infeasible and that the null pointer exception canât ever be executed; deciding that is beyond the ability of SpotBugs.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Possible null pointer dereference in method on exception path

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Null On Some Path Exception

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A reference value which is null on some exception control path is dereferenced here.Â  This may lead to a NullPointerException when the code is executed.Â  Note that because SpotBugs currently does not prune infeasible exception paths, this may be a false warning.

Also note that SpotBugs considers the default case of a switch statement to be an exception path, since the default case is often infeasible.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Possible null pointer dereference due to return value of called method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Null On Some Path From Return Value

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The return value from a method is dereferenced without a null check, and the return value of that method is one that should generally be checked for null. This may lead to a NullPointerException when the code is executed.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Possible null pointer dereference on branch that might be infeasible

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Null On Some Path Might Be Infeasible

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: There is a branch of statement that, if executed, guarantees that a null value will be dereferenced, which would generate a NullPointerException when the code is executed. Of course, the problem might be that the branch or statement is infeasible and that the null pointer exception canât ever be executed; deciding that is beyond the ability of SpotBugs. Due to the fact that this value had been previously tested for nullness, this is a definite possibility.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method call passes null for non-null parameter

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Null Param Deref

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method call passes a null value for a non-null method parameter. Either the parameter is annotated as a parameter that should always be non-null, or analysis has shown that it will always be dereferenced.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method call passes null for non-null parameter

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Null Param Deref All Targets Dangerous

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A possibly-null value is passed at a call site where all known target methods require the parameter to be non-null. Either the parameter is annotated as a parameter that should always be non-null, or analysis has shown that it will always be dereferenced.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Non-virtual method call passes null for non-null parameter

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Null Param Deref Nonvirtual

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A possibly-null value is passed to a non-null method parameter. Either the parameter is annotated as a parameter that should always be non-null, or analysis has shown that it will always be dereferenced.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method call passes null to a non-null parameter

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Nonnull Param Violation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method passes a null value as the parameter of a method which must be non-null. Either this parameter has been explicitly marked as @Nonnull, or analysis has determined that this parameter is always dereferenced.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method may return null, but is declared @Nonnull

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Nonnull Return Violation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method may return a null value, but the method (or a superclass method which it overrides) is declared to return @Nonnull.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Questionable use of non-short-circuit logic

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Non Short Circuit

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This code seems to be using non-short-circuit logic (e.g., & or |) rather than short-circuit logic (&& or ||). Non-short-circuit logic causes both sides of the expression to be evaluated even when the result can be inferred from knowing the left-hand side. This can be less efficient and can result in errors if the left-hand side guards cases when evaluating the right-hand side can generate an error.

See the Java Language Specification for details.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method with Optional return type returns explicit null

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Optional Return Null

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The usage of Optional return type (java.util.Optional or com.google.common.base.Optional) always means that explicit null returns were not desired by design. Returning a null value in such case is a contract violation and will most likely break client code.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Parameter must be non-null but is marked as nullable

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Parameter Must Be Nonnull But Marked As Nullable

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This parameter is always used in a way that requires it to be non-null, but the parameter is explicitly annotated as being Nullable. Either the use of the parameter or the annotation is wrong.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Synchronize and null check on the same field.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Sync And Null Check Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Since the field is synchronized on, it seems not likely to be null. If it is null and then synchronized on a NullPointerException will be thrown and the check would be pointless. Better to synchronize on another field.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Store of null value into field annotated @Nonnull

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Store Into Nonnull Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A value that could be null is stored into a field that has been annotated as @Nonnull.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class names shouldn't shadow simple name of implemented interface

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Same Simple Name As Interface

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class/interface has a simple name that is identical to that of an implemented/extended interface, except that the interface is in a different package (e.g., alpha.Foo extends beta.Foo). This can be exceptionally confusing, create lots of situations in which you have to look at import statements to resolve references and creates many opportunities to accidentally define methods that do not override methods in their superclasses.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class names shouldn't shadow simple name of superclass

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Same Simple Name As Superclass

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class has a simple name that is identical to that of its superclass, except that its superclass is in a different package (e.g., alpha.Foo extends beta.Foo). This can be exceptionally confusing, create lots of situations in which you have to look at import statements to resolve references and creates many opportunities to accidentally define methods that do not override methods in their superclasses.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: toString method may return null

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Tostring Could Return Null

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This toString method seems to return null in some circumstances. A liberal reading of the spec could be interpreted as allowing this, but it is probably a bad idea and could cause other code to break. Return the empty string or some other appropriate string rather than null.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Read of unwritten field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unwritten Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The program is dereferencing a field that does not seem to ever have a non-null value written to it. Unless the field is initialized via some mechanism not seen by the analysis, dereferencing this value will generate a null pointer exception.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Read of unwritten public or protected field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unwritten Public Or Protected Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The program is dereferencing a public or protected field that does not seem to ever have a non-null value written to it. Unless the field is initialized via some mechanism not seen by the analysis, dereferencing this value will generate a null pointer exception.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Very confusing method names

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Very Confusing

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The referenced methods have names that differ only by capitalization. This is very confusing because if the capitalization were identical then one of the methods would override the other.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Very confusing method names (but perhaps intentional)

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Very Confusing Intentional

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The referenced methods have names that differ only by capitalization. This is very confusing because if the capitalization were identical then one of the methods would override the other. From the existence of other methods, it seems that the existence of both of these methods is intentional, but is sure is confusing. You should try hard to eliminate one of them, unless you are forced to have both due to frozen APIs.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method doesn't override method in superclass due to wrong package for parameter

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Wrong Package

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The method in the subclass doesnât override a similar method in a superclass because the type of a parameter doesnât exactly match the type of the corresponding parameter in the superclass. For example, if you have:

import alpha.Foo;

public class A {
    public int f(Foo x) { return 17; }
}
----
import beta.Foo;

public class B extends A {
    public int f(Foo x) { return 42; }
}

The f(Foo) method defined in class B doesnât override the f(Foo) method defined in class A, because the argument types are Fooâs from different packages.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method doesn't override method in superclass due to wrong package for parameter

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Wrong Package Intentional

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The method in the subclass doesnât override a similar method in a superclass because the type of a parameter doesnât exactly match the type of the corresponding parameter in the superclass. For example, if you have:

import alpha.Foo;

public class A {
    public int f(Foo x) { return 17; }
}
----
import beta.Foo;

public class B extends A {
    public int f(Foo x) { return 42; }
    public int f(alpha.Foo x) { return 27; }
}

The f(Foo) method defined in class B doesnât override the f(Foo) method defined in class A, because the argument types are Fooâs from different packages.

In this case, the subclass does define a method with a signature identical to the method in the superclass, so this is presumably understood. However, such methods are exceptionally confusing. You should strongly consider removing or deprecating the method with the similar but not identical signature.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Super method is annotated with @OverridingMethodsMustInvokeSuper, but the overriding method isn't calling the super method.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Methods Must Invoke Super

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Super method is annotated with @OverridingMethodsMustInvokeSuper, but the overriding method isnât calling the super method.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method may fail to close database resource

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Open Database Resource

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The method creates a database resource (such as a database connection or row set), does not assign it to any fields, pass it to other methods, or return it, and does not appear to close the object on all paths out of the method.Â  Failure to close database resources on all paths out of a method may result in poor performance, and could cause the application to have problems communicating with the database.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method may fail to close database resource on exception

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Open Database Resource Exception Path

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The method creates a database resource (such as a database connection or row set), does not assign it to any fields, pass it to other methods, or return it, and does not appear to close the object on all exception paths out of the method.Â  Failure to close database resources on all paths out of a method may result in poor performance, and could cause the application to have problems communicating with the database.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method may fail to close stream

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Open Stream

attribute.name: HelpText
