attribute.value: The method creates an IO stream object, does not assign it to any fields, pass it to other methods that might close it, or return it, and does not appear to close the stream on all paths out of the method.Â  This may result in a file descriptor leak.Â  It is generally a good idea to use a finally block to ensure that streams are closed.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method may fail to close stream on exception

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Open Stream Exception Path

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The method creates an IO stream object, does not assign it to any fields, pass it to other methods, or return it, and does not appear to close it on all possible exception paths out of the method.Â  This may result in a file descriptor leak.Â  It is generally a good idea to use a finally block to ensure that streams are closed.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method uses toArray() with zero-length array argument

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Inefficient To Array

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method uses the toArray() method of a collection derived class, and passes in a zero-length prototype array argument. It is more efficient to use `myCollection.toArray(new Foo[myCollection.size()])` If the array passed in is big enough to store all of the elements of the collection, then it is populated and returned directly. This avoids the need to create a second array (by reflection) to return as the result.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method may fail to clean up stream or resource

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unsatisfied Obligation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This method may fail to clean up (close, dispose of) a stream, database object, or other resource requiring an explicit cleanup operation.
In general, if a method opens a stream or other resource, the method should use a try/finally block to ensure that the stream or resource is cleaned up before the method returns.
This bug pattern is essentially the same as the OS\_OPEN\_STREAM and ODR\_OPEN\_DATABASE\_RESOURCE bug patterns, but is based on a different (and hopefully better) static analysis technique. We are interested is getting feedback about the usefulness of this bug pattern. For sending feedback, check:
- [contributing guideline](https://github.com/spotbugs/spotbugs/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) - [malinglist](https://github.com/spotbugs/discuss/issues?q=)
In particular, the false-positive suppression heuristics for this bug pattern have not been extensively tuned, so reports about false positives are helpful to us.
See Weimer and Necula, *Finding and Preventing Run-Time Error Handling Mistakes*, for a description of the analysis technique.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method may fail to clean up stream or resource on checked exception

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unsatisfied Obligation Exception Edge

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This method may fail to clean up (close, dispose of) a stream, database object, or other resource requiring an explicit cleanup operation.
In general, if a method opens a stream or other resource, the method should use a try/finally block to ensure that the stream or resource is cleaned up before the method returns.
This bug pattern is essentially the same as the OS\_OPEN\_STREAM and ODR\_OPEN\_DATABASE\_RESOURCE bug patterns, but is based on a different (and hopefully better) static analysis technique. We are interested is getting feedback about the usefulness of this bug pattern. For sending feedback, check:
- [contributing guideline](https://github.com/spotbugs/spotbugs/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) - [malinglist](https://github.com/spotbugs/discuss/issues?q=)
In particular, the false-positive suppression heuristics for this bug pattern have not been extensively tuned, so reports about false positives are helpful to us.
See Weimer and Necula, *Finding and Preventing Run-Time Error Handling Mistakes*, for a description of the analysis technique.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Absolute path traversal in servlet

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Absolute Path Traversal

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The software uses an HTTP request parameter to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize absolute path sequences such as â/abs/pathâ that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. See http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/36.html for more information.

SpotBugs looks only for the most blatant, obvious cases of absolute path traversal. If SpotBugs found any, you almost certainly have more vulnerabilities that SpotBugs doesnât report. If you are concerned about absolute path traversal, you should seriously consider using a commercial static analysis or pen-testing tool.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: clone method does not call super.clone()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Idiom No Super Call

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This non-final class defines a clone() method that does not call super.clone(). If this class (âAâ) is extended by a subclass (âBâ), and the subclass B calls super.clone(), then it is likely that Bâs clone() method will return an object of type A, which violates the standard contract for clone().

If all clone() methods call super.clone(), then they are guaranteed to use Object.clone(), which always returns an object of the correct type.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Don't reuse entry objects in iterators

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dont Reuse Entry Objects In Iterators

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The entrySet() method is allowed to return a view of the underlying Map in which an Iterator and Map.Entry. This clever idea was used in several Map implementations, but introduces the possibility of nasty coding mistakes. If a map m returns such an iterator for an entrySet, then c.addAll(m.entrySet()) will go badly wrong. All of the Map implementations in OpenJDK 1.7 have been rewritten to avoid this, you should to.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class exposes synchronization and semaphores in its public interface

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Public Semaphores

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class uses synchronization along with wait(), notify() or notifyAll() on itself (the this reference). Client classes that use this class, may, in addition, use an instance of this class as a synchronizing object. Because two classes are using the same object for synchronization, Multithread correctness is suspect. You should not synchronize nor call semaphore methods on a public reference. Consider using a internal private member variable to control synchronization.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Consider returning a zero length array rather than null

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Prefer Zero Length Arrays

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
It is often a better design to return a length zero array rather than a null reference to indicate that there are no results (i.e., an empty list of results). This way, no explicit check for null is needed by clients of the method.

On the other hand, using null to indicate âthere is no answer to this questionâ is probably appropriate. For example, File.listFiles() returns an empty list if given a directory containing no files, and returns null if the file is not a directory.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Relative path traversal in servlet

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Relative Path Traversal

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The software uses an HTTP request parameter to construct a pathname that should be within a restricted directory, but it does not properly neutralize sequences such as â..â that can resolve to a location that is outside of that directory. See http://cwe.mitre.org/data/definitions/23.html for more information.

SpotBugs looks only for the most blatant, obvious cases of relative path traversal. If SpotBugs found any, you almost certainly have more vulnerabilities that SpotBugs doesnât report. If you are concerned about relative path traversal, you should seriously consider using a commercial static analysis or pen-testing tool.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method assigns boolean literal in boolean expression

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Questionable Boolean Assignment

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method assigns a literal boolean value (true or false) to a boolean variable inside an if or while expression. Most probably this was supposed to be a boolean comparison using ==, not an assignment using =.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Complicated, subtle or wrong increment in for-loop

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Questionable For Loop

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Are you sure this for loop is incrementing the correct variable? It appears that another variable is being initialized and checked by the for loop.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Random value from 0 to 1 is coerced to the integer 0

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: 01 To Int

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A random value from 0 to 1 is being coerced to the integer value 0. You probably want to multiply the random value by something else before coercing it to an integer, or use the Random.nextInt(n) method.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Array index is out of bounds

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Array Index

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Array operation is performed, but array index is out of bounds, which will result in ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException at runtime.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Array length is out of bounds

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Array Length

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Method is called with array parameter and length parameter, but the length is out of bounds. This will result in IndexOutOfBoundsException at runtime.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Array offset is out of bounds

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Array Offset

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Method is called with array parameter and offset parameter, but the offset is out of bounds. This will result in IndexOutOfBoundsException at runtime.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Bad attempt to compute absolute value of signed 32-bit hashcode

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Absolute Value Of Hashcode

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This code generates a hashcode and then computes the absolute value of that hashcode. If the hashcode is Integer.MIN_VALUE, then the result will be negative as well (since Math.abs(Integer.MIN_VALUE) == Integer.MIN_VALUE).

One out of 2^32 strings have a hashCode of Integer.MIN_VALUE, including âpolygenelubricantsâ âGydZG_â and ââDESIGNING WORKHOUSESâ.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Bad attempt to compute absolute value of signed random integer

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Absolute Value Of Random Int

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code generates a random signed integer and then computes the absolute value of that random integer. If the number returned by the random number generator is Integer.MIN_VALUE, then the result will be negative as well (since Math.abs(Integer.MIN_VALUE) == Integer.MIN_VALUE). (Same problem arises for long values as well).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Invalid syntax for regular expression

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bad Syntax For Regular Expression

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The code here uses a regular expression that is invalid according to the syntax for regular expressions. This statement will throw a PatternSyntaxException when executed.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Code checks for specific values returned by compareTo

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Check Compareto For Specific Return Value

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code invoked a compareTo or compare method, and checks to see if the return value is a specific value, such as 1 or -1. When invoking these methods, you should only check the sign of the result, not for any specific non-zero value. While many or most compareTo and compare methods only return -1, 0 or 1, some of them will return other values.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Exception is caught when Exception is not thrown

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Catch Exception

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This method uses a try-catch block that catches Exception objects, but Exception is not thrown within the try block, and RuntimeException is not explicitly caught. It is a common bug pattern to say try { â¦ } catch (Exception e) { something } as a shorthand for catching a number of types of exception each of whose catch blocks is identical, but this construct also accidentally catches RuntimeException as well, masking potential bugs.

A better approach is to either explicitly catch the specific exceptions that are thrown, or to explicitly catch RuntimeException exception, rethrow it, and then catch all non-Runtime Exceptions, as shown below:

try {
    ...
} catch (RuntimeException e) {
    throw e;
} catch (Exception e) {
    ... deal with all non-runtime exceptions ...
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method checks to see if result of String.indexOf is positive

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Check For Positive Indexof

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The method invokes String.indexOf and checks to see if the result is positive or non-positive. It is much more typical to check to see if the result is negative or non-negative. It is positive only if the substring checked for occurs at some place other than at the beginning of the String.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: File.separator used for regular expression

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Cant Use File Separator As Regular Expression

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The code here uses File.separator where a regular expression is required. This will fail on Windows platforms, where the File.separator is a backslash, which is interpreted in a regular expression as an escape character. Among other options, you can just use File.separatorChar=='\\' ? "\\\\" : File.separator instead of File.separator

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method discards result of readLine after checking if it is non-null

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dont Just Null Check Readline

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The value returned by readLine is discarded after checking to see if the return value is non-null. In almost all situations, if the result is non-null, you will want to use that non-null value. Calling readLine again will give you a different line.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Clone method may return null

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Clone Could Return Null

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This clone method seems to return null in some circumstances, but clone is never allowed to return a null value. If you are convinced this path is unreachable, throw an AssertionError instead.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Exception created and dropped rather than thrown

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Exception Not Thrown

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This code creates an exception (or error) object, but doesnât do anything with it. For example, something like

if (x < 0) {
    new IllegalArgumentException("x must be nonnegative");
}

It was probably the intent of the programmer to throw the created exception:

if (x < 0) {
    throw new IllegalArgumentException("x must be nonnegative");
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method ignores results of InputStream.read()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Not Checked

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method ignores the return value of one of the variants of `java.io.InputStream.read()` which can return multiple bytes.Â If the return value is not checked, the caller will not be able to correctly handle the case where fewer bytes were read than the caller requested.Â This is a particularly insidious kind of bug, because in many programs, reads from input streams usually do read the full amount of data requested, causing the program to fail only sporadically.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Negating the result of compareTo()/compare()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Negating Result Of Compareto

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code negatives the return value of a compareTo or compare method. This is a questionable or bad programming practice, since if the return value is Integer.MIN_VALUE, negating the return value wonât negate the sign of the result. You can achieve the same intended result by reversing the order of the operands rather than by negating the results.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: "." or "|" used for regular expression

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Possible Unintended Pattern

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A String function is being invoked and â.â or â|â is being passed to a parameter that takes a regular expression as an argument. Is this what you intended? For example

  • s.replaceAll(â.â, â/â) will return a String in which every character has been replaced by a â/â character
  • s.split(â.â) always returns a zero length array of String
  • âab|cdâ.replaceAll(â|â, â/â) will return â/a/b/|/c/d/â
  • âab|cdâ.split(â|â) will return array with six (!) elements: [, a, b, |, c, d]

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Suspicious reference comparison

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Ref Comparison

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method compares two reference values using the == or != operator, where the correct way to compare instances of this type is generally with the equals() method. It is possible to create distinct instances that are equal but do not compare as == since they are different objects. Examples of classes which should generally not be compared by reference are java.lang.Integer, java.lang.Float, etc.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Suspicious reference comparison to constant

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Ref Comparison Bad Practice

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method compares a reference value to a constant using the == or != operator, where the correct way to compare instances of this type is generally with the equals() method. It is possible to create distinct instances that are equal but do not compare as == since they are different objects. Examples of classes which should generally not be compared by reference are java.lang.Integer, java.lang.Float, etc.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Suspicious reference comparison of Boolean values

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Ref Comparison Bad Practice Boolean

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method compares two Boolean values using the == or != operator. Normally, there are only two Boolean values (Boolean.TRUE and Boolean.FALSE), but it is possible to create other Boolean objects using the new Boolean(b) constructor. It is best to avoid such objects, but if they do exist, then checking Boolean objects for equality using == or != will give results than are different than you would get using .equals(...).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Redundant comparison of non-null value to null

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Redundant Comparison Of Null And Nonnull Value

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method contains a reference known to be non-null with another reference known to be null.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Repeated conditional tests

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Repeated Conditional Test

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The code contains a conditional test is performed twice, one right after the other (e.g., x == 0 || x == 0). Perhaps the second occurrence is intended to be something else (e.g., x == 0 || y == 0).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Redundant comparison of two null values

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Redundant Comparison Two Null Values

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method contains a redundant comparison of two references known to both be definitely null.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class implements same interface as superclass

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Redundant Interfaces

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class declares that it implements an interface that is also implemented by a superclass. This is redundant because once a superclass implements an interface, all subclasses by default also implement this interface. It may point out that the inheritance hierarchy has changed since this class was created, and consideration should be given to the ownership of the interfaceâs implementation.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Redundant nullcheck of value known to be non-null

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Redundant Nullcheck Of Nonnull Value

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method contains a redundant check of a known non-null value against the constant null.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Nullcheck of value previously dereferenced

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Redundant Nullcheck Would Have Been A Npe

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A value is checked here to see whether it is null, but this value canât be null because it was previously dereferenced and if it were null a null pointer exception would have occurred at the earlier dereference. Essentially, this code and the previous dereference disagree as to whether this value is allowed to be null. Either the check is redundant or the previous dereference is erroneous.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Remainder of hashCode could be negative

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Rem Of Hashcode

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This code computes a hashCode, and then computes the remainder of that value modulo another value. Since the hashCode can be negative, the result of the remainder operation can also be negative.

Assuming you want to ensure that the result of your computation is nonnegative, you may need to change your code. If you know the divisor is a power of 2, you can use a bitwise and operator instead (i.e., instead of using x.hashCode()%n, use x.hashCode()&(n-1)). This is probably faster than computing the remainder as well. If you donât know that the divisor is a power of 2, take the absolute value of the result of the remainder operation (i.e., use Math.abs(x.hashCode()%n)).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Remainder of 32-bit signed random integer

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Rem Of Random Int

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code generates a random signed integer and then computes the remainder of that value modulo another value. Since the random number can be negative, the result of the remainder operation can also be negative. Be sure this is intended, and strongly consider using the Random.nextInt(int) method instead.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class's readObject() method is synchronized

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Readobject Sync

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This serializable class defines a readObject() which is synchronized.Â  By definition, an object created by deserialization is only reachable by one thread, and thus there is no need for readObject() to be synchronized.Â  If the readObject() method itself is causing the object to become visible to another thread, that is an example of very dubious coding style.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method ignores return value

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Return Value Ignored

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The return value of this method should be checked. One common cause of this warning is to invoke a method on an immutable object, thinking that it updates the object. For example, in the following code fragment,

String dateString = getHeaderField(name);
dateString.trim();

the programmer seems to be thinking that the trim() method will update the String referenced by dateString. But since Strings are immutable, the trim() function returns a new String value, which is being ignored here. The code should be corrected to:

String dateString = getHeaderField(name);
dateString = dateString.trim();

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method ignores exceptional return value

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Return Value Ignored Bad Practice

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method returns a value that is not checked. The return value should be checked since it can indicate an unusual or unexpected function execution. For example, the File.delete() method returns false if the file could not be successfully deleted (rather than throwing an Exception). If you donât check the result, you wonât notice if the method invocation signals unexpected behavior by returning an atypical return value.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method ignores return value, is this OK?

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Return Value Ignored Inferred

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This code calls a method and ignores the return value. The return value is the same type as the type the method is invoked on, and from our analysis it looks like the return value might be important (e.g., like ignoring the return value of String.toLowerCase()).

We are guessing that ignoring the return value might be a bad idea just from a simple analysis of the body of the method. You can use a @CheckReturnValue annotation to instruct SpotBugs as to whether ignoring the return value of this method is important or acceptable.

Please investigate this closely to decide whether it is OK to ignore the return value.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Return value of method without side effect is ignored

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Return Value Ignored No Side Effect

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This code calls a method and ignores the return value. However our analysis shows that the method (including its implementations in subclasses if any) does not produce any effect other than return value. Thus this call can be removed.

We are trying to reduce the false positives as much as possible, but in some cases this warning might be wrong. Common false-positive cases include:

  • The method is designed to be overridden and produce a side effect in other projects which are out of the scope of the analysis.

  • The method is called to trigger the class loading which may have a side effect.

  • The method is called just to get some exception.

If you feel that our assumption is incorrect, you can use a @CheckReturnValue annotation to instruct SpotBugs that ignoring the return value of this method is acceptable.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Return value of putIfAbsent ignored, value passed to putIfAbsent reused

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Return Value Of Putifabsent Ignored

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The putIfAbsent method is typically used to ensure that a single value is associated with a given key (the first value for which put if absent succeeds). If you ignore the return value and retain a reference to the value passed in, you run the risk of retaining a value that is not the one that is associated with the key in the map. If it matters which one you use and you use the one that isnât stored in the map, your program will behave incorrectly.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: String index is out of bounds

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: String Index

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: String method is called and specified string index is out of bounds. This will result in StringIndexOutOfBoundsException at runtime.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Redundant nullcheck of value known to be null

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Redundant Nullcheck Of Null Value

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method contains a redundant check of a known null value against the constant null.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Non-transient non-serializable instance field in serializable class

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bad Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This Serializable class defines a non-primitive instance field which is neither transient, Serializable, or java.lang.Object, and does not appear to implement the Externalizable interface or the readObject() and writeObject() methods.Â  Objects of this class will not be deserialized correctly if a non-Serializable object is stored in this field.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Non-serializable class has a serializable inner class

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bad Field Inner Class

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This Serializable class is an inner class of a non-serializable class. Thus, attempts to serialize it will also attempt to associate instance of the outer class with which it is associated, leading to a runtime error.

If possible, making the inner class a static inner class should solve the problem. Making the outer class serializable might also work, but that would mean serializing an instance of the inner class would always also serialize the instance of the outer class, which it often not what you really want.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Non-serializable value stored into instance field of a serializable class

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bad Field Store

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A non-serializable value is stored into a non-transient field of a serializable class.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method attempts to access a prepared statement parameter with index 0

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bad Prepared Statement Access

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A call to a setXXX method of a prepared statement was made where the parameter index is 0. As parameter indexes start at index 1, this is always a mistake.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method attempts to access a result set field with index 0

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bad Resultset Access

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A call to getXXX or updateXXX methods of a result set was made where the field index is 0. As ResultSet fields start at index 1, this is always a mistake.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Comparator doesn't implement Serializable

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Comparator Should Be Serializable

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class implements the Comparator interface. You should consider whether or not it should also implement the Serializable interface. If a comparator is used to construct an ordered collection such as a TreeMap, then the TreeMap will be serializable only if the comparator is also serializable. As most comparators have little or no state, making them serializable is generally easy and good defensive programming.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class too big for analysis

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Class Too Big

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class is bigger than can be effectively handled, and was not fully analyzed for errors.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Dead store due to switch statement fall through

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dead Store Due To Switch Fallthrough

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A value stored in the previous switch case is overwritten here due to a switch fall through. It is likely that you forgot to put a break or return at the end of the previous case.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Dead store due to switch statement fall through to throw

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dead Store Due To Switch Fallthrough To Throw

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A value stored in the previous switch case is ignored here due to a switch fall through to a place where an exception is thrown. It is likely that you forgot to put a break or return at the end of the previous case.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Double assignment of field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Field Double Assignment

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This method contains a double assignment of a field; e.g.

int x,y;
public void foo() {
    x = x = 17;
}

Assigning to a field twice is useless, and may indicate a logic error or typo.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Self assignment of field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Field Self Assignment

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This method contains a self assignment of a field; e.g.

int x;
public void foo() {
    x = x;
}

Such assignments are useless, and may indicate a logic error or typo.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Self comparison of field with itself

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Field Self Comparison

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method compares a field with itself, and may indicate a typo or a logic error. Make sure that you are comparing the right things.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class defines hashcode(); should it be hashCode()?

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Lcase Hashcode

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class defines a method called hashcode().Â  This method does not override the hashCode() method in java.lang.Object, which is probably what was intended.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Static initializer creates instance before all static final fields assigned

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Instance Before Finals Assigned

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The classâs static initializer creates an instance of the class before all of the static final fields are assigned.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Serializable inner class

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Inner Class

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This Serializable class is an inner class. Any attempt to serialize it will also serialize the associated outer instance. The outer instance is serializable, so this wonât fail, but it might serialize a lot more data than intended. If possible, making the inner class a static inner class (also known as a nested class) should solve the problem.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Unneeded use of currentThread() call, to call interrupted()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Interrupted On Currentthread

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method invokes the Thread.currentThread() call, just to call the interrupted() method. As interrupted() is a static method, is more simple and clear to use Thread.interrupted().

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Call to static Calendar

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Invoke On Static Calendar Instance

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Even though the JavaDoc does not contain a hint about it, Calendars are inherently unsafe for multithreaded use. The detector has found a call to an instance of Calendar that has been obtained via a static field. This looks suspicious.

For more information on this see JDK Bug #6231579 and JDK Bug #6178997.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Call to static DateFormat

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Invoke On Static Date Format Instance

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
As the JavaDoc states, DateFormats are inherently unsafe for multithreaded use. The detector has found a call to an instance of DateFormat that has been obtained via a static field. This looks suspicious.

For more information on this see JDK Bug #6231579 and JDK Bug #6178997.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Static Thread.interrupted() method invoked on thread instance

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Interrupted On Unknownthread

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method invokes the Thread.interrupted() method on a Thread object that appears to be a Thread object that is not the current thread. As the interrupted() method is static, the interrupted method will be called on a different object than the one the author intended.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Should be a static inner class

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Inner Should Be Static

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class is an inner class, but does not use its embedded reference to the object which created it.Â  This reference makes the instances of the class larger, and may keep the reference to the creator object alive longer than necessary.Â  If possible, the class should be made static.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Could be refactored into a named static inner class

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Inner Should Be Static Anon

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class is an inner class, but does not use its embedded reference to the object which created it.Â  This reference makes the instances of the class larger, and may keep the reference to the creator object alive longer than necessary.Â  If possible, the class should be made into a static inner class. Since anonymous inner classes cannot be marked as static, doing this will require refactoring the inner class so that it is a named inner class.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Could be refactored into a static inner class

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Inner Should Be Static Needs This

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class is an inner class, but does not use its embedded reference to the object which created it except during construction of the inner object.Â  This reference makes the instances of the class larger, and may keep the reference to the creator object alive longer than necessary.Â  If possible, the class should be made into a static inner class. Since the reference to the outer object is required during construction of the inner instance, the inner class will need to be refactored so as to pass a reference to the outer instance to the constructor for the inner class.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Double assignment of local variable

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Local Double Assignment

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This method contains a double assignment of a local variable; e.g.

public void foo() {
    int x,y;
    x = x = 17;
}

Assigning the same value to a variable twice is useless, and may indicate a logic error or typo.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Self assignment of local variable

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Local Self Assignment

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This method contains a self assignment of a local variable; e.g.

public void foo() {
    int x = 3;
    x = x;
}

Such assignments are useless, and may indicate a logic error or typo.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Self assignment of local rather than assignment to field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Local Self Assignment Instead Of Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This method contains a self assignment of a local variable, and there is a field with an identical name. assignment appears to have been ; e.g.

    int foo;
    public void setFoo(int foo) {
        foo = foo;
    }

The assignment is useless. Did you mean to assign to the field instead?

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Self comparison of value with itself

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Local Self Comparison

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method compares a local variable with itself, and may indicate a typo or a logic error. Make sure that you are comparing the right things.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method must be private in order for serialization to work

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Method Must Be Private

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class implements the Serializable interface, and defines a method for custom serialization/deserialization. But since that method isnât declared private, it will be silently ignored by the serialization/deserialization API.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method ignores results of InputStream.skip()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Not Checked

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method ignores the return value of java.io.InputStream.skip() which can skip multiple bytes.Â  If the return value is not checked, the caller will not be able to correctly handle the case where fewer bytes were skipped than the caller requested.Â  This is a particularly insidious kind of bug, because in many programs, skips from input streams usually do skip the full amount of data requested, causing the program to fail only sporadically. With Buffered streams, however, skip() will only skip data in the buffer, and will routinely fail to skip the requested number of bytes.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: serialVersionUID isn't final

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Nonfinal Serialversionid

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class defines a serialVersionUID field that is not final.Â  The field should be made final if it is intended to specify the version UID for purposes of serialization.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class is Serializable but its superclass doesn't define a void constructor

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: No Suitable Constructor

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class implements the Serializable interface and its superclass does not. When such an object is deserialized, the fields of the superclass need to be initialized by invoking the void constructor of the superclass. Since the superclass does not have one, serialization and deserialization will fail at runtime.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class is Externalizable but doesn't define a void constructor

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: No Suitable Constructor For Externalization

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class implements the Externalizable interface, but does not define a public void constructor. When Externalizable objects are deserialized, they first need to be constructed by invoking the public void constructor. Since this class does not have one, serialization and deserialization will fail at runtime.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Nonconstant string passed to execute or addBatch method on an SQL statement

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Nonconstant String Passed To Execute

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The method invokes the execute or addBatch method on an SQL statement with a String that seems to be dynamically generated. Consider using a prepared statement instead. It is more efficient and less vulnerable to SQL injection attacks.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Private readResolve method not inherited by subclasses

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Private Read Resolve Not Inherited

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class defines a private readResolve method. Since it is private, it wonât be inherited by subclasses. This might be intentional and OK, but should be reviewed to ensure it is what is intended.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A prepared statement is generated from a nonconstant String

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Prepared Statement Generated From Nonconstant String

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The code creates an SQL prepared statement from a nonconstant String. If unchecked, tainted data from a user is used in building this String, SQL injection could be used to make the prepared statement do something unexpected and undesirable.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The readResolve method must not be declared as a static method.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Read Resolve Is Static

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: In order for the readResolve method to be recognized by the serialization mechanism, it must not be declared as a static method.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The readResolve method must be declared with a return type of Object.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Read Resolve Must Return Object

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: In order for the readResolve method to be recognized by the serialization mechanism, it must be declared to have a return type of Object.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Unread field: should this field be static?

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Should Be Static

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class contains an instance final field that is initialized to a compile-time static value. Consider making the field static.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Static Calendar field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Static Calendar Instance

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Even though the JavaDoc does not contain a hint about it, Calendars are inherently unsafe for multithreaded use. Sharing a single instance across thread boundaries without proper synchronization will result in erratic behavior of the application. Under 1.4 problems seem to surface less often than under Java 5 where you will probably see random ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsExceptions or IndexOutOfBoundsExceptions in sun.util.calendar.BaseCalendar.getCalendarDateFromFixedDate().

You may also experience serialization problems.

Using an instance field is recommended.

For more information on this see JDK Bug #6231579 and JDK Bug #6178997.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Unnecessary type check done using instanceof operator

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Superfluous Instanceof

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Type check performed using the instanceof operator where it can be statically determined whether the object is of the type requested.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Constructor invokes Thread.start()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Start In Ctor

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: The constructor starts a thread. This is likely to be wrong if the class is ever extended/subclassed, since the thread will be started before the subclass constructor is started.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Certain swing methods needs to be invoked in Swing thread

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Swing Methods Invoked In Swing Thread

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: (From JDC Tech Tip): The Swing methods show(), setVisible(), and pack() will create the associated peer for the frame. With the creation of the peer, the system creates the event dispatch thread. This makes things problematic because the event dispatch thread could be notifying listeners while pack and validate are still processing. This situation could result in two threads going through the Swing component-based GUI â itâs a serious flaw that could result in deadlocks or other related threading issues. A pack call causes components to be realized. As they are being realized (that is, not necessarily visible), they could trigger listener notification on the event dispatch thread.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method spins on field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Spin On Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method spins in a loop which reads a field.Â  The compiler may legally hoist the read out of the loop, turning the code into an infinite loop.Â  The class should be changed so it uses proper synchronization (including wait and notify calls).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Static DateFormat

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Static Simple Date Format Instance

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
As the JavaDoc states, DateFormats are inherently unsafe for multithreaded use. Sharing a single instance across thread boundaries without proper synchronization will result in erratic behavior of the application.

You may also experience serialization problems.

Using an instance field is recommended.

For more information on this see JDK Bug #6231579 and JDK Bug #6178997.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method calls Thread.sleep() with a lock held

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Sleep With Lock Held

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method calls Thread.sleep() with a lock held. This may result in very poor performance and scalability, or a deadlock, since other threads may be waiting to acquire the lock. It is a much better idea to call wait() on the lock, which releases the lock and allows other threads to run.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Deadly embrace of non-static inner class and thread local

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Threadlocal Deadly Embrace

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class is an inner class, but should probably be a static inner class. As it is, there is a serious danger of a deadly embrace between the inner class and the thread local in the outer class. Because the inner class isnât static, it retains a reference to the outer class. If the thread local contains a reference to an instance of the inner class, the inner and outer instance will both be reachable and not eligible for garbage collection.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Transient field that isn't set by deserialization.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Transient Field Not Restored

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class contains a field that is updated at multiple places in the class, thus it seems to be part of the state of the class. However, since the field is marked as transient and not set in readObject or readResolve, it will contain the default value in any deserialized instance of the class.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Transient field of class that isn't Serializable.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Transient Field Of Nonserializable Class

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The field is marked as transient, but the class isnât Serializable, so marking it as transient has absolutely no effect. This may be leftover marking from a previous version of the code in which the class was transient, or it may indicate a misunderstanding of how serialization works.

This bug is reported only if special option reportTransientFieldOfNonSerializableClass is set.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method invokes toString() method on a String

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: String Tostring

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Calling String.toString() is just a redundant operation. Just use the String.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Write to static field from instance method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Write To Static From Instance Method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This instance method writes to a static field. This is tricky to get correct if multiple instances are being manipulated, and generally bad practice.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Nonsensical self computation involving a field (e.g., x & x)

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Field Self Computation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method performs a nonsensical computation of a field with another reference to the same field (e.g., x&x or x-x). Because of the nature of the computation, this operation doesnât seem to make sense, and may indicate a typo or a logic error. Double check the computation.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Nonsensical self computation involving a variable (e.g., x & x)

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Local Self Computation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method performs a nonsensical computation of a local variable with another reference to the same variable (e.g., x&x or x-x). Because of the nature of the computation, this operation doesnât seem to make sense, and may indicate a typo or a logic error. Double check the computation.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: serialVersionUID isn't long

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Nonlong Serialversionid

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class defines a serialVersionUID field that is not long.Â  The field should be made long if it is intended to specify the version UID for purposes of serialization.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: serialVersionUID isn't static

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Nonstatic Serialversionid

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class defines a serialVersionUID field that is not static.Â  The field should be made static if it is intended to specify the version UID for purposes of serialization.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Value annotated as carrying a type qualifier used where a value that must not carry that qualifier is required

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Always Value Used Where Never Required

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A value specified as carrying a type qualifier annotation is consumed in a location or locations requiring that the value not carry that annotation.

More precisely, a value annotated with a type qualifier specifying when=ALWAYS is guaranteed to reach a use or uses where the same type qualifier specifies when=NEVER.

For example, say that @NonNegative is a nickname for the type qualifier annotation @Negative(when=When.NEVER). The following code will generate this warning because the return statement requires a @NonNegative value, but receives one that is marked as @Negative.

public @NonNegative Integer example(@Negative Integer value) {
    return value;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Comparing values with incompatible type qualifiers

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Comparing Values With Incompatible Type Qualifiers

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A value specified as carrying a type qualifier annotation is compared with a value that doesnât ever carry that qualifier.

More precisely, a value annotated with a type qualifier specifying when=ALWAYS is compared with a value that where the same type qualifier specifies when=NEVER.

For example, say that @NonNegative is a nickname for the type qualifier annotation @Negative(when=When.NEVER). The following code will generate this warning because the return statement requires a @NonNegative value, but receives one that is marked as @Negative.

public boolean example(@Negative Integer value1, @NonNegative Integer value2) {
    return value1.equals(value2);
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Value required to have type qualifier, but marked as unknown

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Explicit Unknown Source Value Reaches Always Sink

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A value is used in a way that requires it to be always be a value denoted by a type qualifier, but there is an explicit annotation stating that it is not known where the value is required to have that type qualifier. Either the usage or the annotation is incorrect.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Value required to not have type qualifier, but marked as unknown

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Explicit Unknown Source Value Reaches Never Sink

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A value is used in a way that requires it to be never be a value denoted by a type qualifier, but there is an explicit annotation stating that it is not known where the value is prohibited from having that type qualifier. Either the usage or the annotation is incorrect.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Value that might not carry a type qualifier is always used in a way requires that type qualifier

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Maybe Source Value Reaches Always Sink

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A value that is annotated as possibility not being an instance of the values denoted by the type qualifier, and the value is guaranteed to be used in a way that requires values denoted by that type qualifier.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Value that might carry a type qualifier is always used in a way prohibits it from having that type qualifier

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Maybe Source Value Reaches Never Sink

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A value that is annotated as possibility being an instance of the values denoted by the type qualifier, and the value is guaranteed to be used in a way that prohibits values denoted by that type qualifier.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Value annotated as never carrying a type qualifier used where value carrying that qualifier is required

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Never Value Used Where Always Required

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A value specified as not carrying a type qualifier annotation is guaranteed to be consumed in a location or locations requiring that the value does carry that annotation.

More precisely, a value annotated with a type qualifier specifying when=NEVER is guaranteed to reach a use or uses where the same type qualifier specifies when=ALWAYS.

TODO: example

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Wait with two locks held

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Two Lock Wait

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Waiting on a monitor while two locks are held may cause deadlock. Â  Performing a wait only releases the lock on the object being waited on, not any other locks. Â  This not necessarily a bug, but is worth examining closely.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Value without a type qualifier used where a value is required to have that qualifier

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unknown Value Used Where Always Strictly Required

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A value is being used in a way that requires the value be annotation with a type qualifier. The type qualifier is strict, so the tool rejects any values that do not have the appropriate annotation.

To coerce a value to have a strict annotation, define an identity function where the return value is annotated with the strict annotation. This is the only way to turn a non-annotated value into a value with a strict type qualifier annotation.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Field not initialized in constructor but dereferenced without null check

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Field Not Initialized In Constructor

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This field is never initialized within any constructor, and is therefore could be null after the object is constructed. Elsewhere, it is loaded and dereferenced without a null check. This could be a either an error or a questionable design, since it means a null pointer exception will be generated if that field is dereferenced before being initialized.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Usage of GetResource may be unsafe if class is extended

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Inheritance Unsafe Getresource

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Calling this.getClass().getResource(...) could give results other than expected if this class is extended by a class in another package.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Consider using Locale parameterized version of invoked method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Convert Case

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A String is being converted to upper or lowercase, using the platformâs default encoding. This may result in improper conversions when used with international characters. Use the

  • String.toUpperCase( Locale l )
  • String.toLowerCase( Locale l )

versions instead.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: equals() method does not check for null argument

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Equals Should Handle Null Argument

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This implementation of equals(Object) violates the contract defined by java.lang.Object.equals() because it does not check for null being passed as the argument. All equals() methods should return false if passed a null value.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Field only ever set to null

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Null Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: All writes to this field are of the constant value null, and thus all reads of the field will return null. Check for errors, or remove it if it is useless.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Useless increment in return statement

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dead Local Increment In Return

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This statement has a return such as return x++;. A postfix increment/decrement does not impact the value of the expression, so this increment/decrement has no effect. Please verify that this statement does the right thing.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method concatenates strings using + in a loop

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Stringbuffer Concatenation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The method seems to be building a String using concatenation in a loop. In each iteration, the String is converted to a StringBuffer/StringBuilder, appended to, and converted back to a String. This can lead to a cost quadratic in the number of iterations, as the growing string is recopied in each iteration.

Better performance can be obtained by using a StringBuffer (or StringBuilder in Java 1.5) explicitly.

For example:

// This is bad
String s = "";
for (int i = 0; i < field.length; ++i) {
    s = s + field[i];
}

// This is better
StringBuffer buf = new StringBuffer();
for (int i = 0; i < field.length; ++i) {
    buf.append(field[i]);
}
String s = buf.toString();

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Unsynchronized get method, synchronized set method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Sync Set Unsync Get

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class contains similarly-named get and set methods where the set method is synchronized and the get method is not.Â  This may result in incorrect behavior at runtime, as callers of the get method will not necessarily see a consistent state for the object.Â  The get method should be made synchronized.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Abstract Method is already defined in implemented interface

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Useless Abstract Method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This abstract method is already defined in an interface that is implemented by this abstract class. This method can be removed, as it provides no additional value.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Useless control flow

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Useless Control Flow

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This method contains a useless control flow statement, where control flow continues onto the same place regardless of whether or not the branch is taken. For example, this is caused by having an empty statement block for an if statement:

if (argv.length == 0) {
    // TODO: handle this case
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Useless control flow to next line

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Useless Control Flow Next Line

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This method contains a useless control flow statement in which control flow follows to the same or following line regardless of whether or not the branch is taken. Often, this is caused by inadvertently using an empty statement as the body of an if statement, e.g.:

if (argv.length == 1);
    System.out.println("Hello, " + argv[0]);

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Condition has no effect due to the variable type

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Useless Condition Type

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This condition always produces the same result due to the type range of the involved variable. Probably something else was meant or the condition can be removed.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Condition has no effect

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Useless Condition

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This condition always produces the same result as the value of the involved variable that was narrowed before. Probably something else was meant or the condition can be removed.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Unread field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unread Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This field is never read.Â  Consider removing it from the class.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method does not release lock on all paths

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unreleased Lock

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This method acquires a JSR-166 (java.util.concurrent) lock, but does not release it on all paths out of the method. In general, the correct idiom for using a JSR-166 lock is:

Lock l = ...;
l.lock();
try {
    // do something
} finally {
    l.unlock();
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method does not release lock on all exception paths

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unreleased Lock Exception Path

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This method acquires a JSR-166 (java.util.concurrent) lock, but does not release it on all exception paths out of the method. In general, the correct idiom for using a JSR-166 lock is:

Lock l = ...;
l.lock();
try {
    // do something
} finally {
    l.unlock();
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method calls static Math class method on a constant value

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unnecessary Math

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This method uses a static method from java.lang.Math on a constant value. This methodâs result in this case, can be determined statically, and is faster and sometimes more accurate to just use the constant. Methods detected are:

Method Parameter
abs -any-
acos 0.0 or 1.0
asin 0.0 or 1.0
atan 0.0 or 1.0
atan2 0.0
cbrt 0.0 or 1.0
ceil -any-
cos 0.0
cosh 0.0
exp 0.0 or 1.0
expm1 0.0
floor -any-
log 0.0 or 1.0
log10 0.0 or 1.0
rint -any-
round -any-
sin 0.0
sinh 0.0
sqrt 0.0 or 1.0
tan 0.0
tanh 0.0
toDegrees 0.0 or 1.0
toRadians 0.0

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Uncallable method defined in anonymous class

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Uncallable Method Of Anonymous Class

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This anonymous class defines a method that is not directly invoked and does not override a method in a superclass. Since methods in other classes cannot directly invoke methods declared in an anonymous class, it seems that this method is uncallable. The method might simply be dead code, but it is also possible that the method is intended to override a method declared in a superclass, and due to a typo or other error the method does not, in fact, override the method it is intended to.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Useless object created

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Useless Object

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Our analysis shows that this object is useless. Itâs created and modified, but its value never go outside of the method or produce any side-effect. Either there is a mistake and object was intended to be used or it can be removed.

This analysis rarely produces false-positives. Common false-positive cases include:

  • This object used to implicitly throw some obscure exception.

  • This object used as a stub to generalize the code.

  • This object used to hold strong references to weak/soft-referenced objects.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Useless object created on stack

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Useless Object Stack

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This object is created just to perform some modifications which donât have any side-effect. Probably something else was meant or the object can be removed.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Private method is never called

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Uncalled Private Method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This private method is never called. Although it is possible that the method will be invoked through reflection, it is more likely that the method is never used, and should be removed.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Unread public/protected field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unread Public Or Protected Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This field is never read.Â  The field is public or protected, so perhaps it is intended to be used with classes not seen as part of the analysis. If not, consider removing it from the class.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Uninitialized read of field in constructor

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Uninit Read

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This constructor reads a field which has not yet been assigned a value.Â  This is often caused when the programmer mistakenly uses the field instead of one of the constructorâs parameters.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Uninitialized read of field method called from constructor of superclass

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Uninit Read Called From Super Constructor

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This method is invoked in the constructor of the superclass. At this point, the fields of the class have not yet initialized.

To make this more concrete, consider the following classes:

abstract class A {
    int hashCode;
    abstract Object getValue();

    A() {
        hashCode = getValue().hashCode();
    }
}

class B extends A {
    Object value;

    B(Object v) {
        this.value = v;
    }

    Object getValue() {
        return value;
    }
}

When a B is constructed, the constructor for the A class is invoked before the constructor for B sets value. Thus, when the constructor for A invokes getValue, an uninitialized value is read for value.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method superfluously delegates to parent class method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Useless Subclass Method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This derived method merely calls the same superclass method passing in the exact parameters received. This method can be removed, as it provides no additional value.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Useless non-empty void method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Useless Void Method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Our analysis shows that this non-empty void method does not actually perform any useful work. Please check it: probably thereâs a mistake in its code or its body can be fully removed.

We are trying to reduce the false positives as much as possible, but in some cases this warning might be wrong. Common false-positive cases include:

  • The method is intended to trigger loading of some class which may have a side effect.
  • The method is intended to implicitly throw some obscure exception.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Unconditional wait

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Uncond Wait

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method contains a call to java.lang.Object.wait() which is not guarded by conditional control flow.Â  The code should verify that condition it intends to wait for is not already satisfied before calling wait; any previous notifications will be ignored.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method invokes inefficient Number constructor; use static valueOf instead

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Number Ctor

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Using new Integer(int) is guaranteed to always result in a new object whereas Integer.valueOf(int) allows caching of values to be done by the compiler, class library, or JVM. Using of cached values avoids object allocation and the code will be faster.

Values between -128 and 127 are guaranteed to have corresponding cached instances and using valueOf is approximately 3.5 times faster than using constructor. For values outside the constant range the performance of both styles is the same.

Unless the class must be compatible with JVMs predating Java 1.5, use either autoboxing or the valueOf() method when creating instances of Long, Integer, Short, Character, and Byte.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Unused field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unused Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This field is never used.Â  Consider removing it from the class.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Unused public or protected field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unused Public Or Protected Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This field is never used.Â  The field is public or protected, so perhaps it is intended to be used with classes not seen as part of the analysis. If not, consider removing it from the class.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Unwritten field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unwritten Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This field is never written.Â  All reads of it will return the default value. Check for errors (should it have been initialized?), or remove it if it is useless.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Unwritten public or protected field

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unwritten Public Or Protected Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: No writes were seen to this public/protected field.Â  All reads of it will return the default value. Check for errors (should it have been initialized?), or remove it if it is useless.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Format string should use %n rather than \n

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Format String Uses Newline

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This format string includes a newline character (\n). In format strings, it is generally preferable to use %n, which will produce the platform-specific line separator.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Primitive array passed to function expecting a variable number of object arguments

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Primitive Array Passed To Object Vararg

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code passes a primitive array to a function that takes a variable number of object arguments. This creates an array of length one to hold the primitive array and passes it to the function.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class makes reference to unresolvable class or method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unresolvable Reference

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class makes a reference to a class or method that can not be resolved using against the libraries it is being analyzed with.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An increment to a volatile field isn't atomic

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Volatile Increment

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This code increments a volatile field. Increments of volatile fields arenât atomic. If more than one thread is incrementing the field at the same time, increments could be lost.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A volatile reference to an array doesn't treat the array elements as volatile

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Volatile Reference To Array

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This declares a volatile reference to an array, which might not be what you want. With a volatile reference to an array, reads and writes of the reference to the array are treated as volatile, but the array elements are non-volatile. To get volatile array elements, you will need to use one of the atomic array classes in java.util.concurrent (provided in Java 5.0).

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Condition.await() not in loop

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Await Not In Loop

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method contains a call to java.util.concurrent.await() (or variants) which is not in a loop.Â  If the object is used for multiple conditions, the condition the caller intended to wait for might not be the one that actually occurred.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Wait not in loop

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Not In Loop

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method contains a call to java.lang.Object.wait() which is not in a loop.Â  If the monitor is used for multiple conditions, the condition the caller intended to wait for might not be the one that actually occurred.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Synchronization on getClass rather than class literal

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Using Getclass Rather Than Class Literal

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This instance method synchronizes on this.getClass(). If this class is subclassed, subclasses will synchronize on the class object for the subclass, which isnât likely what was intended. For example, consider this code from java.awt.Label:

private static final String base = "label";
private static int nameCounter = 0;

String constructComponentName() {
    synchronized (getClass()) {
        return base + nameCounter++;
    }
}

Subclasses of Label wonât synchronize on the same subclass, giving rise to a datarace. Instead, this code should be synchronizing on Label.class

private static final String base = "label";
private static int nameCounter = 0;

String constructComponentName() {
    synchronized (Label.class) {
        return base + nameCounter++;
    }
}

Bug pattern contributed by Jason Mehrens

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Inefficient use of keySet iterator instead of entrySet iterator

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Wrong Map Iterator

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This method accesses the value of a Map entry, using a key that was retrieved from a keySet iterator. It is more efficient to use an iterator on the entrySet of the map, to avoid the Map.get(key) lookup.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class's writeObject() method is synchronized but nothing else is

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Writeobject Sync
