attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: This class has a writeObject() method which is synchronized; however, no other method of the class is synchronized.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: JSP reflected cross site scripting vulnerability

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Request Parameter To Jsp Writer

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This code directly writes an HTTP parameter to JSP output, which allows for a cross site scripting vulnerability. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-site_scripting for more information.

SpotBugs looks only for the most blatant, obvious cases of cross site scripting. If SpotBugs found any, you almost certainly have more cross site scripting vulnerabilities that SpotBugs doesnât report. If you are concerned about cross site scripting, you should seriously consider using a commercial static analysis or pen-testing tool.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Servlet reflected cross site scripting vulnerability in error page

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Request Parameter To Send Error

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This code directly writes an HTTP parameter to a Server error page (using HttpServletResponse.sendError). Echoing this untrusted input allows for a reflected cross site scripting vulnerability. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-site_scripting for more information.

SpotBugs looks only for the most blatant, obvious cases of cross site scripting. If SpotBugs found any, you almost certainly have more cross site scripting vulnerabilities that SpotBugs doesnât report. If you are concerned about cross site scripting, you should seriously consider using a commercial static analysis or pen-testing tool.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Servlet reflected cross site scripting vulnerability

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Request Parameter To Servlet Writer

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This code directly writes an HTTP parameter to Servlet output, which allows for a reflected cross site scripting vulnerability. See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cross-site_scripting for more information.

SpotBugs looks only for the most blatant, obvious cases of cross site scripting. If SpotBugs found any, you almost certainly have more cross site scripting vulnerabilities that SpotBugs doesnât report. If you are concerned about cross site scripting, you should seriously consider using a commercial static analysis or pen-testing tool.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method directly allocates a specific implementation of xml interfaces

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Xml Factory Bypass

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This method allocates a specific implementation of an xml interface. It is preferable to use the supplied factory classes to create these objects so that the implementation can be changed at runtime. See

  • javax.xml.parsers.DocumentBuilderFactory
  • javax.xml.parsers.SAXParserFactory
  • javax.xml.transform.TransformerFactory
  • org.w3c.dom.Document.createXXXX

for details.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid catching NullPointerException; consider removing the cause of the NPE.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Catching NPE

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Code should never throw NullPointerExceptions under normal circumstances. A catch block may hide the original error, causing other, more subtle problems later on.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  void bar() {
    try {
    // do something
    } catch (NullPointerException npe) {
    
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A catch statement should never catch throwable since it includes errors.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Catching Throwable

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Catching Throwable errors is not recommended since its scope is very broad. It includes runtime issues such as OutOfMemoryError that should be exposed and managed separately.

Example(s): 

public void bar() {
  try {
    // do something
  } catch (Throwable th) { // should not catch Throwable
    th.printStackTrace();
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Deeply nested if..then statements are hard to read.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Deeply Nested If Stmts

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid creating deeply nested if-then statements since they are harder to read and error-prone to maintain.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  public void bar(int x, int y, int z) {
    if (x > y) {
      if (y > z) {
        if (z == x) {
          // !! too deep
        }
      }
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Do not add empty strings.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Add Empty String

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The conversion of literals to strings by concatenating them with empty strings is inefficient. It is much better to use one of the type-specific toString() methods instead.

Example(s): 

String s = "" + 123; // inefficient

String t = Integer.toString(456); // preferred approach

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An instanceof check is being performed on the caught exception. Create a separate catch clause for this exception type.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Instanceof Checks In Catch Clause

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Each caught exception type should be handled in its own catch clause.

Example(s): 

try { // Avoid this
  // do something
} catch (Exception ee) {
  if (ee instanceof IOException) {
    cleanup();
  }
}

try { // Prefer this:
  // do something
} catch (IOException ee) {
  cleanup();
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using assignment operators in operands.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Assignment In Operand

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid Assignments in operands; this can make code more complicated and harder to read.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  public void bar(int x, int y, int z) {
    if ((x = y) > 6) { // assignment operator in condition
      z = 9;
    }
  }

}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The user-supplied array is stored directly.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Array Is Stored Directly

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Constructors and methods receiving arrays should clone objects and store the copy. This prevents future changes from the user from affecting the original array.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  private String [] x;
  
  public void foo (String [] param) {
    // Don't do this, make a copy of the array at least
    this.x=param;
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Each class should declare at least one constructor.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: At Least One Constructor

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid printStackTrace(); use a logger call instead.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Print Stack Trace

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid printStackTrace(); use a logger call instead.

Example(s): 

class Foo {

  void bar() {
    try {
      // do something
    } catch (Exception e) {
      e.printStackTrace();
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A catch statement that catches an exception only to rethrow it should be avoided. In cases when the rethrowed exception can be caught by catches below are allowed.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Rethrowing Exception

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Catch blocks that merely rethrow a caught exception only add to code size and runtime complexity. In cases when the rethrowed exception can be caught by following catches are allowed.

Example(s): 

public void bar() {
  try {
    / do something
  } catch (SomeException se) {
    throw se;
  }
}

public void foo(int a) throws IOException {
  try {
    if(a == 20) {
      throw new IOException();
    }
  } catch (IOException e) {
    throw e; // this is pointless
  }
}
  
  public void goo(int a) throws IOException {
    try {
      if(a == 20) {
        throw new IOException();
      } else {
        throw new Eception();
      }
    } catch(IOException e) {
      throw e; // it's OK, we don't want to catch the IOException here.
    } catch(Exception e){
    // do something
    }
  }

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid throwing null pointer exceptions.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Throwing Null Pointer Exception

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid throwing NullPointerExceptions. These are confusing because most people will assume that the virtual machine threw it. Consider using an IllegalArgumentException instead; this will be clearly seen as a programmer-initiated exception. The rule also warns on null pointer exception instantiations.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  void bar() {
    throw new NullPointerException();
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid throwing raw exception types, when you can use specialized types. The rule also warns on raw exception instantiaties.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Throwing Raw Exception Types

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid throwing certain exception types. Rather than throw a raw RuntimeException, Throwable, Exception, or Error, use a subclassed exception or error instead. The rule also warns on raw exception instantiations.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  public void bar() throws Exception {
    throw new Exception();
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A 'getX()' method which returns a boolean should be named 'isX()'.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Boolean Get Method Name

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Methods that return boolean results should be named as predicate statements to denote this. I.e, ‘isReady()’, ‘hasValues()’, ‘canCommit()’, ‘willFail()’, etc. Avoid the use of the ‘get’ prefix for these methods.

Example(s): 

public boolean getFoo(); // bad

public boolean isFoo(); // ok

public boolean getFoo(boolean bar); // ok

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid instantiating Boolean objects; reference Boolean.TRUE or Boolean.FALSE or call Boolean.valueOf() instead.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Boolean Instantiation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid instantiating Boolean objects; you can reference Boolean.TRUE, Boolean.FALSE, or call Boolean.valueOf() instead.

Example(s): 

Boolean bar = new Boolean("true"); // unnecessary creation, just reference Boolean.TRUE;

Boolean buz = Boolean.valueOf(false); // ..., just reference Boolean.FALSE;

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Don't create instances of already existing BigInteger and BigDecimal (ZERO, ONE, TEN).

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Big Integer Instantiation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Don’t create instances of already existing BigInteger (BigInteger.ZERO, BigInteger.ONE) and for Java 1.5 onwards, BigInteger.TEN and BigDecimal (BigDecimal.ZERO, BigDecimal.ONE, BigDecimal.TEN)

Example(s): 

BigInteger bi = new BigInteger(1); // reference BigInteger.ONE instead

BigInteger bi2 = new BigInteger("0"); // reference BigInteger.ZERO instead

BigInteger bi3 = new BigInteger(0.0); // reference BigInteger.ZERO instead

BigInteger bi4;

bi4 = new BigInteger(0); // reference BigInteger.ZERO instead

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid instantiating Byte objects. Call Byte.valueOf() instead.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Byte Instantiation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Calling new Byte() causes memory allocation that can be avoided by the static Byte.valueOf(). It makes use of an internal cache that recycles earlier instances making it more memory efficient.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  private Byte i = new Byte(0); // change to Byte i = Byte.valueOf(0);
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The method has greater Cyclomatic Complexity than the limit.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Cyclomatic Complexity

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Parameters of controllers endpoints should have JSR validation.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Controller endpoint parameter JSR validation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Functions in controller classes, which act as controller endpoints should have their parameters validated with JSR validation annotations, like @NotNull, @Min, @Max, etc. 


public class ExampleController {
  @GetMapping
  int getEndpointWithEntityParameter(@Valid ExampleEntity testEntity) {
    //Implementation...
  }

  @PostMapping
  public int postEndpointWithParameter(@NotNull String str) {
    //Implementation...
  }

  @RequestMapping
  public int requestEndpointMoreParameter(@Positive int db, @PositiveOrZero int count) {
    //Implementation...
  } 

  @DeleteMapping
  public int deleteEndpointMoreParameter(@Negative int num, @NegativeOrZero int num2) {
    //Implementation...
  } 

  @PutMapping
  public int putEndpointMoreParameter(@PastOrPresent Date startDate, @FutureOrPresent Date endDate) {
    //Implementation...
  } 

  @PatchMapping
  public int patchEndpointParameter(@NotNull ControllerTmp test) {
    //Implementation...
  } 
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Use equals() to compare object references.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Compare Objects With Equals

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid @Controller or @RestController annotation without @Validated annotation.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Controller @Validated annotation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Controller classes should have @Validated annotation in addition to the @Controller or @RestController annotations. 

@Validated
@Controller
public class ExamplesControllerValidated {
}

@Validated
@RestController
public class ExampleRestControllerValidated {
}

//Wrong! Do not do the following two.
@Controller
public class ControllerValidateFailed {
}

@RestController
public class RestControllerValidateFailed {
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Ensure that all resources object are closed after use.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Close Resource

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Ensure that resources (like Connection, Statement, and ResultSet objects) are always closed in a finally block after use.

Example(s): 

public class Bar {

  public void foo() {
    Connection c = pool.getConnection();
    try {
      // do stuff
    } catch (SQLException ex) {
      // handle exception
    } finally {
      // oops, should close the connection using 'close'!
      // c.close();
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The default label should be the last label in a switch statement.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Default Label Not Last In Switch Stmt

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
By convention, the default label should be the last label in a switch statement.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  void bar(int a) {
    switch (a) {
      case 1: // do something
        break;
      default: // the default case should be last, by convention
        break;
      case 2:
        break;
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Do not Call Runtime exec.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Do not Call Runtime exec

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Runtime.exec() should not be invoked.

Example(s): 

  void executeCommand(String command) {
    Process process = Runtime.getRuntime().exec(command);
    // ...
  }

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Do not Create Threads in EJB.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Do not Create Threads in EJB

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The enterprise bean must not attempt to manage threads because it would harm resource management and transaction management.

Example(s): 

@Stateless
public class Example {
  void threadExample() {
    Thread t = new Thread();
    t.run();  // never call Thread.run() in EJB
    t.start();  // never call Thread.start() in EJB
  }
  
  void runnableExample() {
    Runnable r = new Runnable() {
      public void run() {
        // ...
      }
    };
    r.run();  // never call Runnable.run() in EJB
  }
  
  void callableExample() throws Exception {
    Callable<Integer> c = new Callable<Integer>() {
      public Integer call() throws Exception {
        // ...
      }
    };
    c.call();  // never call Callable<T>.call() in EJB
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Do not Use Local Files in EJB

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Do not Use Local Files in EJB

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
java.io.Reader, java.io.InputStream, java.nio.file.Files and javax.imageio.stream.FileImageInputStream should not be used in enterprise bean to access local files.

Example(s): 

@Remote
public class Example {
  void foo() {
    Reader reader = new StringReader("input.txt");
    // ...
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Do Not Use NamedQuery Annotation

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Do Not Use NamedQuery Annotation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
NamedQuery annotations should not be used.

Example(s): 

@NamedQuery(
    name="findAllEmployee",
    queryString="SELECT * FROM Employee"
)
public class Employee {
  // ...
}


@NamedQueries({
  @NamedQuery(name="Student.findAll",
              query="SELECT s FROM Student s"),
  @NamedQuery(name="Student.findByName",
              query="SELECT s FROM Student s WHERE s.name = :name")
})
public class Student {
  // ...
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Do not Use Synchronized in EJB.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Do not Use Synchronized in EJB

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Neither method nor block level synchronization should be used in enterprise bean.

Example(s): 

@Stateless
class Example {
  
  public synchronized void foo() {
    // ...
  }

  public void goo() {
    synchronized(this) {
      // ...
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty catch blocks.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Catch Block

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty Catch Block finds instances where an exception is caught, but nothing is done, except if there is a comment in the code. In most circumstances, this swallows an exception which should either be acted on or reported.

Example(s): 

public void doSomething() {
  try {
  FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream("/tmp/bugger");
  } catch (IOException ioe) {

  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid enum member of entity class without @Enumerated annotation.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Need @Enumerated annotation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid enum members in an entity class without annotating it with the @Enumerated annotation. 


public class ExampleEntity {
  public enum TestType {
    Test1,
    Test2,
    Test3
  } 

  @Enumerated(value = EnumType.STRING)
  TestType enumMember; 

  @Enumerated(EnumType.STRING)
  TestType enumMember2; 

  //The following ones are incorrect.
  @Enumerated(value = EnumType.ORDINAL)
  TestType wrongAnnotationValue; 

  @Enumerated(value = EnumType.ORDINAL, value = EnumType.STRING)
  TestType wrongAnnotationValueNumber; 

  @Enumerated(EnumType.ORDINAL, EnumType.STRING)
  TestType wrongAnnotationValue2;

  @Enumerated
  TestType missingAnnotationValueEnumMember; 
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty finally blocks.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Finally Block

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty finally blocks serve no purpose and should be removed.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  public void bar() {
    try {
    int x=2;
    } finally {
    // empty!
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty 'if' statements.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty If Stmt

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty If Statement finds instances where a condition is checked but nothing is done about it.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  void bar(int x) {
    if (x == 0) {
    // empty!
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid @Entity annotation without equals and hashcode method.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Need equals and hashcode method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Entity classes should override both the equals and the hashcode methods inherited from the Object class. 


public class ExampleEntity {
  @Override
  public boolean equals(Object obj) {
    //Implementation...
  }

  @Override
  public int hashCode() {
    //Implementation...
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid really long methods.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Excessive Method Length

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid using equals() methods with a constant return value.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Equal Method Returns Constant

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Do not use equals() methods with a constant return value. These are potentially unfinished methods.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

@Override
public boolean equals(Object arg) {
  return true; // returns with constant
}
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Members of the entity should have JSR validation annotations.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Entity member JSR validation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The members of the entity class should have JSR validation, like @NotNull, @Min, @Max, etc.

Example(s): 


public class ExampleEntity {
  @Min(2)
  private int num;

  @Max(10)
  private int db;

  @AssertTrue
  private boolean isTest;

  @AssertFalse
  private boolean isNotTest;

  @NotEmpty
  private List labels;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid @Entity annotation without version member and annotation.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Entity optimistic locking

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid using the @Entity annotation on a class without it containing a member annotated with the @Version annotation. The type of this member should be long or Long. 


@Entity
public class T_EntityVersionSuccess {
  @Version
  private Long version;
  
  public Long getVersion() {
    return version;
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An empty method should not be overridden by another empty method.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Override Block

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Do not override an empty method with another empty method. It is useless.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  public void bar() {
  
  }
  
}

public class Child extends Foo{

  @Override
  public void bar() { // empty override block

  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty synchronized blocks.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Synchronized Block

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty synchronized blocks serve no purpose and should be removed.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  public void bar() {
    synchronized (this) {
    // empty!
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid @Entity annotation without @Validated annotation.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: @Entity and @Validated annotation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Entity classes should have a @Validated annotation in addition to the @Entity annotation. 


@Validated
@Entity
public class ExampleEntity {
  public ExampleEntity() {}
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid @Entity annotation without public default constructor.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Entity annotation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid using @Entity annotation without a public default constructor in the class. This constructor can either be compiler-generated or explicitly written.

Example(s): 


@Validated
@Entity
public class ExampleEntity {
  public ExampleEntity() {}
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty switch statements.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Switch Statements

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty switch statements serve no purpose and should be removed.

Example(s): 

public void bar() {
  int x = 2;
  switch (x) {
    // once there was code here
    // but it's been commented out or something
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty try blocks.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Try Block

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid empty try blocks - what’s the point?

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  public void bar() {
    try {
    
    } catch (Exception e) {
    e.printStackTrace();
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The @Version annotation should be on the right type.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Entity optimistic locking type

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The @Version annotation in the entity class should be used on the right type. The usable types are: int, Integer, long, Long, short, Short. We recommend using long or Long. 


public class EntityVersionRightType {

  @Version
  private Integer version; //It is OK.

  public Integer getVersion() {
    return version;
  }
} 

public class EntityVersionWrongType {

  @Version
  private String version; //Wrong! The version member should be one of the types mentioned above.

  public String getVersion() {
    return version;
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty 'while' statements.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty While Stmt

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty While Statement finds all instances where a while statement does nothing. If it is a timing loop, then you should use Thread.sleep() for it; if it is a while loop that does a lot in the condition expression (increase, decrease, assign or call a method), no warning is issued.

Example(s): 

void bar(int a, int b) {
  while (a == b) {
    // empty!
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using 'for' statements without curly braces.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: For Loops Must Use Braces

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid using ‘for’ statements without using curly braces. If the code formatting or indentation is lost then it becomes difficult to separate the code being controlled from the rest.

Example(s): 

for (int i = 0; i < 42; i++)
  foo();

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Global exception handler exist.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Global exception handler

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Global exception handler exist.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Reach fields via getter/setter functions, not by direct reference

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Hide Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Reach fields via getter/setter functions, not by direct reference.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  public int i;

}

class Bar {

  public void example() {
    Foo f = new Foo();
    int z = f.i; // should be accessed via a getter
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using 'if...else' statements without curly braces.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: If Else Stmts Must Use Braces

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid using if or if..else statements without using surrounding braces. If the code formatting or indentation is lost then it becomes difficult to separate the code being controlled from the rest.

Example(s): 

if (foo)
  x = x+1;
else
  x = x-1;

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid instantiating Integer objects. Call Integer.valueOf() instead.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Integer Instantiation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Calling new Integer() causes memory allocation that can be avoided by the static Integer.valueOf(). It makes use of an internal cache that recycles earlier instances making it more memory efficient.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  private Integer i = new Integer(0);
  // change to Integer i = Integer.valueOf(0);
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: JSR validation annotations should be used on the right type.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: JSR validation type

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The given annotation is not working properly with the type it was used on. For example, make sure you use annotations like @Min and @Max on numeric values and @AssertTrue and @AssertFalse annotations on boolean values.

Example(s): 


int getRightMinParameter(@Min(7) int id) { //It is OK, because id is an integer.
  return 1;
}

int getRightAsserTrueParameter(@AssertTrue boolean conditionValue) { //It is also OK, @AssertTrue is on a boolean value.
  return 1;
}

int getWrongMinPrimitiveType(@Min(7) boolean id) { //Wrong! The @Min annotation should be used on an integer value like above.
  return 1;
}

int getWrongAsserTruePrimitiveParameter(@AssertTrue int conditionValue) { //Wrong! The @AssertTrue annotation should be used on a boolean value.
  return 1;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Local variable could be declared final.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Local Variable Could Be Final

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid using concrete implementation types. Use its interface instead.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Loose Coupling

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid using implementation types (i.e., HashSet); use the interface (i.e, Set) instead.

Example(s): 

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.HashSet;

public class Bar {
  // Use List instead
  private ArrayList list = new ArrayList();
  
  // Use Set instead
  public HashSet getFoo() {
    return new HashSet();
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid instantiating Long objects.Call Long.valueOf() instead.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Long Instantiation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Calling new Long() causes memory allocation that can be avoided by the static Long.valueOf(). It makes use of an internal cache that recycles earlier instances making it more memory efficient.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  private Long i = new Long(0); // change to Long i = Long.valueOf(0);
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A switch statement does not contain a break.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Missing Break In Switch

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Switch statements without break, continue, throw or return statements for each case branch may indicate problematic behaviour. Empty cases are ignored as these indicate an intentional fall-through. When the case branch ends with a comment with ‘fall-through’ content are ignored as well. Missing break in the last case branch does not cause any problem so it is also ignored.

Example(s): 

public void bar(int status) {
  switch(status) {
    case CANCELLED:
      doCancelled();
      // break; hm, should this be commented out?
    case NEW:
      doNew();
      // is this really a fall-through?
    case REMOVED:
      doRemoved();
      // what happens if you add another case after this one?
    case OTHER: // empty case - this is interpreted as an intentional
      // fall-through
    case ERROR:
      doErrorHandling();
      break;
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using an object's members in toString methods without checking whether the object is null.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Missing Null Check In ToString

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid using an object’s members in toString methods without checking whether the object is null. A null check may be required to avoid NullPointerException.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  private Object o;

  @Override
  public String toString() {
    return o.toString(); // missing null check
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Classes should not have non-constructor methods with the same name as the class.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Method With Same Name As Enclosing Class

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Non-constructor methods should not have the same name as the enclosing class.

Example(s): 

public class MyClass {

  public MyClass() {} // this is OK because it is a constructor
  public void MyClass() {} // this is bad because it is a method
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method name does not begin with a lower case character.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Method Naming Conventions

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Method names should always begin with a lower case character, and should not contain underscores.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  public void fooStuff() {

  }

}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Non-constant static variable must be used in synchronized block or method.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Non Final Static Variable Must Be In Synchronized Block

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Non-constant static variable must be used in synchronized block or method.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  public static int a;

  public void bar() { // should be synchronized
    if (a == 0){
      a = 10;
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The method has greater NPath complexity than the limit.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: NPath Complexity

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Position literals first in String comparisons. Marks cases when the equals parameter is a static final String constant.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Position Literals First In Comparisons

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Position literals (or static final variables) first in comparisons, if the second argument is null then NullPointerExceptions can be avoided, they will just return false.

Example(s): 

class Foo {

  private static final String OK_BUTTON = "OK";

  boolean bar(String x) {
    return x.equals("2"); // should be "2".equals(x)
  }

  boolean isOK(String x) {
    return x.equals(OK_BUTTON); // should be OK_BUTTON.equals(x)
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Position literals first in String comparisons for EqualsIgnoreCase

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Position Literals First In Case Insensitive Comparisons

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Position literals (or static final variables) first in comparisons, if the second argument is null then NullPointerExceptions can be avoided, they will just return false.

Example(s): 

class Foo {

  private static final String OK_BUTTON = "OK";

  boolean bar(String x) {
    // should be "Bar".equalsIgnoreCase(x)
    return x.equalsIgnoreCase("Bar");
  }

  boolean isOK(String x) {
    // should be OK_BUTTON.equalsIgnoreCase(x)
    return x.equalsIgnoreCase(OK_BUTTON);
  }

}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: New exception is thrown in catch block, original stack trace may be lost.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Preserve Stack Trace

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Throwing a new exception from a catch block without passing the original exception into the new exception will cause the original stack trace to be lost making it difficult to debug effectively.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  void good() {
    try{
      Integer.parseInt("a");
    } catch (Exception e) {
      throw new Exception(e); // first possibility to create
      // exception chain
    }
    try {
      Integer.parseInt("a");
    } catch (Exception e) {
    throw (IllegalStateException)new IllegalStateException()
      .initCause(e);// second possibility to create exception chain.
    }
  }
  
  void bad() {
    try{
      Integer.parseInt("a");
    } catch (Exception e) {
      throw new Exception(e.getMessage()); // loosing the stack trace!
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The repository functions should return Optional if the return type is not a collection.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Repository function should return Optional

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The repository functions should return Optional if the return type is not a collection. 


public interface ExampleRepository() {
  ExampleEntity findByFirstName(String firstName); //Wrong! Do not do it.
  
  //Use this one instead.
  Optional findByFirstName(String firstName);

  List findAllByFirstName(String firstName);
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Consider replacing this Hashtable with the newer java.util.Map.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Replace Hashtable With Map

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Consider replacing Hashtable usage with the newer java.util.Map if thread safety is not required.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  void bar() {
    Hashtable h = new Hashtable();
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Consider replacing this Vector with the newer java.util.List.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Replace Vector With List

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Consider replacing Vector usages with the newer java.util.ArrayList if expensive thread-safe operations are not required.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  void bar() {
    Vector v = new Vector();
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: No need to check for null before an instanceof.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Simplify Conditional

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
No need to check for null before an instanceof; the instanceof keyword returns false when given a null argument.

Example(s): 

class Foo {

  void bar(Object x) {
    if (x != null && x instanceof Bar) {
      // just drop the "x != null" check
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: When instantiating a SimpleDateFormat object, specify a Locale.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Simple Date Format Needs Locale

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Be sure to specify a Locale when creating java.text.SimpleDateFormat instances to ensure that locale-appropriate formatting is used.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  // Should specify Locale.US (or whatever)
  private SimpleDateFormat sdf = new SimpleDateFormat("pattern");
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Service function with entity parameter is missing @Transactional annotation.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Service entity parameter transactional mandatory

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
If a service function has an entity as its parameter, the function should have @Transactional(Propagation.MANDATORY) annotation. 


public class ExampleService {
  @Transactional //No entity parameter, @Transactional is enough.
  public void serviceFunctionWithoutEntity(@NotBlank String str) {
  }

  @Transactional(propagation = Propagation.MANDATORY)
  public void serviceFunctionWithEntityRight(@NotBlank String str, @NotNull ExampleEntity testEntity) {
  }

  @Transactional(propagation = Propagation.MANDATORY) //There is no entity parameter so according to the rule, this is unnecessary.
  public void serviceFunctionWithEntityWrong3(@NotBlank String str, @NotEmpty List testEntityList) {
    this.privateFunctionWithParameter();
  } 
  
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Parameters of service functions should have JSR validation annotations.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Service function JSR validation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The parameters of a service function should have been validated with JSR validations like @NotNull, @Min, @Max, @NotEmpty, etc. 


public class ExampleService {
  @Transactional
  public void serviceFunctionWithValidation(@NotBlank String str, @Min(4) Integer num) {
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Service functions should have @Transactional annotation.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Service function @Transactional annotation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
If a function is used as a service function in a service class, it should be annotated with the @Transactional annotation. 


public class ExampleService {
  @Transactional
  public void serviceFunctionWithoutParameter() {
  }

  @Transactional
  public void serviceFunctionWithParameter(@NotBlank String str) {
  }

  //This is not a service function in this case, it does not need the @Transactional annotation.
  private void privatecFunctionWithoutParameter() {
    staticFunctionWithoutParameter();
  }  
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The method name and return type are suspiciously close to hashCode().

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Suspicious Hashcode Method Name

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The method name and return type are suspiciously close to hashCode(), which may denote an intention to override the hashCode() method.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  public int hashcode() { 
    // oops, this probably was
    // supposed to be 'hashCode'
  }

}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid instantiating Short objects. Call Short.valueOf() instead.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Short Instantiation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Calling new Short() causes memory allocation that can be avoided by the static Short.valueOf(). It makes use of an internal cache that recycles earlier instances making it more memory efficient.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  private Short i = new Short(0); // change to Short i = Short.valueOf(0);
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using short method names.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Short Method Name

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Method names that are very short are not helpful to the reader. Names like ‘or’, ‘in’, ‘lt’, ‘gt’, ‘eq’, ‘le’, ‘ge’, ‘ne’ are allowed.

Example(s): 

public class ShortMethod {

  public void a( int i ) { // Violation

  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A service should not use another service.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Service uses service

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A service should not use another service either as its member or as a parameter for one of its functions. 


public class AnotherService {
  //Some methods here for the service class.
}

public class ExampleService {
  private AnotherService anotherService; //Wrong! Another service as a member is not recommended.
  
  //Wrong! Another service as a parameter for a function is not recommended.
  public void serviceFuntionWithServiceParameter(@NotBlank String strParameter, @NotNull AnotherService service) {
  } 
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: System.out.print is used

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: System Println

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Printing to System.(out|err) is usually intended for debugging purposes and should not remain in the code.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  Logger log = Logger.getLogger(Foo.class.getName());

  public void testA() {

    System.out.println("Entering");

    // Better use this

    log.info("Entering");

  }

}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid @Service annotation without @Validated annotation.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Service @Validated annotation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Service classes should have both @Service and @Validated annotations. 


@Validated
@Service
public class ServiceValidation { //OK.
}

@Service
final class ServiceWithoutValidation { //@Validated annotation is missing!
}

final class ServiceValidationSimpleClass { //@Service and @Validated annotations are missing! 
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Switch statements should have a default label.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Switch Stmts Should Have Default

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
All switch statements should include a default option to catch any unspecified values.

Example(s): 

public void bar() {
  int x = 2;
  switch (x) {
  case 1: int j = 6;
  case 2: int j = 8;
    // missing default: here
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: This class has too many methods, consider refactoring it.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Too Many Methods

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A class with too many methods is probably a good suspect for refactoring, in order to reduce its complexity and find a way to have more fine grained objects.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using more than one return statements in a method.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Too Many Returns

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Do not use more than one return statement in a method. Too many return statements can make a method less understandable.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  public void bar(int x, int y, int z) { // too many returns
    if (x > y && x > z) {
      return x;
    } else if (y > x && y > z) {
      return y;
    } else {
      return z;
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Use ArrayList instead of Vector.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Array List Instead Of Vector

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
ArrayList is a much better Collection implementation than Vector if thread-safe operation is not required.

Example(s): 

public class SimpleTest extends TestCase {

  public void testX() {
    Collection c1 = new Vector();
    Collection c2 = new ArrayList(); // achieves the same
    // with much better performance
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Document empty method.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Uncommented Empty Method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Uncommented Empty Method finds instances where a method does not contain statements, but there is no comment. By explicitly commenting empty methods it is easier to distinguish between intentional (commented) and unintentional empty methods.

Example(s): 

public void doSomething() {

}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Use equals() to compare strings instead of ''=='' or ''!=''.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Equals To Compare Strings

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Using ‘==’ or ‘!=’ to compare strings only works if intern version is used on both sides. Use the equals() method instead.

Example(s): 

public boolean test(String s) {
  if (s == "one") return true; // unreliable
  if ("two".equals(s)) return true; // better
  return false;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Consider simply returning the value vs storing it in a local variable.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unnecessary Local Before Return

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Consider simply returning the value vs storing it in a local variable.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  public int foo() {
    int x = doSomething();
    return x; // instead, just 'return doSomething();'
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid unused local variables.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unused Local Variable

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Detects when a local variable is just declared, but not used.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  public void doSomething() {
    int i = 5; // Unused
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: When doing a String.toLowerCase()/toUpperCase() call, use a Locale.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Locale With Case Conversions

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
When doing String.toLowerCase()/toUpperCase() conversions, use Locales to avoid problems with languages that have unusual conventions, i.e. Turkish.

Example(s): 

class Foo {
  // BAD
  if (x.toLowerCase().equals("list"))...
  // This will not match "LIST" when in Turkish locale
  // The above could be
  // if (x.toLowerCase(Locale.US).equals("list")) ...
  // or simply
  // if (x.equalsIgnoreCase("list")) ...
  // GOOD

  String z = a.toLowerCase(Locale.EN);
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Overriding method merely calls super

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Useless Overriding Method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The overriding method merely calls the same method defined in a superclass.

Example(s): 

public void foo(String bar) {
  super.foo(bar); // why bother overriding?
}

public String foo() {
  return super.foo(); // why bother overriding?
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid unused private fields.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unused Private Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Detects when a private field is just declared, but not used.

Example(s): 

public class Something {

  private static int FOO = 2; // Unused
  private int i = 5; // Unused
  private int j = 6;
  
  public int addOne() {
    return j++;
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid unused private methods.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unused Private Method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Unused Private Method: Unused Private Method detects when a private method is declared but is unused.

Example(s): 

  public class Something {
    private void foo() {} // unused
  }

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Prefer StringBuffer over += for concatenating strings.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use String Buffer For String Appends

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The use of the ‘+=’ operator for appending strings causes the JVM to create and use an internal StringBuffer. If a non-trivial number of these concatenations are being used then the explicit use of a StringBuilder or threadsafe StringBuffer is recommended to avoid this.

Example(s): 

public class Foo {

  void bar() {
    String a;
    a = "foo";
    a += " bar";
    // better would be:
    // StringBuilder a = new StringBuilder("foo");
    // a.append(" bar");
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid unused imports.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unused Imports

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid unused import statements. This rule will find unused on demand imports, i.e. import com.foo.*

Example(s): 

import java.io.*; // not referenced or required

public class Foo {}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Useless parentheses.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Useless Parentheses

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid using 'while' statements without curly braces.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: While Loops Must Use Braces

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid using ‘while’ statements without using braces to surround the code block. If the code formatting or indentation is lost then it becomes difficult to separate the code being controlled from the rest.

Example(s): 

while (true) // not recommended
  x++;
while (true) { // preferred approach
  x++;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method: Halstead Calculated Program Length

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Halstead Calculated Program Length

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Method:

  • n1: number of distinct operators (semantic meanings of the reserved keywords, semicolons, blocks, and identifiers except in their declarations)
  • n2: number of distinct operands (literals - e.g. character, string, and integer literals, - and the identifiers in their declarations)

The calculated program length is n1 * log2(n1) + n2 * log2(n2).

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: HCPL warning

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Threshold warning for 'HCPL' metrics of the 'Method' entities.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method: Halstead Difficulty

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Halstead Difficulty

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Method:

  • n1: number of distinct operators (semantic meanings of the reserved keywords, semicolons, blocks, and identifiers except in their declarations)
  • n2: number of distinct operands (literals - e.g. character, string, and integer literals, - and the identifiers in their declarations)
  • N2: total number of operands

The Halstead difficulty is n1/2 * N2/n2.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: HDIF warning

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Threshold warning for 'HDIF' metrics of the 'Method' entities.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method: Halstead Effort

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Halstead Effort

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Method:

  • n1: number of distinct operators (semantic meanings of the reserved keywords, semicolons, blocks, and identifiers except in their declarations)
  • n2: number of distinct operands (literals - e.g. character, string, and integer literals, - and the identifiers in their declarations)
  • N1: total number of operators
  • N2: total number of operands
  • n : n1 + n2 (program vocabulary)
  • N : N1 + N2 (program length)
  • V : N * log2(n) (volume)
  • D : n1/2 * N2/n2 (difficulty)

The Halstead effort is D * V.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class: number of functionalities of the class. One of the basic principles of object-oriented programming is encapsulation, meaning that attributes belonging together and the operations that use them should be organized into one class, and one class shall implement only one functionality, i.e. its attributes and methods should be coherent. This metric measures the lack of cohesion and computes into how many coherent classes the class could be split. It is calculated by taking a non-directed graph, where the nodes are the implemented local methods of the class and there is an edge between the two nodes if and only if a common (local or inherited) attribute or abstract method is used or a method invokes another. The value of the metric is the number of connected components in the graph not counting those, which contain only constructors, destructors, getters, or setters.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Lack of Cohesion in Methods 5

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Class: number of functionalities of the class. One of the basic principles of object-oriented programming is encapsulation, meaning that attributes belonging together and the operations that use them should be organized into one class, and one class shall implement only one functionality, i.e. its attributes and methods should be coherent. This metric measures the lack of cohesion and computes into how many coherent classes the class could be split. It is calculated by taking a non-directed graph, where the nodes are the implemented local methods of the class and there is an edge between the two nodes if and only if a common (local or inherited) attribute or abstract method is used or a method invokes another. The value of the metric is the number of connected components in the graph not counting those, which contain only constructors, destructors, getters, or setters.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Maintainability Index (Original version)

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
• HVOL: Halstead Volume
  • McCC: McCabe’s cyclomatic complexity
  • LLOC: logical lines of code

The original Maintainability Index is computed by the following formula:

MI = 171 - 5.2 * ln(HVOL) - 0.23 * (McCC) - 16.2 * ln(LLOC)

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Maintainability Index (Microsoft version)

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
• HVOL: Halstead Volume
  • McCC: McCabe’s cyclomatic complexity
  • LLOC: logical lines of code

The Maintainability Index used by Microsoft’s Visual Studio is computed by the following formula:

MIMS = max(0,(171 - 5.2 * ln(HVOL) - 0.23 * (McCC) - 16.2 * ln(LLOC)) * 100 / 171)

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: MIMS warning

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Threshold warning for 'MIMS' metrics of the 'Method' entities.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Maintainability Index (SEI version)

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
• HVOL: Halstead Volume
  • McCC: McCabe’s cyclomatic complexity
  • LLOC: logical lines of code
  • CD: comment density

The Maintainability Index derived by the Software Engineering Institute (SEI) is computed by the following formula:

MISEI = 171 - 5.2 * log2(HVOL) - 0.23 * McCC - 16.2 * log2(LLOC) + 50 * sin(sqrt(2.4 * CD))

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: MISEI warning

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Threshold warning for 'MISEI' metrics of the 'Method' entities.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Maintainability Index (SourceMeter version)

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
• HVOL: Halstead Volume
  • McCC: McCabe’s cyclomatic complexity
  • LLOC: logical lines of code
  • CD: comment density

The Maintainability Index proposed by SourceMeter combines the different scaling approach from Microsoft’s version with the inclusion of comment percentage from the Software Engineering Institute (SEI) version into the following formula:

MISM = max(0, (171 - 5.2 * log2(HVOL) - 0.23 * McCC - 16.2 * log2(LLOC) + 50 * sin(sqrt(2.4 * CD))) * 100 / 171)

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Method: complexity of the method expressed as the number of independent control flow paths in it. It represents a lower bound for the number of possible execution paths in the source code and at the same time it is an upper bound for the minimum number of test cases needed for achieving full branch test coverage. The value of the metric is calculated as the number of the following instructions plus 1: if, for, foreach, while, do-while, case label (which belongs to a switch instruction), catch, conditional statement (?:). Moreover, logical "and" (&&) and logical "or" (||) expressions also add 1 to the value because their short-circuit evaluation can cause branching depending on the first operand. The following instructions are not included: else, switch, default label (which belongs to a switch instruction), try, finally.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: McCabe's Cyclomatic Complexity

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Method: complexity of the method expressed as the number of independent control flow paths in it. It represents a lower bound for the number of possible execution paths in the source code and at the same time it is an upper bound for the minimum number of test cases needed for achieving full branch test coverage. The value of the metric is calculated as the number of the following instructions plus 1: if, for, foreach, while, do-while, case label (which belongs to a switch instruction), catch, conditional statement (?:). Moreover, logical “and” (&&) and logical “or” (||) expressions also add 1 to the value because their short-circuit evaluation can cause branching depending on the first operand. The following instructions are not included: else, switch, default label (which belongs to a switch instruction), try, finally.

File: complexity of the file expressed as the number of independent control flow paths in it. It is calculated as the sum of the McCabe’s Cyclomatic Complexity values of the methods can be found in the file.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value:
Method: complexity of the method expressed as the depth of the maximum embeddedness of its conditional and iteration block scopes. The following instructions are taken into account: if, for, while, do-while, switch, conditional statement (?:). The following instructions do not increase the value by themselves; however, if additional embeddednesses can be found in their blocks, they are considered: else, case and default label (which belong to a switch instruction), try, catch, finally.
Class: complexity of the class expressed as the depth of the maximum embeddedness of its conditional and iteration block scopes. It is calculated as the maximum nesting level (NL) of its local methods and init blocks.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Nesting Level

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Method: complexity of the method expressed as the depth of the maximum embeddedness of its conditional, iteration and exception handling block scopes. The following instructions are taken into account: if, else-if, else, for, while, do-while, switch, try, catch, finally and block statements that are directly inside another block statement. The following instructions do not increase the value by themselves; however, if additional embeddednesses can be found in their blocks, they are considered: case and default label (which belong to a switch instruction).

Class: complexity of the class expressed as the depth of the maximum embeddedness of its conditional, iteration and exception handling block scopes. It is calculated as the maximum nesting level (NL) of its local methods and init blocks.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value:
Method: complexity of the method expressed as the depth of the maximum embeddedness of its conditional and iteration block scopes, where in the if-else-if construct only the first if instruction is considered. The following instructions are taken into account: if, for, while, do-while, switch, conditional statement (?:). The following instructions do not increase the value by themselves; however, if additional embeddednesses can be found in their blocks, they are considered: else, else if (i.e. in the if-else-if construct the use of else-if does not increase the value of the metric), case and default label (which belong to a switch instruction), try, catch, finally.
Class: complexity of the class expressed as the depth of the maximum embeddedness of its conditional and iteration block scopes, where in the if-else-if construct only the first if instruction is considered. It is calculated as the maximum nesting level (NLE) of its local methods and init blocks.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Nesting Level Else-If

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Method: complexity of the method expressed as the depth of the maximum embeddedness of its conditional, iteration and exception handling block scopes, where in the if-else-if construct only the first if instruction is considered. The following instructions are taken into account: if, else, for, while, do-while, switch, try, catch, finally and block statements that are directly inside another block statement. The following instructions do not increase the value by themselves; however, if additional embeddednesses can be found in their blocks, they are considered: else-if (i.e. in the if-else-if construct the use of else-if does not increase the value of the metric), case and default label (which belong to a switch instruction).

Class: complexity of the class expressed as the depth of the maximum embeddedness of its conditional, iteration and exception handling block scopes, where in the if-else-if construct only the first if instruction is considered. It is calculated as the maximum nesting level (NLE) of its local methods and init blocks.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: You should not modify visibility of class or methods using getDeclaredConstructors(), getDeclaredConstructor(Class[]), setAccessible() or PrivilegedAction.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Accessibility Alteration

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Methods such as getDeclaredConstructors(), getDeclaredConstructor(Class[]) and setAccessible(), as the interface PrivilegedAction, allow for the runtime alteration of variable, class, or method visibility, even if they are private. This violates the principle of encapsulation.

Example(s):

import java.lang.reflect.AccessibleObject;
import java.lang.reflect.Method;
import java.security.PrivilegedAction;

public class Violation {
  public void invalidCallsInMethod() throws SecurityException, NoSuchMethodException {
    // Possible call to forbidden getDeclaredConstructors
    Class[] arrayOfClass = new Class[1];
    this.getClass().getDeclaredConstructors();
    this.getClass().getDeclaredConstructor(arrayOfClass);
    Class clazz = this.getClass();
    clazz.getDeclaredConstructor(arrayOfClass);
    clazz.getDeclaredConstructors();
      // Possible call to forbidden setAccessible
    clazz.getMethod("", arrayOfClass).setAccessible(false);
    AccessibleObject.setAccessible(null, false);
    Method.setAccessible(null, false);
    Method[] methodsArray = clazz.getMethods();
    int nbMethod;
    for ( nbMethod = 0; nbMethod < methodsArray.length; nbMethod++ ) {
      methodsArray[nbMethod].setAccessible(false);
    }

      // Possible call to forbidden PrivilegedAction
    PrivilegedAction priv = (PrivilegedAction) new Object(); priv.run();
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using assert as an identifier; it became a reserved word in JDK 1.4

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Assert As Identifier

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: System.arraycopy is more efficient

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Array Loops

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Instead of manually copying data between two arrays, use the efficient Arrays.copyOf or System.arraycopy method instead.

Example(s):

public class Test {
    public void bar() {
        int[] a = new int[10];
        int[] b = new int[10];
        for (int i=0;i<10;i++) {
            b[i]=a[i];
        }

        int[] c = new int[10];
        // this will trigger the rule
        for (int i=0;i<10;i++) {
            b[i]=a[c[i]];
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using a branching statement as the last in a loop.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Branching Statement As Last In Loop

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Using a branching statement as the last part of a loop may be a bug, and/or is confusing. Ensure that the usage is not a bug, or consider using another approach.

Example(s):

// unusual use of branching statement in a loop
for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
    if (i*i <= 25) {
        continue;
    }
    break;
}

// this makes more sense...
for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {
    if (i*i > 25) {
        break;
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A Calendar is used to create a Date or DateTime, this is expensive.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Calendar Date Creation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Problem: A Calendar is a heavyweight object and expensive to create.

Solution: Use new Date(), Java 8+ java.time.LocalDateTime.now() or ZonedDateTime.now().

Example(s):

import java.time.LocalDateTime;
import java.util.Calendar;
import java.util.Date;

public class DateStuff {
    private Date bad1() {
        return Calendar.getInstance().getTime(); // now
    }
    private Date good1a() {
        return new Date(); // now
    }
    private LocalDateTime good1b() {
        return LocalDateTime.now();
    }
    private long bad2() {
        return Calendar.getInstance().getTimeInMillis();
    }
    private long good2() {
        return System.currentTimeMillis();
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid calling finalize() explicitly

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Calling Finalize

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The method Object.finalize() is called by the garbage collector on an object when garbage collection determines that there are no more references to the object. It should not be invoked by application logic.

Note that Oracle has declared Object.finalize() as deprecated since JDK 9.

Example(s):

void foo() {
    Bar b = new Bar();
    b.finalize();
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid instantiation through private constructors from outside of the constructor's class.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Accessor Class Generation

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid catching generic exceptions such as NullPointerException, RuntimeException, Exception in try-catch block

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Catching Generic Exception

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid catching generic exceptions such as NullPointerException, RuntimeException, Exception in try-catch block

Example(s):

package com.igate.primitive;

public class PrimitiveType {

    public void downCastPrimitiveType() {
        try {
            System.out.println(" i [" + i + "]");
        } catch(Exception e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        } catch(RuntimeException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        } catch(NullPointerException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid catching NullPointerException; consider removing the cause of the NPE.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Catching NPE

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Code should never throw NullPointerExceptions under normal circumstances. A catch block may hide the original error, causing other, more subtle problems later on.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    void bar() {
        try {
            // do something
        } catch (NullPointerException npe) {
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A catch statement should never catch throwable since it includes errors.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Catching Throwable

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Catching Throwable errors is not recommended since its scope is very broad. It includes runtime issues such as OutOfMemoryError that should be exposed and managed separately.

Example(s):

public void bar() {
    try {
        // do something
    } catch (Throwable th) {  // should not catch Throwable
        th.printStackTrace();
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: This abstract class does not have any abstract methods

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Abstract Class Without Abstract Method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The abstract class does not contain any abstract methods. An abstract class suggests an incomplete implementation, which is to be completed by subclasses implementing the abstract methods. If the class is intended to be used as a base class only (not to be instantiated directly) a protected constructor can be provided prevent direct instantiation.

Example(s):

public abstract class Foo {
  void int method1() { ... }
  void int method2() { ... }
  // consider using abstract methods or removing
  // the abstract modifier and adding protected constructors
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid appending characters as strings in StringBuffer.append.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Append Character With Char

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid concatenating characters as strings in StringBuffer/StringBuilder.append methods.
Example(s):
```java StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer(); sb.append("a"); // avoid this
StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer(); sb.append('a'); // use this instead ```

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The String literal {0} appears {1} times in this file; the first occurrence is on line {2}

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Duplicate Literals

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Code containing duplicate String literals can usually be improved by declaring the String as a constant field.

Example(s):

private void bar() {
     buz("Howdy");
     buz("Howdy");
     buz("Howdy");
     buz("Howdy");
}
private void buz(String x) {}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid creating BigDecimal with a decimal (float/double) literal. Use a String literal

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Decimal Literals In Big Decimal Constructor

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
One might assume that the result of “new BigDecimal(0.1)” is exactly equal to 0.1, but it is actually equal to .1000000000000000055511151231257827021181583404541015625. This is because 0.1 cannot be represented exactly as a double (or as a binary fraction of any finite length). Thus, the long value that is being passed in to the constructor is not exactly equal to 0.1, appearances notwithstanding.

The (String) constructor, on the other hand, is perfectly predictable: ‘new BigDecimal(“0.1”)’ is exactly equal to 0.1, as one would expect. Therefore, it is generally recommended that the (String) constructor be used in preference to this one.

Example(s):

BigDecimal bd = new BigDecimal(1.123);       // loss of precision, this would trigger the rule

BigDecimal bd = new BigDecimal("1.123");     // preferred approach

BigDecimal bd = new BigDecimal(12);          // preferred approach, ok for integer values

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Deeply nested if..then statements are hard to read

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Deeply Nested If Stmts

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid using dollar signs in variable/method/class/interface names

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Dollar Signs

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid using dollar signs in variable/method/class/interface names.

Example(s):

public class Fo$o {  // not a recommended name
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using enum as an identifier; it's a reserved word in JDK 1.5

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Enum As Identifier

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Do not add empty strings

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Add Empty String

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The conversion of literals to strings by concatenating them with empty strings is inefficient. It is much better to use one of the type-specific toString() methods instead.

Example(s):

String s = "" + 123;                // inefficient
String t = Integer.toString(456);   // preferred approach

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using final local variables, turn them into fields

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Final Local Variable

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid using final local variables, turn them into fields.
Note that this is a controversial rule which is merely useful to enforce a certain code style (which is contradictory to good coding practices in most of the cases it's applied to) and avoid local literals being declared in a scope smaller than the class.
Also note, that this rule is the opposite of {% rule "java/codestyle/LocalVariableCouldBeFinal" %}. Having both rules enabled results in contradictory violations being reported.
This rule is deprecated and will be removed with PMD 7.0.0. There is no replacement planned. If the goal is to avoid defining constants in a scope smaller than the class, then the rule {% rule "java/errorprone/AvoidDuplicateLiterals" %} should be used instead.
Example(s):
```java public class MyClass { public void foo() { final String finalLocalVariable; } } ```

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Field {0} has the same name as a method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Field Name Matching Method Name

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
It can be confusing to have a field name with the same name as a method. While this is permitted, having information (field) and actions (method) is not clear naming. Developers versed in Smalltalk often prefer this approach as the methods denote accessor methods.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    Object bar;
    // bar is data or an action or both?
    void bar() {
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: It is somewhat confusing to have a field name matching the declaring class name

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Field Name Matching Type Name

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
It is somewhat confusing to have a field name matching the declaring class name. This probably means that type and/or field names should be chosen more carefully.

Example(s):

public class Foo extends Bar {
    int foo;    // There is probably a better name that can be used
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid instantiating FileInputStream, FileOutputStream, FileReader, or FileWriter

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid File Stream

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The FileInputStream and FileOutputStream classes contains a finalizer method which will cause garbage collection pauses. See JDK-8080225 for details.

The FileReader and FileWriter constructors instantiate FileInputStream and FileOutputStream, again causing garbage collection issues while finalizer methods are called.

  • Use Files.newInputStream(Paths.get(fileName)) instead of new FileInputStream(fileName).
  • Use Files.newOutputStream(Paths.get(fileName)) instead of new FileOutputStream(fileName).
  • Use Files.newBufferedReader(Paths.get(fileName)) instead of new FileReader(fileName).
  • Use Files.newBufferedWriter(Paths.get(fileName)) instead of new FileWriter(fileName).

Please note, that the java.nio API does not throw a FileNotFoundException anymore, instead it throws a NoSuchFileException. If your code dealt explicitly with a FileNotFoundException, then this needs to be adjusted. Both exceptions are subclasses of IOException, so catching that one covers both.

Example(s):

// these instantiations cause garbage collection pauses, even if properly closed

    FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream(fileName);
    FileOutputStream fos = new FileOutputStream(fileName);
    FileReader fr = new FileReader(fileName);
    FileWriter fw = new FileWriter(fileName);

    // the following instantiations help prevent Garbage Collection pauses, no finalization

    try(InputStream is = Files.newInputStream(Paths.get(fileName))) {
    }
    try(OutputStream os = Files.newOutputStream(Paths.get(fileName))) {
    }
    try(BufferedReader br = Files.newBufferedReader(Paths.get(fileName), StandardCharsets.UTF_8)) {
    }
    try(BufferedWriter wr = Files.newBufferedWriter(Paths.get(fileName), StandardCharsets.UTF_8)) {
    }

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An instanceof check is being performed on the caught exception. Create a separate catch clause for this exception type.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Instanceof Checks In Catch Clause

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Each caught exception type should be handled in its own catch clause.

Example(s):

try { // Avoid this
    // do something
} catch (Exception ee) {
    if (ee instanceof IOException) {
        cleanup();
    }
}

try {  // Prefer this:
    // do something
} catch (IOException ee) {
    cleanup();
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid assignments in operands

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Assignment In Operand

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid assignments in operands; this can make code more complicated and harder to read.

Example(s):

public void bar() {
    int x = 2;
    if ((x = getX()) == 3) {
      System.out.println("3!");
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
