attribute.value: Avoid instantiating new objects inside loops

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Instantiating Objects In Loops

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: The user-supplied array ''{0}'' is stored directly.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Array Is Stored Directly

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Constructors and methods receiving arrays should clone objects and store the copy. This prevents future changes from the user from affecting the original array.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    private String [] x;
        public void foo (String [] param) {
        // Don't do this, make a copy of the array at least
        this.x=param;
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid statements in a catch block that invoke accessors on the exception without using the information

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Losing Exception Information

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Statements in a catch block that invoke accessors on the exception without using the information only add to code size. Either remove the invocation, or use the return result.

Example(s):

public void bar() {
    try {
        // do something
    } catch (SomeException se) {
        se.getMessage();
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using Literals in Conditional Statements

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Literals In If Condition

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Each class should declare at least one constructor

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: At Least One Constructor

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: You shouldn't declare field of MessageDigest type, because unsynchronized access could cause problems

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Message Digest Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Declaring a MessageDigest instance as a field make this instance directly available to multiple threads. Such sharing of MessageDigest instances should be avoided if possible since it leads to wrong results if the access is not synchronized correctly. Just create a new instance and use it locally, where you need it. Creating a new instance is easier than synchronizing access to a shared instance.

Example(s):

import java.security.MessageDigest;
public class AvoidMessageDigestFieldExample {
    private final MessageDigest sharedMd;
    public AvoidMessageDigestFieldExample() throws Exception {
        sharedMd = MessageDigest.getInstance("SHA-256");
    }
    public byte[] calculateHashShared(byte[] data) {
        // sharing a MessageDigest like this without synchronizing access
        // might lead to wrong results
        sharedMd.reset();
        sharedMd.update(data);
        return sharedMd.digest();
    }

    // better
    public byte[] calculateHash(byte[] data) throws Exception {
        MessageDigest md = MessageDigest.getInstance("SHA-256");
        md.update(data);
        return md.digest();
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid autogenerated methods to access private fields and methods of inner / outer classes

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Accessor Method Generation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
When accessing private fields / methods from another class, the Java compiler will generate accessor methods with package-private visibility. This adds overhead, and to the dex method count on Android. This situation can be avoided by changing the visibility of the field / method from private to package-private.

Example(s):

public class OuterClass {
    private int counter;
    /* package */ int id;

    public class InnerClass {
        InnerClass() {
            OuterClass.this.counter++; // wrong accessor method will be generated
        }

        public int getOuterClassId() {
            return OuterClass.this.id; // id is package-private, no accessor method needed
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Using multiple unary operators may be a bug, and/or is confusing.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Multiple Unary Operators

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The use of multiple unary operators may be problematic, and/or confusing. Ensure that the intended usage is not a bug, or consider simplifying the expression.

Example(s):

// These are typo bugs, or at best needlessly complex and confusing:
int i = - -1;
int j = + - +1;
int z = ~~2;
boolean b = !!true;
boolean c = !!!true;

// These are better:
int i = 1;
int j = -1;
int z = 2;
boolean b = true;
boolean c = false;

// And these just make your brain hurt:
int i = ~-2;
int j = -~7;

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Abstract classes should be named 'AbstractXXX'

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Abstract Naming

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Abstract classes should be named 'AbstractXXX'.
This rule is deprecated and will be removed with PMD 7.0.0. The rule is replaced by [Class Naming Conventions](#PMD_CNC).
Example(s):
```java public abstract class Foo { // should be AbstractFoo } ```

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid protected fields in a final class. Change to private or package access.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Protected Field In Final Class

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Do not use protected fields in final classes since they cannot be subclassed. Clarify your intent by using private or package access modifiers instead.

Example(s):

public final class Bar {
  private int x;
  protected int y;  // bar cannot be subclassed, so is y really private or package visible?
  Bar() {}
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid protected methods in a final class that doesn't extend anything other than Object. Change to private or package access.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Protected Method In Final Class Not Extending

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Do not use protected methods in most final classes since they cannot be subclassed. This should only be allowed in final classes that extend other classes with protected methods (whose visibility cannot be reduced). Clarify your intent by using private or package access modifiers instead.

Example(s):

public final class Foo {
  private int bar() {}
  protected int baz() {} // Foo cannot be subclassed, and doesn't extend anything, so is baz() really private or package visible?
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid prefixing parameters by in, out or inOut. Uses Javadoc to document this behavior.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Prefixing Method Parameters

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Prefixing parameters by ‘in’ or ‘out’ pollutes the name of the parameters and reduces code readability. To indicate whether or not a parameter will be modify in a method, its better to document method behavior with Javadoc.

This rule is deprecated and will be removed with PMD 7.0.0. The rule is replaced by the more general rule Formal Parameter Naming Conventions.

Example(s):

// Not really clear
public class Foo {
  public void bar(
      int inLeftOperand,
      Result outRightOperand) {
      outRightOperand.setValue(inLeftOperand * outRightOperand.getValue());
  }
}
// Far more useful
public class Foo {
  /**
   *
   * @param leftOperand, (purpose), not modified by method.
   * @param rightOperand (purpose), will be modified by the method: contains the result.
   */
  public void bar(
        int leftOperand,
        Result rightOperand) {
        rightOperand.setValue(leftOperand * rightOperand.getValue());
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid printStackTrace(); use a logger call instead.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Print Stack Trace

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid printStackTrace(); use a logger call instead.

Example(s):

class Foo {
    void bar() {
        try {
            // do something
        } catch (Exception e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid reassigning caught exception ''{0}''

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Reassigning Catch Variables

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Reassigning exception variables caught in a catch statement should be avoided because of:

  1. If it is needed, multi catch can be easily added and code will still compile.

  2. Following the principle of least surprise we want to make sure that a variable caught in a catch statement is always the one thrown in a try block.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    public void foo() {
        try {
            // do something
        } catch (Exception e) {
            e = new NullPointerException(); // not recommended
        }

        try {
            // do something
        } catch (MyException | ServerException e) {
            e = new RuntimeException(); // won't compile
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A catch statement that catches an exception only to rethrow it should be avoided.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Rethrowing Exception

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Catch blocks that merely rethrow a caught exception only add to code size and runtime complexity.

Example(s):

public void bar() {
    try {
        // do something
    }  catch (SomeException se) {
       throw se;
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid reassigning the loop control variable ''{0}''

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Reassigning Loop Variables

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Reassigning loop variables can lead to hard-to-find bugs. Prevent or limit how these variables can be changed.

In foreach-loops, configured by the foreachReassign property: - deny: Report any reassignment of the loop variable in the loop body. This is the default. - allow: Don’t check the loop variable. - firstOnly: Report any reassignments of the loop variable, except as the first statement in the loop body. This is useful if some kind of normalization or clean-up of the value before using is permitted, but any other change of the variable is not.

In for-loops, configured by the forReassign property: - deny: Report any reassignment of the control variable in the loop body. This is the default. - allow: Don’t check the control variable. - skip: Report any reassignments of the control variable, except conditional increments/decrements (++, --, +=, -=). This prevents accidental reassignments or unconditional increments of the control variable.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  private void foo() {
    for (String s : listOfStrings()) {
      s = s.trim(); // OK, when foreachReassign is "firstOnly" or "allow"
      doSomethingWith(s);

      s = s.toUpper(); // OK, when foreachReassign is "allow"
      doSomethingElseWith(s);
    }

    for (int i=0; i < 10; i++) {
      if (check(i)) {
        i++; // OK, when forReassign is "skip" or "allow"
      }

      i = 5;  // OK, when forReassign is "allow"

      doSomethingWith(i);
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid reassigning parameters such as ''{0}''

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Reassigning Parameters

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Reassigning values to incoming parameters is not recommended. Use temporary local variables instead.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  private void foo(String bar) {
    bar = "something else";
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Use block level rather than method level synchronization

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Synchronized At Method Level

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Method-level synchronization can cause problems when new code is added to the method. Block-level synchronization helps to ensure that only the code that needs synchronization gets it.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    // Try to avoid this:
    synchronized void foo() {
        // code, that doesn't need synchronization
        // ...
        // code, that requires synchronization
        if (!sharedData.has("bar")) {
            sharedData.add("bar");
        }
        // more code, that doesn't need synchronization
        // ...
    }
    // Prefer this:
    void bar() {
        // code, that doesn't need synchronization
        // ...
        synchronized(this) {
            if (!sharedData.has("bar")) {
                sharedData.add("bar");
            }
        }
        // more code, that doesn't need synchronization
        // ...
    }

    // Try to avoid this for static methods:
    static synchronized void fooStatic() {
    }

    // Prefer this:
    static void barStatic() {
        // code, that doesn't need synchronization
        // ...
        synchronized(Foo.class) {
            // code, that requires synchronization
        }
        // more code, that doesn't need synchronization
        // ...
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: StringBuffers can grow quite a lot, and so may become a source of memory leak (if the owning class has a long life time).

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid String Buffer Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
StringBuffers/StringBuilders can grow considerably, and so may become a source of memory leaks if held within objects with long lifetimes.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    private StringBuffer buffer;    // potential memory leak as an instance variable;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using java.lang.ThreadGroup; it is not thread safe

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Thread Group

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid using java.lang.ThreadGroup; although it is intended to be used in a threaded environment it contains methods that are not thread-safe.

Example(s):

public class Bar {
    void buz() {
        ThreadGroup tg = new ThreadGroup("My threadgroup");
        tg = new ThreadGroup(tg, "my thread group");
        tg = Thread.currentThread().getThreadGroup();
        tg = System.getSecurityManager().getThreadGroup();
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Possible unsafe assignment to a non-final static field in a constructor.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Assignment To Non Final Static

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Identifies a possible unsafe usage of a static field.

Example(s):

public class StaticField {
   static int x;
   public FinalFields(int y) {
    x = y; // unsafe
   }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A catch statement that catches an exception only to wrap it in a new instance of the same type of exception and throw it should be avoided

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Throwing New Instance Of Same Exception

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Catch blocks that merely rethrow a caught exception wrapped inside a new instance of the same type only add to code size and runtime complexity.

Example(s):

public void bar() {
    try {
        // do something
    } catch (SomeException se) {
        // harmless comment
        throw new SomeException(se);
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid throwing null pointer exceptions.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Throwing Null Pointer Exception

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid throwing NullPointerExceptions manually. These are confusing because most people will assume that the virtual machine threw it. To avoid a method being called with a null parameter, you may consider using an IllegalArgumentException instead, making it clearly seen as a programmer-initiated exception. However, there are better ways to handle this:

Effective Java, 3rd Edition, Item 72: Favor the use of standard exceptions

Arguably, every erroneous method invocation boils down to an illegal argument or state, but other exceptions are standardly used for certain kinds of illegal arguments and states. If a caller passes null in some parameter for which null values are prohibited, convention dictates that NullPointerException be thrown rather than IllegalArgumentException.

To implement that, you are encouraged to use java.util.Objects.requireNonNull() (introduced in Java 1.7). This method is designed primarily for doing parameter validation in methods and constructors with multiple parameters.

Your parameter validation could thus look like the following:

public class Foo {
    private String exampleValue;

    void setExampleValue(String exampleValue) {
      // check, throw and assignment in a single standard call
      this.exampleValue = Objects.requireNonNull(exampleValue, "exampleValue must not be null!");
    }
  }

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    void bar() {
        throw new NullPointerException();
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid throwing raw exception types.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Throwing Raw Exception Types

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid throwing certain exception types. Rather than throw a raw RuntimeException, Throwable, Exception, or Error, use a subclassed exception or error instead.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    public void bar() throws Exception {
        throw new Exception();
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A method or constructor should not explicitly declare unchecked exceptions in its ''throws'' clause

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Unchecked Exceptions In Signatures

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A method or constructor should not explicitly declare unchecked exceptions in its throws clause. Java doesn’t force the caller to handle an unchecked exception, so it’s unnecessary except for documentation. A better practice is to document the exceptional cases with a @throws Javadoc tag, which allows being more descriptive.

Example(s):

public void foo() throws RuntimeException {
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Do not hard code the IP address ${variableName}

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Using Hard Coded IP

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Application with hard-coded IP addresses can become impossible to deploy in some cases. Externalizing IP adresses is preferable.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    private String ip = "127.0.0.1";     // not recommended
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The use of native code is not recommended.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Using Native Code

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Unnecessary reliance on Java Native Interface (JNI) calls directly reduces application portability and increases the maintenance burden.

Example(s):

public class SomeJNIClass {

     public SomeJNIClass() {
         System.loadLibrary("nativelib");
     }

     static {
         System.loadLibrary("nativelib");
     }

     public void invalidCallsInMethod() throws SecurityException, NoSuchMethodException {
         System.loadLibrary("nativelib");
     }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Do not start a literal by 0 unless it's an octal value

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Using Octal Values

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Integer literals should not start with zero since this denotes that the rest of literal will be interpreted as an octal value.

Example(s):

int i = 012;    // set i with 10 not 12
int j = 010;    // set j with 8 not 10
k = i * j;      // set k with 80 not 120

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Do not use the short type

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Using Short Type

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Use of modifier volatile is not recommended.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Avoid Using Volatile

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Use of the keyword 'volatile' is generally used to fine tune a Java application, and therefore, requires a good expertise of the Java Memory Model. Moreover, its range of action is somewhat misknown. Therefore, the volatile keyword should not be used for maintenance purpose and portability.
Example(s):
```java public class ThrDeux { private volatile String var1; // not suggested private String var2; // preferred } ```

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: No abstract method which means that the keyword is most likely used to prevent instantiation. Use a private or protected constructor instead.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Abstract Class Without Any Method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
If an abstract class does not provides any methods, it may be acting as a simple data container that is not meant to be instantiated. In this case, it is probably better to use a private or protected constructor in order to prevent instantiation than make the class misleadingly abstract.

Example(s):

public abstract class Example {
    String field;
    int otherField;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid equality comparisons with Double.NaN

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bad Comparison

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid equality comparisons with Double.NaN. Due to the implicit lack of representation precision when comparing floating point numbers these are likely to cause logic errors.

Example(s):

boolean x = (y == Double.NaN);

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A 'getX()' method which returns a boolean should be named 'isX()'

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Boolean Get Method Name

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Methods that return boolean results should be named as predicate statements to denote this. I.e, ‘isReady()’, ‘hasValues()’, ‘canCommit()’, ‘willFail()’, etc. Avoid the use of the ‘get’ prefix for these methods.

Example(s):

public boolean getFoo();            // bad
public boolean isFoo();             // ok
public boolean getFoo(boolean bar); // ok, unless checkParameterizedMethods=true

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid instantiating Boolean objects; reference Boolean.TRUE or Boolean.FALSE or call Boolean.valueOf() instead.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Boolean Instantiation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid instantiating Boolean objects; you can reference Boolean.TRUE, Boolean.FALSE, or call Boolean.valueOf() instead. Note that new Boolean() is deprecated since JDK 9 for that reason.

Example(s):

Boolean bar = new Boolean("true");        // unnecessary creation, just reference Boolean.TRUE;
Boolean buz = Boolean.valueOf(false);    // ...., just reference Boolean.FALSE;

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Don't create instances of already existing BigInteger and BigDecimal (ZERO, ONE, TEN)

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Big Integer Instantiation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Don’t create instances of already existing BigInteger (BigInteger.ZERO, BigInteger.ONE) and for Java 1.5 onwards, BigInteger.TEN and BigDecimal (BigDecimal.ZERO, BigDecimal.ONE, BigDecimal.TEN)

Example(s):

BigInteger bi = new BigInteger(1);       // reference BigInteger.ONE instead
BigInteger bi2 = new BigInteger("0");    // reference BigInteger.ZERO instead
BigInteger bi3 = new BigInteger(0.0);    // reference BigInteger.ZERO instead
BigInteger bi4;
bi4 = new BigInteger(0);                 // reference BigInteger.ZERO instead

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Found non-transient, non-static member. Please mark as transient or provide accessors.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Bean Members Should Serialize

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Method call on object which may be null

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Broken Null Check

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The null check is broken since it will throw a NullPointerException itself. It is likely that you used || instead of && or vice versa.

Example(s):

public String bar(String string) {
  // should be &&
    if (string!=null || !string.equals(""))
        return string;
  // should be ||
    if (string==null && string.equals(""))
        return string;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid instantiating Byte objects. Call Byte.valueOf() instead

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Byte Instantiation

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: StringBuffer (or StringBuilder).append is called consecutively without reusing the target variable.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Consecutive Appends Should Reuse

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Consecutive calls to StringBuffer/StringBuilder .append should be chained, reusing the target object. This can improve the performance by producing a smaller bytecode, reducing overhead and improving inlining. A complete analysis can be found here

Example(s):

String foo = " ";

StringBuffer buf = new StringBuffer();
buf.append("Hello"); // poor
buf.append(foo);
buf.append("World");

StringBuffer buf = new StringBuffer();
buf.append("Hello").append(foo).append("World"); // good

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: High amount of different objects as members denotes a high coupling

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Coupling Between Objects

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: The {0} ''{1}'' has a{2} cyclomatic complexity of {3}.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Cyclomatic Complexity

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: This usage of the Collection.toArray() method will throw a ClassCastException.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Class Cast Exception With To Array

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
When deriving an array of a specific class from your Collection, one should provide an array of the same class as the parameter of the toArray() method. Doing otherwise you will will result in a ClassCastException.

Example(s):

Collection c = new ArrayList();
Integer obj = new Integer(1);
c.add(obj);

    // this would trigger the rule (and throw a ClassCastException if executed)
Integer[] a = (Integer [])c.toArray();

   // this is fine and will not trigger the rule
Integer[] b = (Integer [])c.toArray(new Integer[c.size()]);

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Overridable {0} called during object construction

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Constructor Calls Overridable Method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Calling overridable methods during construction poses a risk of invoking methods on an incompletely constructed object and can be difficult to debug. It may leave the sub-class unable to construct its superclass or forced to replicate the construction process completely within itself, losing the ability to call super(). If the default constructor contains a call to an overridable method, the subclass may be completely uninstantiable. Note that this includes method calls throughout the control flow graph - i.e., if a constructor Foo() calls a private method bar() that calls a public method buz(), this denotes a problem.

Example(s):

public class SeniorClass {
  public SeniorClass(){
      toString(); //may throw NullPointerException if overridden
  }
  public String toString(){
    return "IAmSeniorClass";
  }
}
public class JuniorClass extends SeniorClass {
  private String name;
  public JuniorClass(){
    super(); //Automatic call leads to NullPointerException
    name = "JuniorClass";
  }
  public String toString(){
    return name.toUpperCase();
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Missing commented default access modifier

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Comment Default Access Modifier

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid constants in interfaces. Interfaces define types, constants are implementation details better placed in classes or enums. See Effective Java, item 19.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Constants In Interface

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid constants in interfaces. Interfaces should define types, constants are implementation details better placed in classes or enums. See Effective Java, item 19.

Example(s):

public interface ConstantInterface {
    public static final int CONST1 = 1; // violation, no fields allowed in interface!
    static final int CONST2 = 1;        // violation, no fields allowed in interface!
    final int CONST3 = 1;               // violation, no fields allowed in interface!
    int CONST4 = 1;                     // violation, no fields allowed in interface!
}

// with ignoreIfHasMethods = false
public interface AnotherConstantInterface {
    public static final int CONST1 = 1; // violation, no fields allowed in interface!

    int anyMethod();
}

// with ignoreIfHasMethods = true
public interface YetAnotherConstantInterface {
    public static final int CONST1 = 1; // no violation

    int anyMethod();
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: These nested if statements could be combined

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Collapsible If Statements

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Sometimes two consecutive ‘if’ statements can be consolidated by separating their conditions with a boolean short-circuit operator.

Example(s):

void bar() {
    if (x) {            // original implementation
        if (y) {
            // do stuff
        }
    }
}

void bar() {
    if (x && y) {        // optimized implementation
        // do stuff
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: StringBuffer (or StringBuilder).append is called {0} consecutive times with literals. Use a single append with a single combined String.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Consecutive Literal Appends

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Consecutively calling StringBuffer/StringBuilder.append(…) with literals should be avoided. Since the literals are constants, they can already be combined into a single String literal and this String can be appended in a single method call.

Example(s):

StringBuilder buf = new StringBuilder();
buf.append("Hello").append(" ").append("World");    // poor
buf.append("Hello World");                          // good

buf.append('h').append('e').append('l').append('l').append('o'); // poor
buf.append("hello");                                             // good

buf.append(1).append('m');  // poor
buf.append("1m");           // good

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: clone() method must be public if the class implements Cloneable

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Clone Method Must Be Public

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The java Manual says “By convention, classes that implement this interface should override Object.clone (which is protected) with a public method.”

Example(s):

public class Foo implements Cloneable {
    @Override
    protected Object clone() throws CloneNotSupportedException { // Violation, must be public
    }
}

public class Foo implements Cloneable {
    @Override
    protected Foo clone() { // Violation, must be public
    }
}

public class Foo implements Cloneable {
    @Override
    public Object clone() // Ok
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The return type of the clone() method must be the class name when implements Cloneable

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Clone Method Return Type Must Match Class Name

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
If a class implements cloneable the return type of the method clone() must be the class name. That way, the caller of the clone method doesn’t need to cast the returned clone to the correct type.

Note: This is only possible with Java 1.5 or higher.

Example(s):

public class Foo implements Cloneable {
    @Override
    protected Object clone() { // Violation, Object must be Foo
    }
}

public class Foo implements Cloneable {
    @Override
    public Foo clone() { //Ok
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The {0} name ''{1}'' doesn''t match ''{2}''

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Class Naming Conventions

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Use equals() to compare object references.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Compare Objects With Equals

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Comment is required

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Comment Required

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Denotes whether javadoc (formal) comments are required (or unwanted) for specific language elements.
Example(s):
```java /** * * * @author Jon Doe */ ```

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Always check the return of one of the navigation method (next,previous,first,last) of a ResultSet.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Check Result Set

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Always check the return values of navigation methods (next, previous, first, last) of a ResultSet. If the value return is ‘false’, it should be handled properly.

Example(s):

Statement stat = conn.createStatement();
ResultSet rst = stat.executeQuery("SELECT name FROM person");
rst.next();     // what if it returns false? bad form
String firstName = rst.getString(1);

Statement stat = conn.createStatement();
ResultSet rst = stat.executeQuery("SELECT name FROM person");
if (rst.next()) {    // result is properly examined and used
    String firstName = rst.getString(1);
    } else  {
        // handle missing data
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Comment is too large

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Comment Size

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Determines whether the dimensions of non-header comments found are within the specified limits.
Example(s):
```java /** * * too many lines! * * * * * * * * * * * * */ ```

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: This statement should have braces

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Control Statement Braces

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Enforce a policy for braces on control statements. It is recommended to use braces on ‘if … else’ statements and loop statements, even if they are optional. This usually makes the code clearer, and helps prepare the future when you need to add another statement. That said, this rule lets you control which statements are required to have braces via properties.

        From 6.2.0 on, this rule supersedes WhileLoopMustUseBraces, ForLoopMustUseBraces, IfStmtMustUseBraces,
        and IfElseStmtMustUseBraces.

Example(s):

while (true)    // not recommended
  x++;

while (true) {  // preferred approach
  x++;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: super should be called at the start of the method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Call Super First

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: It is a good practice to call super() in a constructor

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Call Super In Constructor

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: super should be called at the end of the method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Call Super Last

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Check the value returned by the skip() method of an InputStream to see if the requested number of bytes has been skipped.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Check Skip Result

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The skip() method may skip a smaller number of bytes than requested. Check the returned value to find out if it was the case or not.

Example(s):

public class Foo {

   private FileInputStream _s = new FileInputStream("file");

   public void skip(int n) throws IOException {
      _s.skip(n); // You are not sure that exactly n bytes are skipped
   }

   public void skipExactly(int n) throws IOException {
      while (n != 0) {
         long skipped = _s.skip(n);
         if (skipped == 0)
            throw new EOFException();
         n -= skipped;
      }
   }

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid if (x != y) ..; else ..;

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Confusing Ternary

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid negation within an "if" expression with an "else" clause. For example, rephrase: `if (x != y) diff(); else same();` as: `if (x == y) same(); else diff();`.
Most "if (x != y)" cases without an "else" are often return cases, so consistent use of this rule makes the code easier to read. Also, this resolves trivial ordering problems, such as "does the error case go first?" or "does the common case go first?".
Example(s):
```java boolean bar(int x, int y) { return (x != y) ? diff : same; } ```

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: clone() method should throw CloneNotSupportedException

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Clone Throws Clone Not Supported Exception

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The method clone() should throw a CloneNotSupportedException.

Example(s):

public class MyClass implements Cloneable{
    public Object clone() { // will cause an error
         MyClass clone = (MyClass)super.clone();
         return clone;
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A class which only has private constructors should be final

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Class With Only Private Constructors Should Be Final

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A class with only private constructors should be final, unless the private constructor is invoked by a inner class.

Example(s):

public class Foo {  //Should be final
    private Foo() { }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: clone() method should be implemented only if implementing Cloneable interface

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Clone Method Must Implement Cloneable

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The method clone() should only be implemented if the class implements the Cloneable interface with the exception of a final method that only throws CloneNotSupportedException.

The rule can also detect, if the class implements or extends a Cloneable class.

Example(s):

public class MyClass {
 public Object clone() throws CloneNotSupportedException {
  return foo;
 }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Ensure that resources like this {0} object are closed after use

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Close Resource

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Ensure that resources (like java.sql.Connection, java.sql.Statement, and java.sql.ResultSet objects and any subtype of java.lang.AutoCloseable) are always closed after use. Failing to do so might result in resource leaks.

Note: It suffices to configure the super type, e.g. java.lang.AutoClosable, so that this rule automatically triggers on any subtype (e.g. java.io.FileInputStream). Additionally specifying java.sql.Connection helps in detecting the types, if the type resolution / auxclasspath is not correctly setup.

Note: Since PMD 6.16.0 the default value for the property types contains java.lang.AutoCloseable and detects now cases where the standard java.io.*Stream classes are involved. In order to restore the old behaviour, just remove “AutoCloseable” from the types.

Example(s):

public class Bar {
    public void withSQL() {
        Connection c = pool.getConnection();
        try {
            // do stuff
        } catch (SQLException ex) {
           // handle exception
        } finally {
            // oops, should close the connection using 'close'!
            // c.close();
        }
    }

    public void withFile() {
        InputStream file = new FileInputStream(new File("/tmp/foo"));
        try {
            int c = file.in();
        } catch (IOException e) {
            // handle exception
        } finally {
            // TODO: close file
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Invalid words or phrases found

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Comment Content

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A rule for the politically correct... we don't want to offend anyone.
Example(s):
```java //OMG, this is horrible, Bob is an idiot !!! ```

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Found ''{0}''-anomaly for variable ''{1}'' (lines ''{2}''-''{3}'').

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dataflow Anomaly Analysis

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Double-brace initialization should be avoided

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Double Brace Initialization

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Double brace initialisation is a pattern to initialise eg collections concisely. But it implicitly generates a new .class file, and the object holds a strong reference to the enclosing object. For those reasons, it is preferable to initialize the object normally, even though it’s verbose.

        This rule counts any anonymous class which only has a single initializer as an instance of double-brace
        initialization. There is currently no way to find out whether a method called in the initializer is not
        accessible from outside the anonymous class, and those legit cases should be suppressed for the time being.

Example(s):

// this is double-brace initialization
return new ArrayList<String>(){{
    add("a");
    add("b");
    add("c");
}};

// the better way is to not create an anonymous class:
List<String> a = new ArrayList<>();
a.add("a");
a.add("b");
a.add("c");
return a;

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The class ''{0}'' is suspected to be a Data Class (WOC={1}, NOPA={2}, NOAM={3}, WMC={4})

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Data Class

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Data Classes are simple data holders, which reveal most of their state, and without complex functionality. The lack of functionality may indicate that their behaviour is defined elsewhere, which is a sign of poor data-behaviour proximity. By directly exposing their internals, Data Classes break encapsulation, and therefore reduce the system’s maintainability and understandability. Moreover, classes tend to strongly rely on their data representation, which makes for a brittle design.

Refactoring a Data Class should focus on restoring a good data-behaviour proximity. In most cases, that means moving the operations defined on the data back into the class. In some other cases it may make sense to remove entirely the class and move the data into the former client classes.

Example(s):

public class DataClass {

  public int bar = 0;
  public int na = 0;
  private int bee = 0;

  public void setBee(int n) {
    bee = n;
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Double checked locking is not thread safe in Java.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Double Checked Locking

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Partially created objects can be returned by the Double Checked Locking pattern when used in Java. An optimizing JRE may assign a reference to the baz variable before it calls the constructor of the object the reference points to.

Note: With Java 5, you can make Double checked locking work, if you declare the variable to be volatile.

For more details refer to: http://www.javaworld.com/javaworld/jw-02-2001/jw-0209-double.html or http://www.cs.umd.edu/~pugh/java/memoryModel/DoubleCheckedLocking.html

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    /*volatile */ Object baz = null; // fix for Java5 and later: volatile
    Object bar() {
        if (baz == null) { // baz may be non-null yet not fully created
            synchronized(this) {
                if (baz == null) {
                    baz = new Object();
                }
              }
        }
        return baz;
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Don't call Thread.run() explicitly, use Thread.start()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dont Call Thread Run

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Explicitly calling Thread.run() method will execute in the caller’s thread of control. Instead, call Thread.start() for the intended behavior.

Example(s):

Thread t = new Thread();
t.run();            // use t.start() instead
new Thread().run(); // same violation

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid duplicate imports such as ''{0}''

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Duplicate Imports

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Duplicate or overlapping import statements should be avoided.

Example(s):

import java.lang.String;
import java.lang.*;
public class Foo {}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid importing anything from the package 'java.lang'

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dont Import Java Lang

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid importing anything from the package ‘java.lang’. These classes are automatically imported (JLS 7.5.3).

Example(s):

import java.lang.String;    // this is unnecessary

public class Foo {}

// --- in another source code file...

import java.lang.*;         // this is bad

public class Foo {}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid importing anything from the 'sun.*' packages

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dont Import Sun

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid importing anything from the ’sun.*’ packages. These packages are not portable and are likely to change.

Example(s):

import sun.misc.foo;
public class Foo {}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The default label should be the last label in a switch statement

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Default Label Not Last In Switch Stmt

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
By convention, the default label should be the last label in a switch statement.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  void bar(int a) {
   switch (a) {
    case 1:  // do something
       break;
    default:  // the default case should be last, by convention
       break;
    case 2:
       break;
   }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Do not explicitly trigger a garbage collection.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Do Not Call Garbage Collection Explicitly

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Calls to System.gc(), Runtime.getRuntime().gc(), and System.runFinalization() are not advised. Code should have the same behavior whether the garbage collection is disabled using the option -Xdisableexplicitgc or not. Moreover, “modern” jvms do a very good job handling garbage collections. If memory usage issues unrelated to memory leaks develop within an application, it should be dealt with JVM options rather than within the code itself.

Example(s):

public class GCCall {
    public GCCall() {
        // Explicit gc call !
        System.gc();
    }

    public void doSomething() {
        // Explicit gc call !
        Runtime.getRuntime().gc();
    }

    public explicitGCcall() {
        // Explicit gc call !
        System.gc();
    }

    public void doSomething() {
        // Explicit gc call !
        Runtime.getRuntime().gc();
    }
}

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Do Not Call System Exit

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Exceptions should not extend java.lang.Error

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Do Not Extend Java Lang Error

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Errors are system exceptions. Do not extend them.

Example(s):

public class Foo extends Error { }

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Exceptions should not extend java.lang.Throwable

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Do Not Extend Java Lang Throwable

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Extend Exception or RuntimeException instead of Throwable.

Example(s):

public class Foo extends Throwable { }

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Do not hardcode /sdcard.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Do Not Hard Code SDCard

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: A throw statement in a finally block makes the control flow hard to understand.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Do Not Throw Exception In Finally

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Throwing exceptions within a ‘finally’ block is confusing since they may mask other exceptions or code defects. Note: This is a PMD implementation of the Lint4j rule “A throw in a finally block”

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    public void bar() {
        try {
            // Here do some stuff
        } catch( Exception e) {
            // Handling the issue
        } finally {
            // is this really a good idea ?
            throw new Exception();
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: System.exit() should not be used in J2EE/JEE apps

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Do Not Terminate VM

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Web applications should not call System.exit(), since only the web container or the application server should stop the JVM. Otherwise a web application would terminate all other applications running on the same application server.

This rule also checks for the equivalent calls Runtime.getRuntime().exit() and Runtime.getRuntime().halt().

This rule was called DoNotCallSystemExit until PMD 6.29.0.

Example(s):

public void bar() {
    System.exit(0);                 // never call this when running in an application server!
}
public void foo() {
    Runtime.getRuntime().exit(0);   // never stop the JVM manually, the container will do this.
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: To be compliant to J2EE, a webapp should not use any thread.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Do Not Use Threads

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Use explicit scoping instead of the default package private level

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Default Package

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: Use explicit scoping instead of accidental usage of default package private level. The rule allows methods and fields annotated with Guava’s @VisibleForTesting and JUnit 5’s annotations.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Probable detached JUnit test case.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Detached Test Case

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The method appears to be a test case since it has public or default visibility, non-static access, no arguments, no return value, has no annotations, but is a member of a class that has one or more JUnit test cases. If it is a utility method, it should likely have private visibility. If it is an ignored test, it should be annotated with @Test and @Ignore.

Example(s):

public class MyTest {
    @Test
    public void someTest() {
    }

    // violation: Not annotated
    public void someOtherTest () {
    }

}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Don't use floating point for loop indices. If you must use floating point, use double.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Dont Use Float Type For Loop Indices

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Don’t use floating point for loop indices. If you must use floating point, use double unless you’re certain that float provides enough precision and you have a compelling performance need (space or time).

Example(s):

public class Count {
  public static void main(String[] args) {
    final int START = 2000000000;
    int count = 0;
    for (float f = START; f < START + 50; f++)
      count++;
      //Prints 0 because (float) START == (float) (START + 50).
      System.out.println(count);
      //The termination test misbehaves due to floating point granularity.
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using exceptions as flow control.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Exception As Flow Control

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Using Exceptions as form of flow control is not recommended as they obscure true exceptions when debugging. Either add the necessary validation or use an alternate control structure.

Example(s):

public void bar() {
    try {
        try {
        } catch (Exception e) {
            throw new WrapperException(e);
            // this is essentially a GOTO to the WrapperException catch block
        }
    } catch (WrapperException e) {
        // do some more stuff
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty catch blocks

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Catch Block

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty Catch Block finds instances where an exception is caught, but nothing is done. In most circumstances, this swallows an exception which should either be acted on or reported.

Example(s):

public void doSomething() {
    try {
        FileInputStream fis = new FileInputStream("/tmp/bugger");
    } catch (IOException ioe) {
        // not good
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid really long classes.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Excessive Class Length

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty finalize methods

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Finalizer

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty finalize methods serve no purpose and should be removed. Note that Oracle has declared Object.finalize() as deprecated since JDK 9.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
   protected void finalize() {}
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty finally blocks

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Finally Block

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty finally blocks serve no purpose and should be removed.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    public void bar() {
        try {
            int x=2;
        } finally {
            // empty!
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A high number of imports can indicate a high degree of coupling within an object.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Excessive Imports

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty 'if' statements

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty If Stmt

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty If Statement finds instances where a condition is checked but nothing is done about it.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
 void bar(int x) {
  if (x == 0) {
   // empty!
  }
 }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An empty method in an abstract class should be abstract instead

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Method In Abstract Class Should Be Abstract

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty or auto-generated methods in an abstract class should be tagged as abstract. This helps to remove their inapproprate usage by developers who should be implementing their own versions in the concrete subclasses.

Example(s):

public abstract class ShouldBeAbstract {
    public Object couldBeAbstract() {
        // Should be abstract method ?
        return null;
    }

    public void couldBeAbstract() {
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid really long methods.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Excessive Method Length

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid using equals() to compare against null

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Equals Null

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Tests for null should not use the equals() method. The ‘==’ operator should be used instead.

Example(s):

String x = "foo";

if (x.equals(null)) {   // bad form
    doSomething();
}

if (x == null) {        // preferred
    doSomething();
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: No need to explicitly extend Object.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Extends Object

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
No need to explicitly extend Object.

Example(s):

public class Foo extends Object {     // not required
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: This class has a bunch of public methods and attributes

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Excessive Public Count

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid long parameter lists.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Excessive Parameter List

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty synchronized blocks

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Synchronized Block

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty synchronized blocks serve no purpose and should be removed.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    public void bar() {
        synchronized (this) {
            // empty!
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An empty statement (semicolon) not part of a loop

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Statement Not In Loop

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
An empty statement (or a semicolon by itself) that is not used as the sole body of a ‘for’ or ‘while’ loop is probably a bug. It could also be a double semicolon, which has no purpose and should be removed.

Example(s):

public void doit() {
      // this is probably not what you meant to do
      ;
      // the extra semicolon here this is not necessary
      System.out.println("look at the extra semicolon");;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty switch statements

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Switch Statements

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty switch statements serve no purpose and should be removed.

Example(s):

public void bar() {
    int x = 2;
    switch (x) {
        // once there was code here
        // but it's been commented out or something
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty try blocks

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Try Block

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid empty try blocks - what’s the point?

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    public void bar() {
        try {
        } catch (Exception e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty 'while' statements

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty While Stmt

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty While Statement finds all instances where a while statement does nothing. If it is a timing loop, then you should use Thread.sleep() for it; if it is a while loop that does a lot in the exit expression, rewrite it to make it clearer.

Example(s):

void bar(int a, int b) {
    while (a == b) {
        // empty!
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Empty initializer was found

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Initializer

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid empty block statements.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Empty Statement Block

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Empty block statements serve no purpose and should be removed.

Example(s):

public class Foo {

   private int _bar;

   public void setBar(int bar) {
      { _bar = bar; } // Why not?
      {} // But remove this.
   }

}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Last statement in finalize method should be a call to super.finalize()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Finalize Does Not Call Super Finalize

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
If the finalize() is implemented, its last action should be to call super.finalize. Note that Oracle has declared Object.finalize() as deprecated since JDK 9.

Example(s):

protected void finalize() {
    something();
    // neglected to call super.finalize()
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Fields should be declared at the top of the class, before any method declarations, constructors, initializers or inner classes.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Field Declarations Should Be At Start Of Class

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Fields should be declared at the top of the class, before any method declarations, constructors, initializers or inner classes.

Example(s):

public class HelloWorldBean {

  // Field declared before methods / inner classes - OK
  private String _thing;

  public String getMessage() {
    return "Hello World!";
  }

  // Field declared after methods / inner classes - avoid this
  private String _fieldInWrongLocation;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: This final field could be made static

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Final Field Could Be Static

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
If a final field is assigned to a compile-time constant, it could be made static, thus saving overhead in each object at runtime.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  public final int BAR = 42; // this could be static and save some space
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: This 'for' loop can be replaced by a 'foreach' loop

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: For Loop Can Be Foreach

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Reports loops that can be safely replaced with the foreach syntax. The rule considers loops over lists, arrays and iterators. A loop is safe to replace if it only uses the index variable to access an element of the list or array, only has one update statement, and loops through every element of the list or array left to right.

Example(s):

public class MyClass {
  void loop(List<String> l) {
    for (int i = 0; i < l.size(); i++) { // pre Java 1.5
      System.out.println(l.get(i));
    }

    for (String s : l) {        // post Java 1.5
      System.out.println(s);
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using 'for' statements without curly braces

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: For Loops Must Use Braces

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid using 'for' statements without using curly braces. If the code formatting or indentation is lost then it becomes difficult to separate the code being controlled from the rest.
This rule is deprecated and will be removed with PMD 7.0.0. The rule is replaced by the rule [Control Statement Braces](#PMD_CSB).
Example(s):
```java for (int i = 0; i < 42; i++) foo(); ```

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: This for loop could be simplified to a while loop

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: For Loop Should Be While Loop

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Some for loops can be simplified to while loops, this makes them more concise.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    void bar() {
        for (;true;) true; // No Init or Update part, may as well be: while (true)
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Too many control variables in the 'for' statement

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: For Loop Variable Count

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Having a lot of control variables in a ‘for’ loop makes it harder to see what range of values the loop iterates over. By default this rule allows a regular ‘for’ loop with only one variable.

Example(s):

// this will be reported with the default setting of at most one control variable in a for loop
for (int i = 0, j = 0; i < 10; i++, j += 2) {
   foo();

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The {0} name ''{1}'' doesn''t match ''{2}''

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Field Naming Conventions

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Finalize methods should not be overloaded

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Finalize Overloaded

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Methods named finalize() should not have parameters. It is confusing and most likely an attempt to overload Object.finalize(). It will not be called by the VM.

Note that Oracle has declared Object.finalize() as deprecated since JDK 9.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    // this is confusing and probably a bug
    protected void finalize(int a) {
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Finalize should do something besides just calling super.finalize()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Finalize Only Calls Super Finalize

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
If the finalize() is implemented, it should do something besides just calling super.finalize(). Note that Oracle has declared Object.finalize() as deprecated since JDK 9.

Example(s):

protected void finalize() {
    super.finalize();
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The {0} name ''{1}'' doesn''t match ''{2}''

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Formal Parameter Naming Conventions

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: If you override finalize(), make it protected

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Finalize Should Be Protected

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
When overriding the finalize(), the new method should be set as protected. If made public, other classes may invoke it at inappropriate times.

Note that Oracle has declared Object.finalize() as deprecated since JDK 9.

Example(s):

public void finalize() {
    // do something
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Possible God Class (WMC={0}, ATFD={2}, TCC={1})

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: God Class

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The God Class rule detects the God Class design flaw using metrics. God classes do too many things, are very big and overly complex. They should be split apart to be more object-oriented. The rule uses the detection strategy described in "Object-Oriented Metrics in Practice". The violations are reported against the entire class.
See also the references:
Michele Lanza and Radu Marinescu. Object-Oriented Metrics in Practice: Using Software Metrics to Characterize, Evaluate, and Improve the Design of Object-Oriented Systems. Springer, Berlin, 1 edition, October 2006. Page 80.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Logger calls should be surrounded by log level guards.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Guard Log Statement

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Whenever using a log level, one should check if the loglevel is actually enabled, or otherwise skip the associate String creation and manipulation.

Example(s):

// Add this for performance
    if (log.isDebugEnabled() { ...
        log.debug("log something" + " and " + "concat strings");

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Generics names should be a one letter long and upper case.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Generics Naming

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Names for references to generic values should be limited to a single uppercase letter.

Example(s):

public interface GenericDao<E extends BaseModel, K extends Serializable> extends BaseDao {
    // This is ok...
}

public interface GenericDao<E extends BaseModel, K extends Serializable> {
    // Also this
}

public interface GenericDao<e extends BaseModel, K extends Serializable> {
    // 'e' should be an 'E'
}

public interface GenericDao<EF extends BaseModel, K extends Serializable> {
   // 'EF' is not ok.
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Do not use hard coded encryption keys

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Hard Coded Crypto Key

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Do not use hard coded values for cryptographic operations. Please store keys outside of source code.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    void good() {
        SecretKeySpec secretKeySpec = new SecretKeySpec(Properties.getKey(), "AES");
    }

    void bad() {
        SecretKeySpec secretKeySpec = new SecretKeySpec("my secret here".getBytes(), "AES");
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: ''catch'' branch identical to ''{0}'' branch

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Identical Catch Branches

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Identical catch branches use up vertical space and increase the complexity of code without adding functionality. It’s better style to collapse identical branches into a single multi-catch branch.

Example(s):

try {
    // do something
} catch (IllegalArgumentException e) {
    throw e;
} catch (IllegalStateException e) { // Can be collapsed into the previous block
    throw e;
}

try {
    // do something
} catch (IllegalArgumentException | IllegalStateException e) { // This is better
    throw e;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Do not use hard coded initialization vector in crypto operations

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Insecure Crypto Iv

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Do not use hard coded initialization vector in cryptographic operations. Please use a randomly generated IV.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    void good() {
        SecureRandom random = new SecureRandom();
        byte iv[] = new byte[16];
        random.nextBytes(bytes);
    }

    void bad() {
        byte[] iv = new byte[] { 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, };
    }

    void alsoBad() {
        byte[] iv = "secret iv in here".getBytes();
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: String.trim().length() == 0 / String.trim().isEmpty() is an inefficient way to validate a blank String.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Inefficient Empty String Check

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid using 'if...else' statements without curly braces

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: If Else Stmts Must Use Braces

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Private field ''{0}'' could be made final; it is only initialized in the declaration or constructor.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Immutable Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Identifies private fields whose values never change once object initialization ends either in the declaration of the field or by a constructor. This helps in converting existing classes to becoming immutable ones. Note that this rule does not enforce referenced object to be immutable itself. A class can still be mutable, even if all its member fields are declared final. This is referred to as shallow immutability. For more information on mutability, see Effective Java, 3rd Edition, Item 17: Minimize mutability.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  private int x; // could be final
  public Foo() {
      x = 7;
  }
  public void foo() {
     int a = x + 2;
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: No need to import a type that lives in the same package

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Import From Same Package

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
There is no need to import a type that lives in the same package.

Example(s):

package foo;

import foo.Buz;     // no need for this
import foo.*;       // or this

public class Bar{}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid instantiating Integer objects. Call Integer.valueOf() instead.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Integer Instantiation

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Invalid message format

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Invalid Log Message Format

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Check for messages in slf4j and log4j2 (since 6.19.0) loggers with non matching number of arguments and placeholders.

Since 6.32.0 in addition to parameterized message placeholders ({}) also format specifiers of string formatted messages are supported (%s).

Example(s):

LOGGER.error("forget the arg {}");
LOGGER.error("forget the arg %s");
LOGGER.error("too many args {}", "arg1", "arg2");
LOGGER.error("param {}", "arg1", new IllegalStateException("arg")); //The exception is shown separately, so is correct.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid idempotent operations (like assigning a variable to itself).

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Idempotent Operations

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid idempotent operations - they have no effect.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
 public void bar() {
  int x = 2;
  x = x;
 }
}

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Invalid Slf4j Message Format

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid concatenating nonliterals in a StringBuffer/StringBuilder constructor or append().

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Inefficient String Buffering

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid concatenating non-literals in a StringBuffer constructor or append() since intermediate buffers will need to be be created and destroyed by the JVM.

Example(s):

// Avoid this, two buffers are actually being created here
StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer("tmp = "+System.getProperty("java.io.tmpdir"));

// do this instead
StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer("tmp = ");
sb.append(System.getProperty("java.io.tmpdir"));

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: StringBuffer constructor is initialized with size {0}, but has at least {1} characters appended.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Insufficient String Buffer Declaration

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid using if statements without curly braces

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: If Stmts Must Use Braces

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid using if statements without using braces to surround the code block. If the code formatting or indentation is lost then it becomes difficult to separate the code being controlled from the rest.
This rule is deprecated and will be removed with PMD 7.0.0. The rule is replaced by the rule [Control Statement Braces](#PMD_CSB).
Example(s):
```java if (foo) // not recommended x++;
if (foo) { // preferred approach x++; } ```

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid instantiating an object just to call getClass() on it; use the .class public member instead

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Instantiation To Get Class

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid instantiating an object just to call getClass() on it; use the .class public member instead.

Example(s):

// replace this
Class c = new String().getClass();

// with this:
Class c = String.class;

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid modifying an outer loop incrementer in an inner loop for update expression

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Jumbled Incrementer

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid jumbled loop incrementers - its usually a mistake, and is confusing even if intentional.

Example(s):

public class JumbledIncrementerRule1 {
    public void foo() {
        for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) {          // only references 'i'
            for (int k = 0; k < 20; i++) {      // references both 'i' and 'k'
                System.out.println("Hello");
            }
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: JUnit 4 indicates test suites via annotations, not the suite method.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: JUnit4 Suites Should Use Suite Annotation

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: JUnit 4 tests that clean up tests should use the @After annotation, JUnit5 tests should use @AfterEach or @AfterAll

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: JUnit4 Test Should Use After Annotation

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: JUnit 4 tests that set up tests should use the @Before annotation, JUnit5 tests should use @BeforeEach or @BeforeAll

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: JUnit4 Test Should Use Before Annotation

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: JUnit 4 tests that execute tests should use the @Test annotation, JUnit 5 tests should use @Test, @RepeatedTest, @TestFactory, @TestTemplate or @ParameterizedTest

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: JUnit4 Test Should Use Test Annotation

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: JUnit assertions should include a message

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: JUnit Assertions Should Include Message

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
JUnit assertions should include an informative message - i.e., use the three-argument version of assertEquals(), not the two-argument version.

Example(s):

public class Foo extends TestCase {
    public void testSomething() {
        assertEquals("foo", "bar");
        // Use the form:
        // assertEquals("Foo does not equals bar", "foo", "bar");
        // instead
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: You may have misspelled a JUnit framework method (setUp or tearDown)

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: JUnit Spelling

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
In JUnit 3, the setUp method is used to set up all data entities required in running tests. The tearDown method is used to clean up all data entities required in running tests. You should not misspell method name if you want your test to set up and clean up everything correctly.

Example(s):

import junit.framework.*;

public class Foo extends TestCase {
    public void setup() {}    // oops, should be setUp
    public void TearDown() {} // oops, should be tearDown
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: You have a suite() method that is not both public and static, so JUnit won't call it to get your TestSuite. Is that what you wanted to do?

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: JUnit Static Suite

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The suite() method in a JUnit test needs to be both public and static.

Example(s):

import junit.framework.*;

public class Foo extends TestCase {
    public void suite() {}         // oops, should be static
    private static void suite() {} // oops, should be public
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Unit tests should not contain more than ${maximumAsserts} assert(s).

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: JUnit Test Contains Too Many Asserts

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Unit tests should not contain too many asserts. Many asserts are indicative of a complex test, for which it is harder to verify correctness. Consider breaking the test scenario into multiple, shorter test scenarios. Customize the maximum number of assertions used by this Rule to suit your needs.

This rule checks for JUnit4, JUnit5 and TestNG Tests, as well as methods starting with “test”.

Example(s):

public class MyTestCase extends TestCase {
    // Ok
    public void testMyCaseWithOneAssert() {
        boolean myVar = false;
        assertFalse("should be false", myVar);
    }

    // Bad, too many asserts (assuming max=1)
    public void testMyCaseWithMoreAsserts() {
        boolean myVar = false;
        assertFalse("myVar should be false", myVar);
        assertEquals("should equals false", false, myVar);
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: JUnit tests should include assert() or fail()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: JUnit Tests Should Include Assert

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
JUnit tests should include at least one assertion. This makes the tests more robust, and using assert with messages provide the developer a clearer idea of what the test does.

Example(s):

public class Foo extends TestCase {
   public void testSomething() {
      Bar b = findBar();
   // This is better than having a NullPointerException
   // assertNotNull("bar not found", b);
   b.work();
   }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: In JUnit4, use the @Test(expected) annotation to denote tests that should throw exceptions

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: JUnit Use Expected

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Position literals first in String comparisons

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Literals First In Comparisons

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
