Position literals first in all String comparisons, if the second argument is null then NullPointerExceptions can be avoided, they will just return false. Note that switching literal positions for compareTo and compareToIgnoreCase may change the result, see examples.

Example(s):

class Foo {
    boolean bar(String x) {
        return x.equals("2"); // should be "2".equals(x)
    }
    boolean bar(String x) {
        return x.equalsIgnoreCase("2"); // should be "2".equalsIgnoreCase(x)
    }
    boolean bar(String x) {
        return (x.compareTo("bar") > 0); // should be: "bar".compareTo(x) < 0
    }
    boolean bar(String x) {
        return (x.compareToIgnoreCase("bar") > 0); // should be: "bar".compareToIgnoreCase(x) < 0
    }
    boolean bar(String x) {
        return x.contentEquals("bar"); // should be "bar".contentEquals(x)
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The Local Home interface of a Session EJB should be suffixed by 'LocalHome'

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Local Home Naming Convention

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The Local Home interface of a Session EJB should be suffixed by ‘LocalHome’.

Example(s):

public interface MyBeautifulLocalHome extends javax.ejb.EJBLocalHome {} // proper name

public interface MissingProperSuffix extends javax.ejb.EJBLocalHome {}  // non-standard name

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Use opposite operator instead of the logic complement operator.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Logic Inversion

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Use opposite operator instead of negating the whole expression with a logic complement operator.

Example(s):

public boolean bar(int a, int b) {

    if (!(a == b)) { // use !=
         return false;
     }

    if (!(a < b)) { // use >=
         return false;
    }

    return true;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The Logger variable declaration does not contain the static and final modifiers

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Logger Is Not Static Final

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
In most cases, the Logger reference can be declared as static and final.

This rule is deprecated and will be removed with PMD 7.0.0. The rule is replaced by Proper Logger.

Example(s):

public class Foo{
    Logger log = Logger.getLogger(Foo.class.getName());                 // not recommended

    static final Logger log = Logger.getLogger(Foo.class.getName());    // preferred approach
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The Local Interface of a Session EJB should be suffixed by 'Local'

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Local Interface Session Naming Convention

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The Local Interface of a Session EJB should be suffixed by ‘Local’.

Example(s):

public interface MyLocal extends javax.ejb.EJBLocalObject {}                // proper name

public interface MissingProperSuffix extends javax.ejb.EJBLocalObject {}    // non-standard name

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Linguistics Antipattern - Method name and return type is inconsistent linguistically

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Linguistic Naming

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Potential violation of Law of Demeter

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Law Of Demeter

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Use of ''{0}'' outside of package hierarchy ''{1}'' is not recommended; use recommended classes instead

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Loose Package Coupling

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid excessively long variable names like {0}

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Long Variable

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Local variable ''{0}'' could be declared final

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Local Variable Could Be Final

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: The {0} name ''{1}'' doesn''t match ''{2}''

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Local Variable Naming Conventions

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid using implementation types like ''{0}''; use the interface instead

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Loose Coupling

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The use of implementation types (i.e., HashSet) as object references limits your ability to use alternate implementations in the future as requirements change. Whenever available, referencing objects by their interface types (i.e, Set) provides much more flexibility.

Example(s):

import java.util.ArrayList;
import java.util.HashSet;

public class Bar {
    // sub-optimal approach
    private ArrayList<SomeType> list = new ArrayList<>();

    public HashSet<SomeType> getFoo() {
        return new HashSet<SomeType>();
    }

    // preferred approach
    private List<SomeType> list = new ArrayList<>();

    public Set<SomeType> getFoo() {
        return new HashSet<SomeType>();
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid instantiating Long objects.Call Long.valueOf() instead

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Long Instantiation

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Parameter ''{0}'' is not assigned and could be declared final

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Method Argument Could Be Final

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: A switch statement does not contain a break

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Missing Break In Switch

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Switch statements without break or return statements for each case option may indicate problematic behaviour. Empty cases are ignored as these indicate an intentional fall-through.

Example(s):

public void bar(int status) {
    switch(status) {
      case CANCELLED:
        doCancelled();
        // break; hm, should this be commented out?
      case NEW:
        doNew();
        // is this really a fall-through?
      case REMOVED:
        doRemoved();
        // what happens if you add another case after this one?
      case OTHER: // empty case - this is interpreted as an intentional fall-through
      case ERROR:
        doErrorHandling();
        break;
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The {0} ''{1}'' has a Modified Cyclomatic Complexity of {2}.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Modified Cyclomatic Complexity

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: SessionBean or MessageBean should be suffixed by Bean

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: MDBAnd Session Bean Naming Convention

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The EJB Specification states that any MessageDrivenBean or SessionBean should be suffixed by ‘Bean’.

Example(s):

public class SomeBean implements SessionBean{}                  // proper name

public class MissingTheProperSuffix implements SessionBean {}   // non-standard name

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The null check here is misplaced; if the variable ''{0}'' is null there will be a NullPointerException

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Misplaced Null Check

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The null check here is misplaced. If the variable is null a NullPointerException will be thrown. Either the check is useless (the variable will never be “null”) or it is incorrect.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    void bar() {
        if (a.equals(baz) && a != null) {} // a could be null, misplaced null check

        if (a != null && a.equals(baz)) {} // correct null check
    }
}
public class Foo {
    void bar() {
        if (a.equals(baz) || a == null) {} // a could be null, misplaced null check

        if (a == null || a.equals(baz)) {} // correct null check
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The method ''{0}'' is missing an @Override annotation.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Missing Override

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Annotating overridden methods with @Override ensures at compile time that the method really overrides one, which helps refactoring and clarifies intent.

Example(s):

public class Foo implements Runnable {
                // This method is overridden, and should have an @Override annotation
                public void run() {

                }
            }

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Returning ''{0}'' may expose an internal array.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Method Returns Internal Array

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Exposing internal arrays to the caller violates object encapsulation since elements can be removed or replaced outside of the object that owns it. It is safer to return a copy of the array.

Example(s):

public class SecureSystem {
    UserData [] ud;
    public UserData [] getUserData() {
        // Don't return directly the internal array, return a copy
        return ud;
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class cannot be instantiated and does not provide any static methods or fields

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Missing Static Method In Non Instantiatable Class

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A class that has private constructors and does not have any static methods or fields cannot be used.

When one of the private constructors is annotated with one of the annotations, then the class is not considered non-instantiatable anymore and no violation will be reported. See the property annotations.

Example(s):

// This class is unusable, since it cannot be
// instantiated (private constructor),
// and no static method can be called.

public class Foo {
  private Foo() {}
  void foo() {}
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Classes implementing Serializable should set a serialVersionUID

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Missing Serial Version UID

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Serializable classes should provide a serialVersionUID field. The serialVersionUID field is also needed for abstract base classes. Each individual class in the inheritance chain needs an own serialVersionUID field. See also Should an abstract class have a serialVersionUID.

Example(s):

public class Foo implements java.io.Serializable {
    String name;
    // Define serialization id to avoid serialization related bugs
    // i.e., public static final long serialVersionUID = 4328743;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class contains more than one logger.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: More Than One Logger

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Normally only one logger is used in each class. This rule supports slf4j, log4j, Java Util Logging and log4j2 (since 6.19.0).

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    Logger log = Logger.getLogger(Foo.class.getName());
    // It is very rare to see two loggers on a class, normally
    // log information is multiplexed by levels
    Logger log2= Logger.getLogger(Foo.class.getName());
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid naming non-fields with the prefix 'm_'

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: MIs Leading Variable Name

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Detects when a non-field has a name starting with 'm_'. This usually denotes a field and could be confusing.
This rule is deprecated and will be removed with PMD 7.0.0. The rule is replaced by the more general rule [Local Variable Naming Conventions](#PMD_LVNC).
Example(s):
```java public class Foo { private int m_foo; // OK public void bar(String m_baz) { // Bad int m_boz = 42; // Bad } } ```

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Classes should not have non-constructor methods with the same name as the class

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Method With Same Name As Enclosing Class

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Non-constructor methods should not have the same name as the enclosing class.

Example(s):

public class MyClass {

    public MyClass() {}         // this is OK because it is a constructor

    public void MyClass() {}    // this is bad because it is a method
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The {0} name ''{1}'' doesn''t match ''{2}''

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Method Naming Conventions

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Assigning an Object to null is a code smell. Consider refactoring.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Null Assignment

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: The constructor with {0} parameters has an NCSS line count of {1}

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Ncss Constructor Count

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: A non-case label was present in a switch statement

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Non Case Label In Switch Statement

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A non-case label (e.g. a named break/continue label) was present in a switch statement. This legal, but confusing. It is easy to mix up the case labels and the non-case labels.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  void bar(int a) {
   switch (a) {
     case 1:
       // do something
       break;
     mylabel: // this is legal, but confusing!
       break;
     default:
       break;
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The {0} ''{1}'' has a NCSS line count of {2}.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Ncss Count

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: The method {0}() has an NCSS line count of {1}

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Ncss Method Count

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: All classes, interfaces, enums and annotations must belong to a named package

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: No Package

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Detects when a class, interface, enum or annotation does not have a package definition.

Example(s):

// no package declaration
public class ClassInDefaultPackage {
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The {0} ''{1}'' has an NPath complexity of {2}, current threshold is {3}

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: NPath Complexity

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Non-static initializers are confusing

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Non Static Initializer

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A non-static initializer block will be called any time a constructor is invoked (just prior to invoking the constructor). While this is a valid language construct, it is rarely used and is confusing.

Example(s):

public class MyClass {
  // this block gets run before any call to a constructor
  {
    System.out.println("I am about to construct myself");
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The type has an NCSS line count of {0}

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Ncss Type Count

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Singleton is not thread safe

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Non Thread Safe Singleton

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Non-thread safe singletons can result in bad state changes. Eliminate static singletons if possible by instantiating the object directly. Static singletons are usually not needed as only a single instance exists anyway. Other possible fixes are to synchronize the entire method or to use an initialize-on-demand holder class.

Refrain from using the double-checked locking pattern. The Java Memory Model doesn’t guarantee it to work unless the variable is declared as volatile, adding an uneeded performance penalty. Reference

See Effective Java, item 48.

Example(s):

private static Foo foo = null;

//multiple simultaneous callers may see partially initialized objects
public static Foo getFoo() {
    if (foo==null) {
        foo = new Foo();
    }
    return foo;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Ensure you override both equals() and hashCode()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Override Both Equals And Hashcode

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Override both public boolean Object.equals(Object other), and public int Object.hashCode(), or override neither. Even if you are inheriting a hashCode() from a parent class, consider implementing hashCode and explicitly delegating to your superclass.

Example(s):

public class Bar {        // poor, missing a hashcode() method
    public boolean equals(Object o) {
      // do some comparison
    }
}

public class Baz {        // poor, missing an equals() method
    public int hashCode() {
      // return some hash value
    }
}

public class Foo {        // perfect, both methods provided
    public boolean equals(Object other) {
      // do some comparison
    }
    public int hashCode() {
      // return some hash value
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Use one line for each declaration, it enhances code readability.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: One Declaration Per Line

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Java allows the use of several variables declaration of the same type on one line. However, it can lead to quite messy code. This rule looks for several declarations on the same line.

Example(s):

String name;            // separate declarations
String lastname;

String name, lastname;  // combined declaration, a violation

String name,
       lastname;        // combined declaration on multiple lines, no violation by default.
                        // Set property strictMode to true to mark this as violation.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A method should have only one exit point, and that should be the last statement in the method

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Only One Return

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: This call to Collection.toArray() may be optimizable

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Optimizable To Array Call

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Calls to a collection’s toArray(E[]) method should specify a target array of zero size. This allows the JVM to optimize the memory allocation and copying as much as possible.

Previous versions of this rule (pre PMD 6.0.0) suggested the opposite, but current JVM implementations perform always better, when they have full control over the target array. And allocation an array via reflection is nowadays as fast as the direct allocation.

See also Arrays of Wisdom of the Ancients

Note: If you don’t need an array of the correct type, then the simple toArray() method without an array is faster, but returns only an array of type Object[].

Example(s):

List<Foo> foos = getFoos();

// much better; this one allows the jvm to allocate an array of the correct size and effectively skip
// the zeroing, since each array element will be overridden anyways
Foo[] fooArray = foos.toArray(new Foo[0]);

// inefficient, the array needs to be zeroed out by the jvm before it is handed over to the toArray method
Foo[] fooArray = foos.toArray(new Foo[foos.size()]);

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Package name contains upper case characters

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Package Case

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Detects when a package definition contains uppercase characters.

Example(s):

package com.MyCompany;  // should be lowercase name

public class SomeClass {
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Object clone() should be implemented with super.clone()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Proper Clone Implementation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Object clone() should be implemented with super.clone().

Example(s):

class Foo{
    public Object clone(){
        return new Foo(); // This is bad
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid declaring a variable if it is unreferenced before a possible exit point.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Premature Declaration

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Logger should be defined private static final and have the correct class

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Proper Logger

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A logger should normally be defined private static final and be associated with the correct class. private final Log log; is also allowed for rare cases where loggers need to be passed around, with the restriction that the logger needs to be passed into the constructor.

Example(s):

public class Foo {

    private static final Log LOG = LogFactory.getLog(Foo.class);    // proper way

    protected Log LOG = LogFactory.getLog(Testclass.class);         // wrong approach
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Position literals first in String comparisons

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Position Literals First In Comparisons

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Position literals first in String comparisons for EqualsIgnoreCase

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Position Literals First In Case Insensitive Comparisons

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: New exception is thrown in catch block, original stack trace may be lost

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Preserve Stack Trace

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Throwing a new exception from a catch block without passing the original exception into the new exception will cause the original stack trace to be lost making it difficult to debug effectively.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    void good() {
        try{
            Integer.parseInt("a");
        } catch (Exception e) {
            throw new Exception(e); // first possibility to create exception chain
        }
        try {
            Integer.parseInt("a");
        } catch (Exception e) {
            throw (IllegalStateException)new IllegalStateException().initCause(e); // second possibility to create exception chain.
        }
    }
    void bad() {
        try{
            Integer.parseInt("a");
        } catch (Exception e) {
            throw new Exception(e.getMessage());
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Return an empty array rather than 'null'.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Return Empty Array Rather Than Null

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
For any method that returns an array, it is a better to return an empty array rather than a null reference. This removes the need for null checking all results and avoids inadvertent NullPointerExceptions.

Example(s):

public class Example {
    // Not a good idea...
    public int[] badBehavior() {
        // ...
        return null;
    }

    // Good behavior
    public String[] bonnePratique() {
        //...
        return new String[0];
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Consider replacing this Enumeration with the newer java.util.Iterator

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Replace Enumeration With Iterator

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid returning from a finally block

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Return From Finally Block

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid returning from a finally block, this can discard exceptions.

Example(s):

public class Bar {
    public String foo() {
        try {
            throw new Exception( "My Exception" );
        } catch (Exception e) {
            throw e;
        } finally {
            return "A. O. K."; // return not recommended here
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid using redundant field initializer for ''${variableName}''

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Redundant Field Initializer

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Java will initialize fields with known default values so any explicit initialization of those same defaults is redundant and results in a larger class file (approximately three additional bytecode instructions per field).

Example(s):

public class C {
    boolean b   = false;    // examples of redundant initializers
    byte by     = 0;
    short s     = 0;
    char c      = 0;
    int i       = 0;
    long l      = 0;

    float f     = .0f;    // all possible float literals
    doable d    = 0d;     // all possible double literals
    Object o    = null;

    MyClass mca[] = null;
    int i1 = 0, ia1[] = null;

    class Nested {
        boolean b = false;
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Consider replacing this Hashtable with the newer java.util.Map

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Replace Hashtable With Map

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Remote Interface of a Session EJB should NOT be suffixed

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Remote Interface Naming Convention

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Remote Interface of a Session EJB should not have a suffix.

Example(s):

/* Poor Session suffix */
public interface BadSuffixSession extends javax.ejb.EJBObject {}

/* Poor EJB suffix */
public interface BadSuffixEJB extends javax.ejb.EJBObject {}

/* Poor Bean suffix */
public interface BadSuffixBean extends javax.ejb.EJBObject {}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Remote Home interface of a Session EJB should be suffixed by 'Home'

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Remote Session Interface Naming Convention

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A Remote Home interface type of a Session EJB should be suffixed by ‘Home’.

Example(s):

public interface MyBeautifulHome extends javax.ejb.EJBHome {}       // proper name

public interface MissingProperSuffix extends javax.ejb.EJBHome {}   // non-standard name

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Consider replacing this Vector with the newer java.util.List

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Replace Vector With List

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: assertTrue(!expr) can be replaced by assertFalse(expr)

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Simplify Boolean Assertion

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid negation in an assertTrue or assertFalse test.

For example, rephrase:

assertTrue(!expr);

as:

assertFalse(expr);

Example(s):

public class SimpleTest extends TestCase {
    public void testX() {
        assertTrue("not empty", !r.isEmpty());  // replace with assertFalse("not empty", r.isEmpty())
        assertFalse(!r.isEmpty());              // replace with assertTrue(r.isEmpty())
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid unnecessary comparisons in boolean expressions

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Simplify Boolean Expressions

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid unnecessary comparisons in boolean expressions, they serve no purpose and impacts readability.

Example(s):

public class Bar {
  // can be simplified to
  // bar = isFoo();
  private boolean bar = (isFoo() == true);

  public isFoo() { return false;}
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Do not instantiate a StringBuffer or StringBuilder with a char

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: String Buffer Instantiation With Char

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Individual character values provided as initialization arguments will be converted into integers. This can lead to internal buffer sizes that are larger than expected. Some examples:

new StringBuffer()      //  16
new StringBuffer(6)     //  6
new StringBuffer("hello world")  // 11 + 16 = 27
new StringBuffer('A')   //  chr(A) = 65
new StringBuffer("A")   //  1 + 16 = 17

new StringBuilder()     //  16
new StringBuilder(6)    //  6
new StringBuilder("hello world")  // 11 + 16 = 27
new StringBuilder('C')   //  chr(C) = 67
new StringBuilder("A")   //  1 + 16 = 17

Example(s):

// misleading instantiation, these buffers
// are actually sized to 99 characters long
StringBuffer  sb1 = new StringBuffer('c');
StringBuilder sb2 = new StringBuilder('c');

// in these forms, just single characters are allocated
StringBuffer  sb3 = new StringBuffer("c");
StringBuilder sb4 = new StringBuilder("c");

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid unnecessary if..then..else statements when returning booleans

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Simplify Boolean Returns

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid unnecessary if-then-else statements when returning a boolean. The result of the conditional test can be returned instead.

Example(s):

public boolean isBarEqualTo(int x) {
    if (bar == x) {      // this bit of code...
        return true;
    } else {
        return false;
    }
}

public boolean isBarEqualTo(int x) {
    return bar == x;    // can be replaced with this
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: No need to check for null before an instanceof

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Simplify Conditional

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
No need to check for null before an instanceof; the instanceof keyword returns false when given a null argument.

Example(s):

class Foo {
  void bar(Object x) {
    if (x != null && x instanceof Bar) {
      // just drop the "x != null" check
    }
  }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The {0} ''{1}'' has a Standard Cyclomatic Complexity of {2}.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Std Cyclomatic Complexity

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: The field name indicates a constant but its modifiers do not

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Suspicious Constant Field Name

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Field names using all uppercase characters - Sun’s Java naming conventions indicating constants - should be declared as final.

This rule is deprecated and will be removed with PMD 7.0.0. The rule is replaced by the more general rule Field Naming Conventions.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
 // this is bad, since someone could accidentally
 // do PI = 2.71828; which is actually e
 // final double PI = 3.16; is ok
  double PI = 3.16;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid short class names like {0}

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Short Class Name

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Short Classnames with fewer than e.g. five characters are not recommended.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: getInstance method always creates a new object and hence does not comply to Singleton Design Pattern behaviour. Please review

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Singleton Class Returning New Instance

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Some classes contain overloaded getInstance. The problem with overloaded getInstance methods is that the instance created using the overloaded method is not cached and so, for each call and new objects will be created for every invocation.

Example(s):

class Singleton {
    private static Singleton instance = null;
    public static Singleton getInstance() {
        synchronized(Singleton.class) {
            return new Singleton();
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A high ratio of statements to labels in a switch statement. Consider refactoring.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Switch Density

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: When instantiating a SimpleDateFormat object, specify a Locale

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Simple Date Format Needs Locale

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Be sure to specify a Locale when creating SimpleDateFormat instances to ensure that locale-appropriate formatting is used.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  // Should specify Locale.US (or whatever)
  private SimpleDateFormat sdf = new SimpleDateFormat("pattern");
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: EJB's shouldn't have non-final static fields

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Static EJBField Should Be Final

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
According to the J2EE specification, an EJB should not have any static fields with write access. However, static read-only fields are allowed. This ensures proper behavior especially when instances are distributed by the container on several JREs.

Example(s):

public class SomeEJB extends EJBObject implements EJBLocalHome {

    private static int CountA;          // poor, field can be edited

    private static final int CountB;    // preferred, read-only access
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The method name and parameter number are suspiciously close to equals(Object)

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Suspicious Equals Method Name

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The method name and parameter number are suspiciously close to Object.equals, which can denote an intention to override it. However, the method does not override Object.equals, but overloads it instead. Overloading Object.equals method is confusing for other programmers, error-prone and hard to maintain, especially when using inheritance, because @Override annotations used in subclasses can provide a false sense of security. For more information on Object.equals method, see Effective Java, 3rd Edition, Item 10: Obey the general contract when overriding equals.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
   public int equals(Object o) {
     // oops, this probably was supposed to be boolean equals
   }
   public boolean equals(String s) {
     // oops, this probably was supposed to be equals(Object)
   }
   public boolean equals(Object o1, Object o2) {
     // oops, this probably was supposed to be equals(Object)
   }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Perhaps ''{0}'' could be replaced by a local variable.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Singular Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Fields whose scopes are limited to just single methods do not rely on the containing object to provide them to other methods. They may be better implemented as local variables within those methods.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    private int x;  // no reason to exist at the Foo instance level
    public void foo(int y) {
     x = y + 5;
     return x;
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The method name and return type are suspiciously close to hashCode()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Suspicious Hashcode Method Name

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The method name and return type are suspiciously close to hashCode(), which may denote an intention to override the hashCode() method.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    public int hashcode() { // oops, this probably was supposed to be 'hashCode'
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid instantiating Short objects. Call Short.valueOf() instead

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Short Instantiation

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid using short method names

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Short Method Name

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Method names that are very short are not helpful to the reader.

Example(s):

public class ShortMethod {
    public void a( int i ) { // Violation
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Class contains multiple getInstance methods. Please review.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Single Method Singleton

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Some classes contain overloaded getInstance. The problem with overloaded getInstance methods is that the instance created using the overloaded method is not cached and so, for each call and new objects will be created for every invocation.

Example(s):

public class Singleton {

    private static Singleton singleton = new Singleton( );

    private Singleton(){ }

    public static Singleton getInstance( ) {
        return singleton;
    }

    public static Singleton getInstance(Object obj){
        Singleton singleton = (Singleton) obj;
        return singleton;           //violation
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Suspicious decimal characters following octal escape in string literal

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Suspicious Octal Escape

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A suspicious octal escape sequence was found inside a String literal. The Java language specification (section 3.10.6) says an octal escape sequence inside a literal String shall consist of a backslash followed by:

OctalDigit | OctalDigit OctalDigit | ZeroToThree OctalDigit OctalDigit

Any octal escape sequence followed by non-octal digits can be confusing, e.g. “38” is interpreted as the octal escape sequence “3” followed by the literal character “8”.

Example(s):

public void foo() {
  // interpreted as octal 12, followed by character '8'
  System.out.println("suspicious: \128");
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: {0} is used

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: System Println

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
References to System.(out|err).print are usually intended for debugging purposes and can remain in the codebase even in production code. By using a logger one can enable/disable this behaviour at will (and by priority) and avoid clogging the Standard out log.

Example(s):

class Foo{
    Logger log = Logger.getLogger(Foo.class.getName());
    public void testA () {
        System.out.println("Entering test");
        // Better use this
        log.fine("Entering test");
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Switch statements should have a default label

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Switch Stmts Should Have Default

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
All switch statements should include a default option to catch any unspecified values.

Example(s):

public void bar() {
    int x = 2;
    switch (x) {
      case 1: int j = 6;
      case 2: int j = 8;
          // missing default: here
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: This call to String.startsWith can be rewritten using String.charAt(0)

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Simplify Starts With

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Ternary operators that can be simplified with || or &&

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Simplified Ternary

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Look for ternary operators with the form condition ? literalBoolean : foo or condition ? foo : literalBoolean.

These expressions can be simplified respectively to condition || foo when the literalBoolean is true !condition && foo when the literalBoolean is false or !condition || foo when the literalBoolean is true condition && foo when the literalBoolean is false

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    public boolean test() {
        return condition ? true : something(); // can be as simple as return condition || something();
    }

    public void test2() {
        final boolean value = condition ? false : something(); // can be as simple as value = !condition && something();
    }

    public boolean test3() {
        return condition ? something() : true; // can be as simple as return !condition || something();
    }

    public void test4() {
        final boolean otherValue = condition ? something() : false; // can be as simple as condition && something();
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid calling toString() on String objects; this is unnecessary.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: String To String

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid calling toString() on objects already known to be string instances; this is unnecessary.

Example(s):

private String baz() {
    String bar = "howdy";
    return bar.toString();
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid variables with short names like {0}

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Short Variable

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: A method/constructor should not explicitly throw java.lang.Exception

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Signature Declare Throws Exception

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A method/constructor shouldn’t explicitly throw the generic java.lang.Exception, since it is unclear which exceptions that can be thrown from the methods. It might be difficult to document and understand such vague interfaces. Use either a class derived from RuntimeException or a checked exception.

Example(s):

public void foo() throws Exception {
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid instantiating String objects; this is usually unnecessary.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: String Instantiation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid instantiating String objects; this is usually unnecessary since they are immutable and can be safely shared.

Example(s):

private String bar = new String("bar"); // just do a String bar = "bar";

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: This class name ends with 'Test' but contains no test cases

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Test Class Without Test Cases

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Test classes end with the suffix Test. Having a non-test class with that name is not a good practice, since most people will assume it is a test case. Test classes have test methods named testXXX.

Example(s):

//Consider changing the name of the class if it is not a test
//Consider adding test methods if it is a test
public class CarTest {
   public static void main(String[] args) {
    // do something
   }
   // code
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: A switch with less than three branches is inefficient, use a 'if statement' instead.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Too Few Branches For ASwitch Statement

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Switch statements are intended to be used to support complex branching behaviour. Using a switch for only a few cases is ill-advised, since switches are not as easy to understand as if-then statements. In these cases use the if-then statement to increase code readability.

Example(s):

// With a minimumNumberCaseForASwitch of 3
public class Foo {
    public void bar() {
        switch (condition) {
            case ONE:
                instruction;
                break;
            default:
                break; // not enough for a 'switch' stmt, a simple 'if' stmt would have been more appropriate
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Too many fields

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Too Many Fields

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: This class has too many methods, consider refactoring it.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Too Many Methods

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value: A class with too many methods is probably a good suspect for refactoring, in order to reduce its complexity and find a way to have more fine grained objects.

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Too many static imports may lead to messy code

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Too Many Static Imports

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
If you overuse the static import feature, it can make your program unreadable and unmaintainable, polluting its namespace with all the static members you import. Readers of your code (including you, a few months after you wrote it) will not know which class a static member comes from (Sun 1.5 Language Guide).

Example(s):

import static Lennon;
import static Ringo;
import static George;
import static Paul;
import static Yoko; // Too much !

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The value assigned to this variable is never used or always overwritten

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unused Assignment

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Reports assignments to variables that are never used before the variable is overwritten, or goes out of scope. Unused assignments are those for which 1. The variable is never read after the assignment, or 2. The assigned value is always overwritten by other assignments before the next read of the variable.

        The rule doesn't consider assignments to fields except for those of `this` in a constructor,
        or static fields of the current class in static initializers.

        The rule may be suppressed with the standard `@SuppressWarnings("unused")` tag.

        The rule subsumes {% rule "UnusedLocalVariable" %}, and {% rule "UnusedFormalParameter" %}.
        Those violations are filtered
        out by default, in case you already have enabled those rules, but may be enabled with the property
        `reportUnusedVariables`. Variables whose name starts with `ignored` or `unused` are filtered out, as
        is standard practice for exceptions.

        Limitations:
        * The rule currently cannot know which method calls throw exceptions, or which exceptions they throw.
        In the body of a try block, every method or constructor call is assumed to throw.  This may cause false-negatives.
        The only other language construct that is assumed to throw is the `throw` statement, in particular,
        things like `assert` statements, or NullPointerExceptions on dereference are ignored.
        * The rule cannot resolve assignments across constructors, when they're called with the special
        `this(...)` syntax. This may cause false-negatives.

        Both of those limitations may be partly relaxed in PMD 7.

Example(s):

class A {
                // this field initializer is redundant,
                // it is always overwritten in the constructor
                int f = 1;

                A(int f) {
                    this.f = f;
                }
            }
class B {

    int method(int i, int j) {
        // this initializer is redundant,
        // it is overwritten in all branches of the `if`
        int k = 0;

        // Both the assignments to k are unused, because k is
        // not read after the if/else
        // This may hide a bug: the programmer probably wanted to return k
        if (i < j)
            k = i;
        else
            k = j;

        return j;
    }

}
class C {

    int method() {
        int i = 0;

        checkSomething(++i);
        checkSomething(++i);
        checkSomething(++i);
        checkSomething(++i);

        // That last increment is not reported unless
        // the property `checkUnusedPrefixIncrement` is
        // set to `true`
        // Technically it could be written (i+1), but it
        // is not very important
    }

}
class C {

    // variables that are truly unused (at most assigned to, but never accessed)
    // are only reported if property `reportUnusedVariables` is true

    void method(int param) { } // for example this method parameter

    // even then, you can suppress the violation with an annotation:

    void method(@SuppressWarning("unused") int param) { } // no violation, even if `reportUnusedVariables` is true

    // For catch parameters, or for resources which don't need to be used explicitly,
    // you can give a name that starts with "ignored" to ignore such warnings

    {
        try (Something ignored = Something.create()) {
            // even if ignored is unused, it won't be flagged
            // its purpose might be to side-effect in the create/close routines

        } catch (Exception e) { // this is unused and will cause a warning if `reportUnusedVariables` is true
            // you should choose a name that starts with "ignored"
            return;
        }
    }

}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Use asList instead of tight loops

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Arrays As List

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The java.util.Arrays class has a “asList” method that should be used when you want to create a new List from an array of objects. It is faster than executing a loop to copy all the elements of the array one by one.

Note that the result of Arrays.asList() is backed by the specified array, changes in the returned list will result in the array to be modified. For that reason, it is not possible to add new elements to the returned list of Arrays.asList() (UnsupportedOperationException). You must use new ArrayList<>(Arrays.asList(…)) if that is inconvenient for you (e.g. because of concurrent access).

Example(s):

public class Test {
    public void foo(Integer[] ints) {
        // could just use Arrays.asList(ints)
        List<Integer> l= new ArrayList<>(100);
        for (int i=0; i< 100; i++) {
            l.add(ints[i]);
        }
        for (int i=0; i< 100; i++) {
            l.add(a[i].toString()); // won't trigger the rule
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Use assertEquals(x, y) instead of assertTrue(x.equals(y))

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Assert Equals Instead Of Assert True

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This rule detects JUnit assertions in object equality. These assertions should be made by more specific methods, like assertEquals.

Example(s):

public class FooTest extends TestCase {
    void testCode() {
        Object a, b;
        assertTrue(a.equals(b));                    // bad usage
        assertEquals("a should equals b", a, b);    // good usage
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Use ArrayList instead of Vector

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Array List Instead Of Vector

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
ArrayList is a much better Collection implementation than Vector if thread-safe operation is not required.

Example(s):

public class SimpleTest extends TestCase {
    public void testX() {
    Collection c1 = new Vector();
    Collection c2 = new ArrayList();    // achieves the same with much better performance
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Use assertNull(x) instead of assertTrue(x==null), or assertNotNull(x) vs assertFalse(x==null)

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Assert Null Instead Of Assert True

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This rule detects JUnit assertions in object references equality. These assertions should be made by more specific methods, like assertNull, assertNotNull.

Example(s):

public class FooTest extends TestCase {
    void testCode() {
        Object a = doSomething();
        assertTrue(a==null);    // bad usage
        assertNull(a);          // good usage
        assertTrue(a != null);  // bad usage
        assertNotNull(a);       // good usage
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Use assertSame(x, y) instead of assertTrue(x==y), or assertNotSame(x,y) vs assertFalse(x==y)

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Assert Same Instead Of Assert True

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This rule detects JUnit assertions in object references equality. These assertions should be made by more specific methods, like assertSame, assertNotSame.

Example(s):

public class FooTest extends TestCase {
    void testCode() {
        Object a, b;
        assertTrue(a == b); // bad usage
        assertSame(a, b);   // good usage
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Use assertTrue(x)/assertFalse(x) instead of assertEquals(true, x)/assertEquals(false, x) or assertEquals(Boolean.TRUE, x)/assertEquals(Boolean.FALSE, x).

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Assert True Instead Of Assert Equals

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
When asserting a value is the same as a literal or Boxed boolean, use assertTrue/assertFalse, instead of assertEquals.

Example(s):

public class MyTestCase extends TestCase {
    public void testMyCase() {
        boolean myVar = true;
        // Ok
        assertTrue("myVar is true", myVar);
        // Bad
        assertEquals("myVar is true", true, myVar);
        // Bad
        assertEquals("myVar is false", false, myVar);
        // Bad
        assertEquals("myVar is true", Boolean.TRUE, myVar);
        // Bad
        assertEquals("myVar is false", Boolean.FALSE, myVar);
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid the use of value in annotations when it's the only element

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unnecessary Annotation Value Element

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid the use of value in annotations when it’s the only element.

Example(s):

@TestClassAnnotation(value = "TEST")
public class Foo {

    @TestMemberAnnotation(value = "TEST")
    private String y;

    @TestMethodAnnotation(value = "TEST")
    public void bar() {
        int x = 42;
        return;
    }
}

// should be

@TestClassAnnotation("TEST")
public class Foo {

    @TestMemberAnnotation("TEST")
    private String y;

    @TestMethodAnnotation("TEST")
    public void bar() {
        int x = 42;
        return;
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: assertTrue(true) or similar statements are unnecessary

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unnecessary Boolean Assertion

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
A JUnit test assertion with a boolean literal is unnecessary since it always will evaluate to the same thing. Consider using flow control (in case of assertTrue(false) or similar) or simply removing statements like assertTrue(true) and assertFalse(false). If you just want a test to halt after finding an error, use the fail() method and provide an indication message of why it did.

Example(s):

public class SimpleTest extends TestCase {
    public void testX() {
        assertTrue(true);       // serves no real purpose
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid unnecessary constructors - the compiler will generate these for you

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unnecessary Constructor

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This rule detects when a constructor is not necessary; i.e., when there is only one constructor and the constructor is identical to the default constructor. The default constructor should has same access modifier as the declaring class. In an enum type, the default constructor is implicitly private.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
  public Foo() {}
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Using equalsIgnoreCase() is cleaner than using toUpperCase/toLowerCase().equals().

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unnecessary Case Change

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Using equalsIgnoreCase() is faster than using toUpperCase/toLowerCase().equals()

Example(s):

boolean answer1 = buz.toUpperCase().equals("baz");              // should be buz.equalsIgnoreCase("baz")

boolean answer2 = buz.toUpperCase().equalsIgnoreCase("baz");    // another unnecessary toUpperCase()

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Use the correct logging statement for logging exceptions

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Correct Exception Logging

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
To make sure the full stacktrace is printed out, use the logging statement with two arguments: a String and a Throwable.

Example(s):

public class Main {
    private static final Log _LOG = LogFactory.getLog( Main.class );
    void bar() {
        try {
        } catch( Exception e ) {
            _LOG.error( e ); //Wrong!
        } catch( OtherException oe ) {
            _LOG.error( oe.getMessage(), oe ); //Correct
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: If you run in Java5 or newer and have concurrent access, you should use the ConcurrentHashMap implementation

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Concurrent Hash Map

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Substitute calls to size() == 0 (or size() != 0, size() > 0, size() < 1) with calls to isEmpty()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Collection Is Empty

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The isEmpty() method on java.util.Collection is provided to determine if a collection has any elements. Comparing the value of size() to 0 does not convey intent as well as the isEmpty() method.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    void good() {
        List foo = getList();
        if (foo.isEmpty()) {
            // blah
        }
    }

    void bad() {
        List foo = getList();
        if (foo.size() == 0) {
            // blah
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid unnecessary temporaries when converting primitives to Strings

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unnecessary Conversion Temporary

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid the use temporary objects when converting primitives to Strings. Use the static conversion methods on the wrapper classes instead.

Example(s):

public String convert(int x) {
    String foo = new Integer(x).toString(); // this wastes an object

    return Integer.toString(x);             // preferred approach
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Explicit type arguments can be replaced by Diamond Operator

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Diamond Operator

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Use the diamond operator to let the type be inferred automatically. With the Diamond operator it is possible to avoid duplication of the type parameters. Instead, the compiler is now able to infer the parameter types for constructor calls, which makes the code also more readable.

The diamond operator has been introduced with java 7. However, type inference has been improved further with java8, rendering more type parameters unnecessary. This is only possible with java8 and the resulting code won’t compile with java7. If you use java7, make sure to enable java7Compatibility for this rule to avoid false positives.

Example(s):

List<String> strings = new ArrayList<String>(); // unnecessary duplication of type parameters
List<String> stringsWithDiamond = new ArrayList<>(); // using the diamond operator is more concise

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Document empty constructor

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Uncommented Empty Constructor

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Uncommented Empty Constructor finds instances where a constructor does not contain statements, but there is no comment. By explicitly commenting empty constructors it is easier to distinguish between intentional (commented) and unintentional empty constructors.

Example(s):

public Foo() {
  // This constructor is intentionally empty. Nothing special is needed here.
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Document empty method body

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Uncommented Empty Method Body

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Uncommented Empty Method Body finds instances where a method body does not contain statements, but there is no comment. By explicitly commenting empty method bodies it is easier to distinguish between intentional (commented) and unintentional empty methods.

Example(s):

public void doSomething() {
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Use equals() to compare strings instead of ''=='' or ''!=''

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Equals To Compare Strings

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Using ‘==’ or ‘!=’ to compare strings only works if intern version is used on both sides. Use the equals() method instead.

Example(s):

public boolean test(String s) {
    if (s == "one") return true;        // unreliable
    if ("two".equals(s)) return true;   // better
    return false;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid unused {0} parameters such as ''{1}''.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unused Formal Parameter

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Unnecessary use of fully qualified name ''{0}'' due to existing {2}import ''{1}''

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unnecessary Fully Qualified Name

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Import statements allow the use of non-fully qualified names. The use of a fully qualified name which is covered by an import statement is redundant. Consider using the non-fully qualified name.

Example(s):

import java.util.List;

public class Foo {
    private java.util.List list1;   // Unnecessary FQN
    private List list2;             // More appropriate given import of 'java.util.List'
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: String.indexOf(char) is faster than String.indexOf(String).

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Index Of Char

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid memory intensive FileItem.get() or FileItem.getString()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use IOStreams With Apache Commons File Item

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Problem: Use of FileItem.get() and FileItem.getString() could exhaust memory since they load the entire file into memory.

Solution: Use FileItem.getInputStream() and buffering.

Example(s):

import org.apache.commons.fileupload.FileItem;

public class FileStuff {
   private String bad(FileItem fileItem) {
        return fileItem.getString();
   }

   private InputStream good(FileItem fileItem) {
        return fileItem.getInputStream();
   }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Do not use 'if' statements that are always true or always false

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unconditional If Statement

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Do not use “if” statements whose conditionals are always true or always false.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    public void close() {
        if (true) {        // fixed conditional, not recommended
            // ...
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Consider simply returning the value vs storing it in local variable ''{0}''

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unnecessary Local Before Return

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid the creation of unnecessary local variables

Example(s):

public class Foo {
   public int foo() {
     int x = doSomething();
     return x;  // instead, just 'return doSomething();'
   }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid unused local variables such as ''{0}''.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unused Local Variable

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Detects when a local variable is declared and/or assigned, but not used. Variables whose name starts with ignored or unused are filtered out.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    public void doSomething() {
        int i = 5; // Unused
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: When doing a String.toLowerCase()/toUpperCase() call, use a Locale

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Locale With Case Conversions

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
When doing String::toLowerCase()/toUpperCase() conversions, use an explicit locale argument to specify the case transformation rules.

        Using `String::toLowerCase()` without arguments implicitly uses `Locale::getDefault()`.
        The problem is that the default locale depends on the current JVM setup (and usually on the system in which it is running).
        Using the system default may be exactly what you want (e.g. if you are manipulating strings you got through standard input),
        but it may as well not be the case (e.g. if you are getting the string over the network or a file, and the encoding is well-defined
        and independent of the environment). In the latter case, using the default locale makes the case transformation brittle, as
        it may yield unexpected results on a machine whose locale has other case translation rules. For example, in Turkish, the
        uppercase form of `i` is `İ` (U+0130, not ASCII) and not `I` (U+0049) as in English.

        The rule is intended to *force* developers to think about locales when dealing with strings. By taking a conscious decision about
        the choice of locale at the time of writing, you reduce the risk of surprising behaviour down the line, and communicate your intent
        to future readers.

Example(s):

// violation - implicitly system-dependent conversion
if (x.toLowerCase().equals("list")) {}

// The above will not match "LIST" on a system with a Turkish locale.
// It could be replaced with
if (x.toLowerCase(Locale.US).equals("list")) { }
// or simply
if (x.equalsIgnoreCase("list")) { }

// ok - system independent conversion
String z = a.toLowerCase(Locale.ROOT);

// ok - explicit system-dependent conversion
String z2 = a.toLowerCase(Locale.getDefault());

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Call Thread.notifyAll() rather than Thread.notify()

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Notify All Instead Of Notify

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Thread.notify() awakens a thread monitoring the object. If more than one thread is monitoring, then only one is chosen. The thread chosen is arbitrary; thus its usually safer to call notifyAll() instead.

Example(s):

void bar() {
    x.notify();
    // If many threads are monitoring x, only one (and you won't know which) will be notified.
    // use instead:
    x.notifyAll();
  }

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Invoke equals() on the object you''ve already ensured is not null

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unused Null Check In Equals

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
After checking an object reference for null, you should invoke equals() on that object rather than passing it to another object’s equals() method.

Example(s):

public class Test {

    public String method1() { return "ok";}
    public String method2() { return null;}

    public void method(String a) {
        String b;
        // I don't know it method1() can be "null"
        // but I know "a" is not null..
        // I'd better write a.equals(method1())

        if (a!=null && method1().equals(a)) { // will trigger the rule
            //whatever
        }

        if (method1().equals(a) && a != null) { // won't trigger the rule
            //whatever
        }

        if (a!=null && method1().equals(b)) { // won't trigger the rule
            //whatever
        }

        if (a!=null && "LITERAL".equals(a)) { // won't trigger the rule
            //whatever
        }

        if (a!=null && !a.equals("go")) { // won't trigger the rule
            a=method2();
            if (method1().equals(a)) {
                //whatever
            }
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Rather than using a lot of String arguments, consider using a container object for those values.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Object For Clearer API

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Overriding method merely calls super

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Useless Overriding Method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The overriding method merely calls the same method defined in a superclass.

Example(s):

public void foo(String bar) {
    super.foo(bar);      // why bother overriding?
}

public String foo() {
    return super.foo();  // why bother overriding?
}

@Id
public Long getId() {
    return super.getId();  // OK if 'ignoreAnnotations' is false, which is the default behavior
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: An operation on an Immutable object (String, BigDecimal or BigInteger) won't change the object itself

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Useless Operation On Immutable

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
An operation on an Immutable object (String, BigDecimal or BigInteger) won’t change the object itself since the result of the operation is a new object. Therefore, ignoring the operation result is an error.

Example(s):

import java.math.*;

class Test {
    void method1() {
        BigDecimal bd=new BigDecimal(10);
        bd.add(new BigDecimal(5));      // this will trigger the rule
    }
    void method2() {
        BigDecimal bd=new BigDecimal(10);
        bd = bd.add(new BigDecimal(5)); // this won't trigger the rule
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: In J2EE, getClassLoader() might not work as expected. Use Thread.currentThread().getContextClassLoader() instead.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Proper Class Loader

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid unused private fields such as ''{0}''.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unused Private Field

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Detects when a private field is declared and/or assigned a value, but not used.

Example(s):

public class Something {
    private static int FOO = 2; // Unused
    private int i = 5; // Unused
    private int j = 6;
    public int addOne() {
        return j++;
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid unused private methods such as ''{0}''.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unused Private Method

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Unused Private Method detects when a private method is declared but is unused.

Example(s):

public class Something {
    private void foo() {} // unused
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Useless qualified this usage in the same class.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Useless Qualified This

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Reports qualified this usages in the same class.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    final Foo otherFoo = Foo.this;  // use "this" directly

    public void doSomething() {
         final Foo anotherFoo = Foo.this;  // use "this" directly
    }

    private ActionListener returnListener() {
        return new ActionListener() {
            @Override
            public void actionPerformed(ActionEvent e) {
                doSomethingWithQualifiedThis(Foo.this);  // This is fine
            }
        };
    }

    private class Foo3 {
        final Foo myFoo = Foo.this;  // This is fine
    }

    private class Foo2 {
        final Foo2 myFoo2 = Foo2.this;  // Use "this" direclty
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid unnecessary return statements

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unnecessary Return

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Array initialization can be written shorter

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Short Array Initializer

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
When declaring and initializing array fields or variables, it is not necessary to explicitly create a new array using new. Instead one can simply define the initial content of the array as a expression in curly braces.

E.g. int[] x = new int[] { 1, 2, 3 }; can be written as int[] x = { 1, 2, 3 };.

Example(s):

Foo[] x = new Foo[] { ... }; // Overly verbose
Foo[] x = { ... }; //Equivalent to above line

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Prefer StringBuilder (non-synchronized) or StringBuffer (synchronized) over += for concatenating strings

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use String Buffer For String Appends

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
The use of the ‘+=’ operator for appending strings causes the JVM to create and use an internal StringBuffer. If a non-trivial number of these concatenations are being used then the explicit use of a StringBuilder or threadsafe StringBuffer is recommended to avoid this.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    void bar() {
        String a;
        a = "foo";
        a += " bar";
        // better would be:
        // StringBuilder a = new StringBuilder("foo");
        // a.append(" bar");
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: This is an inefficient use of StringBuffer.toString; call StringBuffer.length instead.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use String Buffer Length

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Use StringBuffer.length() to determine StringBuffer length rather than using StringBuffer.toString().equals("") or StringBuffer.toString().length() == ...
Example(s):
```java StringBuffer sb = new StringBuffer();
if (sb.toString().equals("")) {} // inefficient
if (sb.length() == 0) {} // preferred ```

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Static DateFormatter objects should be accessed in a synchronized manner

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unsynchronized Static Date Formatter

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
SimpleDateFormat instances are not synchronized. Sun recommends using separate format instances for each thread. If multiple threads must access a static formatter, the formatter must be synchronized on block level.

This rule has been deprecated in favor of the rule Unsynchronized Static Formatter.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    private static final SimpleDateFormat sdf = new SimpleDateFormat();
    void bar() {
        sdf.format(); // poor, no thread-safety
    }
    void foo() {
        synchronized (sdf) { // preferred
            sdf.format();
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Static Formatter objects should be accessed in a synchronized manner

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unsynchronized Static Formatter

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Instances of java.text.Format are generally not synchronized. Sun recommends using separate format instances for each thread. If multiple threads must access a static formatter, the formatter must be synchronized on block level.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    private static final SimpleDateFormat sdf = new SimpleDateFormat();
    void bar() {
        sdf.format(); // poor, no thread-safety
    }
    void foo() {
        synchronized (sdf) { // preferred
            sdf.format();
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: No need to call String.valueOf to append to a string.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Useless String Value Of

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Consider using a try-with-resources statement instead of explicitly closing the resource

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Try With Resources

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Java 7 introduced the try-with-resources statement. This statement ensures that each resource is closed at the end of the statement. It avoids the need of explicitly closing the resources in a finally block. Additionally exceptions are better handled: If an exception occurred both in the try block and finally block, then the exception from the try block was suppressed. With the try-with-resources statement, the exception thrown from the try-block is preserved.

Example(s):

public class TryWithResources {
    public void run() {
        InputStream in = null;
        try {
            in = openInputStream();
            int i = in.read();
        } catch (IOException e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        } finally {
            try {
                if (in != null) in.close();
            } catch (IOException ignored) {
                // ignored
            }
        }

        // better use try-with-resources
        try (InputStream in2 = openInputStream()) {
            int i = in2.read();
        }
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: All methods are static. Consider using a utility class instead. Alternatively, you could add a private constructor or make the class abstract to silence this warning.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Utility Class

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Number {0} should separate every third digit with an underscore

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Underscores In Numeric Literals

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Since Java 1.7, numeric literals can use underscores to separate digits. This rule enforces that numeric literals above a certain length use these underscores to increase readability.

        The rule only supports decimal (base 10) literals for now. The acceptable length under which literals
        are not required to have underscores is configurable via a property. Even under that length, underscores
        that are misplaced (not making groups of 3 digits) are reported.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    private int num = 1000000; // should be 1_000_000
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Consider using varargs for methods or constructors which take an array the last parameter.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Use Varargs

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Java 5 introduced the varargs parameter declaration for methods and constructors. This syntactic sugar provides flexibility for users of these methods and constructors, allowing them to avoid having to deal with the creation of an array.

Example(s):

public class Foo {
    public void foo(String s, Object[] args) {
        // Do something here...
    }

    public void bar(String s, Object... args) {
        // Ahh, varargs tastes much better...
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Unnecessary wrapper object creation

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unnecessary Wrapper Object Creation

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Most wrapper classes provide static conversion methods that avoid the need to create intermediate objects just to create the primitive forms. Using these avoids the cost of creating objects that also need to be garbage-collected later.

Example(s):

public int convert(String s) {
    int i, i2;

    i = Integer.valueOf(s).intValue();  // this wastes an object
    i = Integer.parseInt(s);            // this is better

    i2 = Integer.valueOf(i).intValue(); // this wastes an object
    i2 = i;                             // this is better

    String s3 = Integer.valueOf(i2).toString(); // this wastes an object
    s3 = Integer.toString(i2);                  // this is better

    return i2;
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid unnecessary casts

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unnecessary Cast

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
This rule detects when a cast is unnecessary while accessing collection elements. This rule is mostly useful for old java code before generics where introduced with java 1.5.

Example(s):

public class UnnecessaryCastSample {
    public void method() {
        List<String> stringList = Arrays.asList("a", "b");
        String element = (String) stringList.get(0); // this cast is unnecessary
        String element2 = stringList.get(0);
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Avoid unused imports such as ''{0}''

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unused Imports

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid unused import statements to prevent unwanted dependencies. This rule will also find unused on demand imports, i.e. import com.foo.*.

Example(s):

import java.io.File;  // not referenced or required
import java.util.*;   // not referenced or required

public class Foo {}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Unnecessary modifier{0} on {1} ''{2}''{3}

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Unnecessary Modifier

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Fields in interfaces and annotations are automatically public static final, and methods are public abstract. Classes, interfaces or annotations nested in an interface or annotation are automatically public static (all nested interfaces and annotations are automatically static). Nested enums are automatically static. For historical reasons, modifiers which are implied by the context are accepted by the compiler, but are superfluous.

Example(s):

public @interface Annotation {
    public abstract void bar();     // both abstract and public are ignored by the compiler
    public static final int X = 0;  // public, static, and final all ignored
    public static class Bar {}      // public, static ignored
    public static interface Baz {}  // ditto
}
public interface Foo {
    public abstract void bar();     // both abstract and public are ignored by the compiler
    public static final int X = 0;  // public, static, and final all ignored
    public static class Bar {}      // public, static ignored
    public static interface Baz {}  // ditto
}
public class Bar {
    public static interface Baz {}  // static ignored
    public static enum FoorBar {    // static ignored
        FOO;
    }
}

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: Useless parentheses.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Useless Parentheses

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: {0} variable {1} should begin with {2}

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: Variable Naming Conventions

attribute.name: HelpText
Description
attribute.value: Avoid using 'while' statements without curly braces

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: While Loops Must Use Braces

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Avoid using 'while' statements without using braces to surround the code block. If the code formatting or indentation is lost then it becomes difficult to separate the code being controlled from the rest.
This rule is deprecated and will be removed with PMD 7.0.0. The rule is replaced by the rule [Control Statement Braces](#PMD_CSB).
Example(s):
```java while (true) // not recommended x++;
while (true) { // preferred approach x++; } ```

attribute.name: Description
attribute.value: The loop can be simplified.

attribute.name: DisplayName
attribute.value: While Loop With Literal Boolean

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
do {} while (true); requires reading the end of the statement before it is apparent that it loops forever, whereas while (true) {} is easier to understand.

do {} while (false); is redundant, and if an inner variable scope is required, a block {} is sufficient.

while (false) {} will never execute the block and can be removed in its entirety.

Example(s):

public class Example {
  {
    while (true) { } // allowed
    while (false) { } // disallowed
    do { } while (true); // disallowed
    do { } while (false); // disallowed
  }
}

Method: ratio of the total comment lines of the method (TCLOC) to the sum of its total comment (TCLOC) and total logical lines of code (TLLOC).
Class: ratio of the total comment lines of the class (TCLOC) to the sum of its total comment (TCLOC) and total logical lines of code (TLLOC).

attribute.name: DisplayName

attribute.name: HelpText
attribute.value:
Method: ratio of the total comment lines of the method (TCLOC) to the sum of its total comment (TCLOC) and total logical lines of code (TLLOC).

Class: ratio of the total comment lines of the class (TCLOC) to the sum of its total comment (TCLOC) and total logical lines of code (TLLOC).

Package: ratio of the total comment lines of the package (TCLOC) to the sum of its total comment (TCLOC) and total logical lines of code (TLLOC).

Component: ratio of the total comment lines of the component (TCLOC) to the sum of its total comment (TCLOC) and total logical lines of code (TLLOC).
